questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She has had excessive fatigue for the last month. A few weeks ago, she was diagnosed with carpal tunnel syndrome for which she received a padded cast. She has mild persistent asthma and anxiety disorder. She is sexually active with her husband of 19 years. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4–6 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She works a desk job in accounting and has recently been working long hours due to an upcoming company merger. Her father has a history of a brain tumor. Current medications include alprazolam and a fluticasone-formoterol inhaler. She drinks 2–3 glasses of red wine per night and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 16 years. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 81.6 kg (180 lb); her BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 128/80 mm Hg. Examination shows no abnormalities. Fasting laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13 g/dL


Serum



 Na+
137 mEq/L


 K+
4.6 mEq/L


 Cl-
105 mEq/L


 HCO3-
22 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
17 mg/dL


 Glucose

160 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's hyperglycemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased insulin production results in hyperglycemia, because insulin is the only glucose-lowering hormone. An autoimmune-mediated decline of insulin production is the major pathophysiology in type 1 diabetes mellitus. Type 1 diabetes mellitus typically manifests during childhood, presenting with weight loss or sometimes acutely as diabetic ketoacidosis. This patient is an obese, middle-aged woman, which makes a different pathomechanism more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Numerous drugs may promote hyperglycemia, e.g. corticosteroids, catecholamines, thiazides, calcineurin-inhibitors, or beta blockers. While this patient is using inhaled corticosteroids to control her asthma, systemic effects of inhaled corticosteroids are typically absent, or – with very high doses – mild.

C) INCORRECT:

Stress causes increased levels of glucocorticoids and catecholamines, both of which are diabetogenic hormones that promote hyperglycemia. While the patient appears to be under moderate work-related stress that may be contributing to her hyperglycemia, physiological levels of these hormones do not result in frank diabetes mellitus.

D) INCORRECT:

Excess ACTH results in Cushing syndrome, which manifests with hyperglycemia and obesity. However, patients with Cushing syndrome typically have additional signs and symptoms of hypercortisolism, e.g., moon facies, easy bruising, proximal muscle atrophy, or hypertension. Additionally, laboratory studies would likely show hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of IGF-1 may be seen in acromegaly, which is caused by excess production of growth hormone in the pituitary gland. IGF-1 may promote hyperglycemia by interfering with insulin binding to its receptors. While hyperglycemia is a feature of acromegaly, the patient does not present with other signs or symptoms of acromegaly (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia, coarsened facial and skull features, amenorrhea, or hypertension).

F) CORRECT:

Insulin resistance and subsequent pancreatic β-cell dysfunction are the major pathophysiological mechanisms of type 2 diabetes mellitus. This patient meets the criteria for obesity, a cardinal risk factor for type 2 diabetes mellitus. A fasting glucose level of ≥ 126 mg/dL is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus.

Obesity with increased plasma levels of free fatty acids impairs insulin-dependent glucose uptake into myocytes and adipocytes, resulting in hyperglycemia. The absence of insulin-dependent inhibition of hepatic glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis further promotes hyperglycemia. Initially, insulin resistance is compensated by increased insulin secretion. Over the course of the disease, pancreatic β-cell production capacity declines, and diabetes mellitus manifests as fasting hyperglycemia.
questions.hint: This patient has class I obesity (BMI > 30 kg/m2), which increases her risk of this endocrine condition.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain in her ankle. She twisted her right ankle inward when walking on uneven ground the previous day. She describes the pain as 6 out of 10 in intensity. She is able to bear weight on the ankle and ambulate. Three weeks ago, she had an episode of gastroenteritis that lasted for two days and resolved spontaneously. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. The patient drinks 8–10 beers each week and does not smoke or use illicit drugs. She adheres to a strict vegetarian diet. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg. Examination of the right ankle shows edema along the lateral aspect, pain with eversion, and tenderness to palpation on the lateral malleolus. The foot is warm to the touch and has dry skin. Pedal pulses are palpable. She has decreased sensation to light touch and vibration on the plantar surface of both feet and dorsal aspects of the first toe bilaterally. She has a full range of motion with 5/5 strength in flexion and extension of both first toes. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15.1 g/dL


Hemoglobin A1c
8.1%


Leukocyte count
7200/mm3



Mean corpuscular volume
82 μm3



Serum



Na+

136 mEq/L


K+

4.0 mEq/L


Cl-

101 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
24 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.3 mg/dL


Thyroid-stimulating hormone
1.2 μU/mL


Which of the following is the most likely cause of the decreased sensation in this patient?

choices.text: Injury to the common peroneal nerve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A demyelinating polyneuropathy is characteristic of conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome and chronic inflammatory demyelinating neuropathy. In demyelinating neuropathies, motor abnormalities are usually as severe as or more severe than sensory abnormalities. This patient has a chronic axonal neuropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Common peroneal nerve injury can result in loss of sensation but the dorsal foot and the lateral calf are typically affected. Moreover, this condition is usually caused by traumatic injuries to the knee, fracture of the fibula, or constant pressure on the lateral knee, not ankle injuries. Foot drop and a slapping gait are also associated with common peroneal nerve injury. Sensory loss on the plantar surface of the feet without motor symptoms makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Although stretch injury to the sural nerve may be caused by lateral ankle injuries, this type of injury typically results in burning pain near the lateral malleolus and over the lateral aspect of the dorsal foot. The patient's loss of sensation in the plantar aspects of both feet and the dorsal aspects of both first toes is not consistent with damage to the sural nerve.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) deficiency can cause bilateral peripheral neuropathy. Vitamin B12 deficiency is more common in vegans and vegetarians who do not eat enough eggs or dairy products, and metformin therapy is a risk factor for vitamin B12 deficiency. However, vitamin B12 deficiency would also likely manifest with macrocytic anemia. The normal hemoglobin value with normal MCV and the presence of a specific risk factor in this patient make a different diagnosis more likely.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with chronic untreated type 2 diabetes mellitus (HbA1c > 6.5) have an increased risk of developing complications resulting from microvascular damage, which typically arises 5–10 years after disease onset. Complications include diabetic neuropathy, retinopathy, and nephropathy. This patient's loss of sensation on the feet bilaterally is consistent with diabetic neuropathy, which is typically a chronic axonal neuropathy and manifests with progressive symmetric sensory loss in the distal extremities (stocking-glove distribution). Patients may also report a burning sensation (dysesthesia) in the affected areas. In diabetic neuropathy, sensory abnormalities often appear before motor abnormalities (e.g., decreased ankle reflex).

This patient's elevated creatinine also suggests diabetic nephropathy, which occurs as a result of microvascular damage to the kidneys.

F) INCORRECT:

Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency may occur in patients with alcohol use disorder and patients with dry beriberi (due to thiamine deficiency) may have symmetrical peripheral neuropathy of the distal extremities. Although this patient drinks more than the recommended amount, peripheral neuropathy due to thiamine deficiency usually includes both sensory and motor impairments. This patient's lack of motor impairment suggests a mechanism that predominantly affects sensory nerves.
questions.hint: This patient's sensory abnormalities are most likely the result of a nontraumatic peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of double vision and unilateral right eye pain that began this morning. His vision improves when he covers either eye. He has hypertension, mild cognitive impairment, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, donepezil, metformin, and insulin with meals. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 132/75 mm Hg. His right eye is abducted and depressed with slight intorsion. He can only minimally adduct the right eye. Visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. Extraocular movements of the left eye are normal. An MRI of the head shows no abnormalities. His fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 325 mg/dL. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ptosis occurs in patients with CN III palsy because the levator palpebrae superioris muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. Whereas patients with CN III palsy due to compression usually show dilated pupils, those with diabetic mononeuropathy normally do not have pupillary involvement because the microangiopathy typically involves the vasa nervorum within the oculomotor nerve, while the pial blood vessels (which supply the superficial parasympathetic fibers) are usually spared.

CN III palsy due to diabetic or hypertensive microangiopathy usually improves with blood pressure and glycemic control. Patients should be monitored closely (every 2 days) during the first week. If the diplopia, ptosis, and/or external ophthalmoplegia worsen during this period or persist after 3 months, an MRI should be performed.
Image Description:

Oculomotor nerve palsy (here, of the left eye) causes ipsilateral impairment of both motor and autonomic (parasympathetic) nerve functions. Paralysis of the inferior rectus, medial rectus, superior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles results in downward deviation (hypotropia) and outward deviation (exotropia) of the affected eye (down-and-out gaze) due to the unopposed actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Weakness of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle results in ptosis and impairment of parasympathetic function in mydriasis (as well as loss of accommodation and pupillary light reflex, which are not shown). Patients present with horizontal or horizontal and vertical double vision (diplopia) that worsens when turning the gaze away from the affected side. The ptosis, however, may prevent patients from experiencing diplopia.

B) INCORRECT:

A dilated and fixed pupil in a patient with an oculomotor nerve palsy is typically seen with compression (e.g., from an aneurysm, tentorial herniation) or complete transection of the oculomotor nerve (e.g., base of the skull fractures) because the parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction are located superficially on the oculomotor nerve. However, there is no clinical or radiological evidence of elevated intracranial pressure and/or hemiparesis to suggest tentorial herniation, or a history of trauma to suggest a skull base fracture; aneurysms only account for approx. 5% of cases of isolated CN III palsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Miosis and anhidrosis are seen in patients with preganglionic and central Horner's syndrome. Although patients with severe long-standing diabetes mellitus may present with Horner's syndrome as a result of diabetic autonomic neuropathy, Horner's syndrome is not typically associated with CN III palsy.
Image Description:

Orbital region of a female patient

The left eyelid is drooping (ptosis), the left pupil is smaller (miosis) than the right, and the left bulbus appears sunken into the orbit (enophthalmos).

Ptosis, miosis and anhydrosis (not shown) represent the classical triad of Horner syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Bitemporal hemianopsia occurs with lesions that compress the optic chiasm such as a pituitary adenoma, craniopharyngioma, meningioma, or a hypothalamic glioma. A tumor at the optic chiasm is unlikely to cause an isolated CN III palsy. Also, the MRI is normal in this patient and does not reveal a sellar tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

A positive swinging flashlight test indicates a relative afferent pupillary defect. An afferent pupillary defect is caused by retinal and/or optic nerve lesions (e.g., central retinal vessel occlusion, extensive retinal detachment, optic neuritis), and not by lesions of the oculomotor nerve, which transmits the efferent impulses of the pupillary reflex. A patient with an afferent pupillary defect would also have decreased visual acuity in the affected eye, whereas this patient has 20/20 vision in both eyes.
questions.hint: The most likely cause of isolated oculomotor nerve palsy in a patient with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus is diabetic mononeuropathy, which occurs as a result of microangiopathic ischemia.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of increased frequency of micturition over the past month. He has also been waking up frequently during the night to urinate. Over the past 2 months, he has had a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is in the 40th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and osmolality are within the reference range. Urine studies show:


Blood
negative


Protein
negative


Glucose
1+


Leukocyte esterase
negative


Osmolality
620 mOsmol/kg H2O


Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Insulin resistance is a pathophysiological feature of type 2 diabetes mellitus, which typically develops in individuals with obesity, a genetic disposition (first-degree relative with diabetes), and features of metabolic syndrome. Affected individuals are usually > 40 years old, though onset can also rarely occur in teenagers with obesity. Since this patient is young, has no family history of serious illness, and is of normal weight, type 2 diabetes mellitus is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated thyroxine levels are a diagnostic finding in individuals with hyperthyroidism. Typical clinical features include heat intolerance, weight loss, diarrhea, tachycardia, and goiter. Despite this patient's weight loss, the lack of other common findings makes hyperthyroidism unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal resistance to ADH is seen in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) and is caused by defects in ADH receptors. These defects can be due to drugs, hypokalemia, or renal disease. Lack of response to ADH impairs the kidney's ability to concentrate urine, resulting in polyuria (> 3 L/day) with diluted urine, nocturia, and polydipsia. Urine osmolality is typically < 300 mOsmol/kg, and is often < 100 mOsmol/kg. Since urine osmolality in this patient is normal, nephrogenic DI can be ruled out.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

D) CORRECT:

Absolute insulin deficiency is the underlying pathology of type 1 diabetes mellitus, caused by autoimmune-mediated destruction of pancreatic β cells. The resulting elevation of blood glucose levels leads to a range of symptoms, typically including polyuria, nocturia, polydipsia, and increased appetite. Nonspecific symptoms of fatigue, weight loss, and an increased tendency to infections (e.g., skin infections, UTIs) are also common. The symptoms usually develop within days to a few weeks or manifest suddenly with diabetic ketoacidosis. While glucosuria detected via urine dipstick is suggestive of diabetes mellitus, the diagnosis is confirmed through an oral glucose tolerance test or a random blood glucose level ≥ 200 mg/dL.

E) INCORRECT:

Compulsive water intake is a feature of primary polydipsia, which is a condition seen in individuals with psychiatric diseases (e.g., schizophrenia, obsessive-compulsive disorder). It is characterized by a compulsion to drink large amounts of fluid despite the absence of thirst, resulting in polyuria with low urine osmolality and hyponatremia. Since the patient's parents report no unusual behavior, and urine osmolality and serum electrolyte levels are normal, primary polydipsia can be ruled out.

F) INCORRECT:

An inadequate ADH secretion is seen in individuals with central diabetes insipidus and is caused by an absent or insufficient hypothalamic synthesis of ADH. The lack of ADH impairs the kidney's ability to concentrate urine, resulting in polyuria (> 3 L/day) with diluted urine, nocturia, and polydipsia. Urine osmolality is typically < 300 mOsmol/kg, and is often < 100 mOsmol/kg. Since urine osmolality in this patient is normal, inadequate ADH secretion can be ruled out.
questions.hint: Polyuria, nocturia, and weight loss in an adolescent with 1+ glucose on urine dipstick are suggestive of type 1 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female college student comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of vaginal itching and burning. She also noticed white vaginal discharge despite cleaning her genital area daily using a "soap-free, natural" vaginal douche. She is worried that she might have contracted a sexually transmitted disease after meeting her new boyfriend around one month ago. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. The patient swims for the college swimming team. She had an intrauterine device implanted 3 months ago and does not use barrier protection. She smokes one pack of cigarettes per day and does not drink alcohol. Speculum examination shows an erythematous vagina covered in copious white discharge. Her vaginal pH is 4.4 and the microscopic image of a potassium hydroxide preparation shows multiple pseudohyphae. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Smoking decreases the number of vaginal Lactobacillus species, has an antiestrogenic effect, and dysregulates immune function, making smokers more prone to bacterial vaginosis, which manifests with a gray or milky vaginal discharge that has a fishy odor. Discharge in candidal vulvovaginitis, on the contrary, is usually white, crumbly, and odorless. Smoking has not been shown to be a risk factor for vaginal yeast infection, although it is one for oral candidiasis in immunocompromised patients (e.g., patients with diabetes).

B) INCORRECT:

While swimming pools do not predispose to Candida infection in general, there is a debate about whether wearing damp, tight-fitting bathing suits for an extended period of time might create an optimal environment for yeast and promote overgrowth. However, another predisposing factor is much more significant in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Frequent vaginal douching to cleanse the inside of the vagina and the use of soaps with perfumes and irritating chemicals are risk factors for bacterial vaginosis because they disturb the normal vaginal microflora. Vaginal douching decreases the amount of lactic acid-producing lactobacilli, which leads to an increase in the pH balance. A pH higher than 4.5 is no longer acidic enough to prevent the proliferation of certain organisms, and contributes, e.g., to an increase in Gardnerella vaginalis.

D) INCORRECT:

Unprotected sexual intercourse is a risk factor for several sexually transmitted infections, such as trichomoniasis and Chlamydia. However, Candida overgrowth is commonly precipitated by other factors.

E) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices may be associated with gynecologic infections and pelvic inflammatory disease. However, the risk is very low, making another cause much more likely in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus (DM) predisposes to vaginal yeast infections since high levels of glucose provide the carbon needed for Candida overgrowth and infection. Moreover, DM results in immunodeficiency, which is also associated with an increased risk of persistent or recurrent yeast infection. Other risk factors that precipitate overgrowth of C. albicans are systemic antibiotic therapy and pregnancy, in which case high levels of estrogen favor overgrowth by Candida. Treatment of acute infection consists of topical azoles (e.g., miconazole, clotrimazole) or a single dose of oral fluconazole. Maintaining normal blood sugar levels may help reduce the risk of recurrent or persistent infections in patients with DM.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast
questions.hint: Multiple pseudohyphae on wet mount preparation are characteristic of Candida infection.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics 30 minutes after the onset of nausea, sweating, and palpitations. On the way to the hospital, the patient had an episode of nonbloody vomiting. He had a peripheral intravenous catheter placed to start administration of fluids. He has no history of similar episodes. Two years ago, he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus, which is controlled with basal insulin and metformin. His wife reports that for the past 2 weeks he has been trying to lose weight and has adjusted his diet and activity level. He follows a low-carb diet and runs 3 times a week for exercise; he returned from a run 2 hours ago. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. He appears well-nourished and anxious. His pulse is 105/min and blood pressure is 118/78 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Physical examination shows pallor and diaphoresis. His fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 35 mg/dL. Shortly after, the patient loses consciousness and starts shaking. The most appropriate next step in management is administration of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous thiamine is the treatment of choice in patients with suspected thiamine deficiency (e.g., malnourishment, a history of heavy alcohol use) to prevent the onset or exacerbation of Wernicke encephalopathy (WE) prior to treating hypoglycemia. Although this patient presents with confusion, he shows no other signs of WE (e.g., oculomotor dysfunction, ataxia) and has no relevant risk factors for thiamine deficiency. A different management step is required for the rapid correction of this patient's hypoglycemia.

B) CORRECT:

Intravenous administration of 50% dextrose with continuous serum glucose monitoring is the most appropriate next step in the management of acute severe hypoglycemia in an unconscious patient who is actively seizing. Alternatively, if the patient is conscious and tolerating oral intake, oral glucose or fast-acting carbohydrates such as fruit juice or candy should be given. If both IV and oral routes are unavailable, intramuscular, subcutaneous, or intranasal glucagon should be administered.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous lorazepam is the best initial therapy for patients with status epilepticus, which is characterized by ≥ 5 min of continuous seizures or ≥ 2 seizures with consciousness not being fully regained in the interictal period. While this patient's loss of consciousness and shaking are consistent with an acute seizure, he does not meet the criteria for status epilepticus. The most appropriate next step in management is to address the underlying cause of this patient's seizure.

D) INCORRECT:

Octreotide can be used for the management of severe symptomatic hypoglycemia due to sulfonylurea intoxication. However, this patient takes insulin and metformin (a biguanide) rather than sulfonylureas, and his hypoglycemia is likely caused by recent changes in diet and physical exercise. A different step in management is more appropriate at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular, subcutaneous, or intranasal glucagon is the most appropriate next step in the management of an unconscious patient with severe hypoglycemia in a nonhospital setting, where intravenous access is not readily available. While glucagon would address the patient's hypoglycemia, there is a quicker and more effective treatment available for this patient who had a peripheral intravenous catheter placed on the way to the hospital.
questions.hint: Nausea, diaphoresis, palpitations, and confusion, followed by a seizure in a patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus who has recently changed his diet and exercise regimen, are consistent with acute severe hypoglycemia. His low blood glucose concentration confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of fatigue and increased urination. The patient reports that he has been drinking more than usual because he is constantly thirsty. He has avoided driving for the past 8 weeks because of intermittent episodes of blurred vision. He had elevated blood pressure at his previous visit but is otherwise healthy. Because of his busy work schedule, his diet consists primarily of fast food. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 93 kg (205 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. His pulse is 75/min and his blood pressure is 144/94 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin A1c
7.1%


Serum



 Glucose
220 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


 Total cholesterol
270 mg/dL


 HDL cholesterol
50 mg/dL


 Triglycerides
180 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood
negative


 Glucose
2+


 Ketones
negative


 Albumin:creatinine ratio


280 mg/g (N < 30)


In addition to metformin therapy and counseling for lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: No additional management is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

All patients with T2DM aged 40–75 years should receive lipid-lowering treatment regardless of baseline lipid levels to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. However, statins are the first-line therapy, not fibrates. Fibrates are used in the treatment of severe hypertriglyceridemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravitreal vascular endothelial growth factor inhibitor injections are used to treat diabetic retinopathy and diabetic macular edema. These complications generally occur in the late stages of T2DM; ∼ 25% of patients with T2DM develop diabetic retinopathy after 15 years. This patient's blurred vision is most likely due to glucose fluctuations and resulting osmotic swelling of the lens, which is a classic early symptom of T2DM.

C) INCORRECT:

Insulin therapy should be considered in patients with newly diagnosed T2DM who present with symptoms of hyperglycemia (as seen here), signs of a continued catabolic state (e.g., weight loss), initial glucose ≥ 300 mg/dL, or HbA1c > 10%. However, a basal insulin regimen with long-acting insulins (e.g., glargine insulin, NPH insulin) should be started initially. Rapid-acting insulins (e.g., lispro) are added to basal insulin regimens when glycemic control is not achieved with basal insulin alone.

D) CORRECT:

An increased urine albumin:creatinine ratio (UACR) indicates albuminuria (UACR of 30–300 mg/g indicates microalbuminuria). While all first-line antihypertensive agents are appropriate for adults with diabetes and hypertension, an ACE inhibitor (ACEI) or an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is the antihypertensive of choice if the patient has albuminuria as these drugs have been shown to have a renoprotective effect in this patient group. The blood pressure target should be individualized; for patients with a high 10-year ASCVD risk, < 130/80 mm Hg is an appropriate treatment goal if safely attained. The American Diabetes Association also recommends prescribing SGLT-2 inhibitors for renoprotection in patients with albuminuria.

In addition to lifestyle modifications, metformin, an ACEI (or ARB), and an SGLT-2 inhibitor, this patient should also be initiated on statin therapy, which is indicated in all patients aged 40–75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of lipid levels.

Additionally, a short course of basal insulin therapy should be considered for patients with symptomatic hyperglycemia (as seen here), signs of a continued catabolic state (e.g., weight loss), initial glucose ≥ 300 mg/dL, or HbA1c > 10%.

E) INCORRECT:

Aspirin therapy should be considered for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) in patients 40–59 years of age with a high 10-year ASCVD risk (≥ 10%) and a low risk of bleeding. In patients > 60 years of age, aspirin is not recommended for the primary prevention of ASCVD.

F) INCORRECT:

Given this patient's comorbidities, additional management besides lifestyle modifications and monotherapy with metformin is required.
questions.hint: Random plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL in a patient with symptoms of hyperglycemia (i.e., fatigue, polyuria, polydipsia, blurred vision) is consistent with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Comorbidities are common in patients with T2DM and should be addressed.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband for increasing confusion over the past 12 hours. Her husband reports that she has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus; she has not been able to refill her home insulin supply over the last 3 days because of insurance issues. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 115/60 mm Hg. She is confused and oriented only to person. Examination shows left periorbital swelling, mucopurulent rhinorrhea, and a black necrotic spot over her nose. There is discharge of the left eye with associated proptosis. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Na+

132 mEq/L


 Cl-

96 mEq/L


 K+

4.2 mEq/L


 HCO3-

16 mEq/L


 Glucose

520 mg/dL


 Ketones

positive


Urine ketones
positive


A CT scan of the face shows obliteration of the left ethmoid, maxillary, and sphenoid sinuses. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Rhizopus oryzae is the most commonly implicated organism, followed by Mucor species, in the pathophysiology of mucormycosis. Patients typically present with signs of a unilateral maxillofacial infection such as retro-orbital headache, facial pain, nasal discharge, and fever. Severe cases can also lead to altered levels of consciousness (indicative of cerebral involvement), eschars (due to microvascular occlusion and resulting tissue necrosis), and cranial nerve palsies. The presence of eschar is particularly concerning for this condition. This patient has several of these early and late signs and symptoms. Moreover, diabetic ketoacidosis is strongly implicated in the pathophysiology of this infection. The history of missed insulin doses combined with urine and serum ketones is diagnostic of ketoacidosis.
Image Description:

Bilateral edema of the eyelid and purulent exudation from both eyes is visible. There are spotted areas of necrotic eschar, especially close to the inner canthus of the right eye, on the right eyelid, and on the nose.

These findings, especially in an immunocompromised patient, suggest Mucorales infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic coccobacillus. With the advent of the Hib vaccine, the incidence of serious bacterial infection attributable to encapsulated strains of H. influenzae has dropped sharply. In developed nations, infection with unencapsulated strains still occurs but is usually mild, causing acute otitis media, conjunctivitis, or sinusitis in children. In developing nations, where vaccination is less common, encapsulated strains may still cause bacteremia, pneumonia, or acute epiglottitis. This adult has no indication of missed vaccinations and has a progressive, localized infection that is not frequently associated with H. influenzae.

C) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is a common fungal species that exists as normal skin flora. In patients with diabetes, there is an increased risk of developing localized overgrowth of the fungus in the mouth, causing thrush. In immunocompromised patients, disseminated candidiasis or candidal esophagitis may develop. However, C. albicans is not known to cause necrotizing facial infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella pneumoniae is part of the normal bacterial flora of the body but can become an opportunistic pathogen; the presence of diabetes, especially with poor control, is a risk factor for infection with this bacterium. The most common sites of K. pneumoniae infection are the urinary tract (cystitis and pyelonephritis) and the lower respiratory tract (pneumonia). This patient is certainly at risk of developing an infection with this agent but the current presentation of necrotizing maxillofacial infection would be very unusual for K. pneumoniae.

E) INCORRECT:

Moraxella catarrhalis is common respiratory bacterium. Infection with this organism most commonly manifests with upper respiratory or otitis media symptoms. Severe, necrotizing infection, as described in this patient, would be extremely unlikely.

F) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive coccus that classically forms clusters when viewed microscopically. This virulent bacterial species is associated with many infections; skin manifestations include cellulitis, impetigo, folliculitis, and even necrotizing fasciitis. The most common presentations are isolated skin abscesses in an adult or impetigo in a child. A necrotizing infection of the face would be very uncommon for this pathogen. Moreover, the presence of diabetic ketoacidosis and a newly formed eschar is more concerning for infection from a different organism.

G) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a highly virulent bacterial species. It is implicated in many infectious conditions and can be especially difficult to treat in cases of nosocomial or multidrug-resistant infections. With regard to the subpopulation of diabetic patients, Pseudomonas classically causes malignant otitis externa. This condition leads to severe ear pain, discharge from the ear canal, facial nerve palsy, and local extension to periauricular structures. Examination may show granulation tissue (often described as “sand-like”). Besides poorly controlled diabetes mellitus, other risk factors include advancing age and general immunosuppression. Despite her diabetes, this patient's presentation is inconsistent with malignant otitis externa.

H) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common gram-positive pathogenic bacterium. It is the most common cause of sinusitis, though the clinical presentation is generally mild and consists of rhinorrhea, facial tenderness (especially on palpation of the affected sinuses), and headache. Numerous other infectious conditions are attributable to this bacterium, including dermatologic infections (abscesses and cellulitis, most often). This patient is presenting with a severe, necrotizing skin infection in the setting of poorly controlled diabetes, altered sensorium, and an eschar. This constellation is very concerning for a more sinister infectious agent than S. pneumoniae.
questions.hint: This woman has a unilateral rhino-orbital-cerebral infection caused by a pathogen that is particularly common among patients with diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient. She recently moved to the area. She feels well. She has dyslipidemia treated with pravastatin. Her past three Pap smears have shown no abnormalities; the most recent Pap smear was 2 years ago. Her maternal aunt was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 56 years. The patient smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit 10 years ago. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Her pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 129/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate health maintenance recommendation at this time?

choices.text: Obtain low-dose CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

For cervical cancer screening in women 30–65 years of age, the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommends Pap smears every 3 years with cervical cytology alone, every 5 years with human papillomavirus (HPV) testing alone, or every 5 years with HPV testing in combination with cytology (HPV/Pap cotesting). This 38-year-old patient had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago and therefore does not need further testing at this time.

B) CORRECT:

Measurement of fasting blood glucose (FBG) concentration is routinely used to screen for diabetes mellitus (DM). Although screening recommendations for DM differ among expert groups, this 38-year-old patient with dyslipidemia and a BMI of 29 kg/m2 meets the screening criteria of both the United States Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) and the American Diabetes Association (ADA). The USPSTF recommends screening individuals 35–70 years of age with overweight or obesity. The ADA recommends screening all individuals ≥ 35 years of age and individuals < 35 years of age who: have overweight or obesity and ≥ 1 additional risk factor for T2DM; have a history of prediabetes or gestational diabetes; or have any risk-enhancing comorbidities (e.g., HIV infection, cystic fibrosis, post organ transplantation).

Besides FBG, other tests used to screen for DM include hemoglobin A1C (HbA1C) and the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT). Each of the following findings can be used to establish a diagnosis of diabetes mellitus: FBG ≥ 126 mg/dL, HbA1C ≥ 6.5%, and a 2-hour plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL during an OGTT.

C) INCORRECT:

Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) screening with abdominal ultrasonography can be considered in individuals < 65 years of age who have multiple risk factors for AAA or a family history of AAA, neither of which applies to this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

An annual low-dose CT scan of the chest is indicated for lung cancer screening in individuals aged 50–80 years with a smoking history of ≥ 20 pack years. This patient has a smoking history of 10 pack years and therefore does not require screening at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Breast cancer screening is generally not recommended before 40 years of age (except for individuals at high risk of breast cancer). Additionally, when breast cancer screening is appropriate, screening mammography is the recommended screening modality, not breast ultrasonography. Breast ultrasonography is typically reserved for individuals < 30 years of age with a palpable breast mass or other findings concerning for breast cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

In individuals 19–49 years of age, pneumococcal vaccination is only indicated if there are risk factors for invasive pneumococcal disease. Because this 38-year-old patient only has dyslipidemia and a remote history of smoking, she does not need the pneumococcal vaccine at this time.
questions.hint: This patient's dyslipidemia and overweight put her at risk of developing a chronic medical condition that can cause microvascular damage.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of bilateral blurry vision and difficulty driving at night that has been worsening progressively over the past 5 months. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. His hemoglobin A1c concentration is 8.9%. A slit-lamp shows cloudy opacities of the lenses bilaterally. The patient's eye condition is most likely due to increased activity of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Galactokinase catalyzes the conversion of galactose to galactose-1-phosphate. Deficiency of this enzyme, not overactivation, causes mild galactosemia (galactokinase deficiency), resulting in cataract formation due to accumulation of galactitol in the lens of the eye.

B) INCORRECT:

Aldolase B is predominantly expressed in the liver and converts fructose-1-phosphate to dihydroxyacetone phosphate (DHAP) and glyceraldehyde. No specific pathologic condition has been associated with overactivity of this enzyme. Its deficiency does however result in hereditary fructose intolerance, which typically presents with hypoglycemia (due to inhibition of glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis) and vomiting following consumption of fructose-containing food.
Image Description:

(1) Essential fructosuria is an inherited benign metabolic disorder that is due to a deficiency of the fructokinase enzyme within the liver.

(2) Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive defect in the fructose metabolism pathway due to an aldolase B enzyme deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucokinase is a hexokinase isoenzyme exclusively present in the liver and beta cells of the pancreas, promoting glucose storage and insulin secretion, respectively. Unlike hexokinase, it has low affinity and high capacity for glucose and is inducible by insulin. It has no role in cataract formation.

D) CORRECT:

Aldose reductase catalyzes the reduction of glucose to sorbitol, which is subsequently oxidized to fructose by sorbitol dehydrogenase enzyme. At normal blood glucose levels, only a small part of glucose is metabolized via this polyol pathway. However, in chronic hyperglycemia due to poorly controlled diabetes, sorbitol formation increases significantly, causing osmotic damage in tissues with low sorbitol dehydrogenase activity (e.g., lens, retina, kidney, and myelin sheath). Consequently, patients present with retinopathy, nephropathy, peripheral neuropathy, and bilateral cataracts as seen in this patient.
Image Description:

During hyperglycemic states, excess glucose is shunted from the hexokinase/glycolysis pathway into various other metabolic pathways. Cells containing aldose reductase convert glucose to sorbitol, which is then converted into fructose. Organs lacking sorbitol dehydrogenase (red) accumulate sorbitol, resulting in osmotic damage.

E) INCORRECT:

Sorbitol dehydrogenase converts sorbitol into fructose, which can be used as energy substrate in the liver and seminal vesicles. The activity of this enzyme is low in the retina and lens. Hence, during chronic hyperglycemia, sorbitol can accumulate in these tissues, causing bilateral cataracts as seen in this patient. However, increased activity of this enzyme is not associated with any specific pathologic conditions.
questions.hint: This patient's physical examination shows bilateral cataracts, most likely due to his poorly-controlled diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: While walking through a park with his wife, a 51-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus develops nausea, sweating, pallor, and palpitations. For the past 3 weeks, he has been trying to lose weight and has adjusted his diet and activity level. He eats a low-carb diet and swims 3 times a week. The man returned home from a training session 2 hours ago. Current medications include basal insulin and metformin. Shortly before his wife returns from their car with his emergency medication kit, he becomes unconscious. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nitroglycerine provides symptomatic relief in a patient with acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The reduced pain sensation that can result from diabetic polyneuropathy may cause some diabetic patients to present with atypical anginal symptoms, such as dyspnea, diaphoresis, and nausea/vomiting. Although this patient has palpitations and diaphoresis, his symptoms and history are more suggestive of severe hypoglycemia.

B) INCORRECT:

The administration of epinephrine can increase blood glucose levels. Studies have shown, however, that the responses are neither reliable nor sustained. Subcutaneous or intramuscular epinephrine (EpiPen) is typically used in the management of anaphylaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral glucose with fast-acting carbohydrates (such as glucose tablets, candy, or juice) is an important part of management for conscious patients with hypoglycemia. This patient, however, is unconscious. Therefore, orally administered glucose is not feasible.

D) CORRECT:

Intramuscular glucagon is the treatment of choice in a nonhospital setting for patients with severe hypoglycemia who are unconscious or unable to tolerate oral delivery of fast-acting carbohydrates. Glucagon elevates endogenous glucose production through hepatic glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. It achieves this by binding a hepatic G protein-coupled receptor, thereby activating a G protein that stimulates adenylate cyclase. Adenylate cyclase produces more cAMP, which increases protein kinase A (PKA) activity. PKA-mediated phosphorylation activates gluconeogenesis by stimulating FBPase-2 and inhibiting PFK-2. PKA also promotes glycogenolysis by activating glycogen phosphorylase and inactivating glycogen synthase via phosphorylation. The net effect is a rapid increase in serum glucose levels. In a hospital setting, intravenous dextrose would be the treatment of choice.

E) INCORRECT:

Lorazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine used in the treatment of status epilepticus. In children, it would be administered rectally, whereas in adults, intramuscular or intravenous injection would be preferred. Furthermore, this patient does not have seizures, and his symptoms and history are more suggestive of severe hypoglycemia.

F) INCORRECT:

In a hospital setting, intravenous dextrose, rather than intra-arterial dextrose, is the treatment of choice for an unconscious person with severe hypoglycemia. Regardless of the application method, there is a more feasible treatment in a nonhospital setting.
questions.hint: This patient presents with nausea, sweating, pallor, and palpitations. Given his history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and the recent change in his diet and exercise regimen (especially without having adjusted his insulin dosage), the symptoms are highly suggestive of severe acute hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. One week ago, an oral glucose tolerance screening test showed elevated serum glucose levels. She has complied with the recommended diet and lifestyle modifications. Over the past week, home blood glucose monitoring showed elevated fasting and post-prandial blood glucose levels. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

DPP-4 inhibitors (gliptins) act via the inhibition of the enzyme dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4). Inhibition of DPP-4 lowers blood glucose levels by preventing the breakdown of glucagon-like peptide 1 in the gastrointestinal tract, which leads to an increase in insulin secretion, a decrease in glucagon secretion, and delayed gastric emptying. The use of DPP-4 inhibitors to treat gestational diabetes is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

SGLT-2 inhibitors act via the reversible inhibition of the sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT-2) in the proximal tubule of the kidney, which leads to decreased reabsorption of glucose. SGLT-2 inhibitors are not recommended for the treatment of gestational diabetes.

C) CORRECT:

Binding of insulin to its transmembrane receptor, a member of the tyrosine kinase family, induces autophosphorylation of tyrosine residues on the intracellular domain of the protein. This activates downstream signaling cascades that mediate insulin's homeostatic and anabolic effects, e.g., enhanced glucose uptake and glycogen synthesis/storage. All women with gestational diabetes should first attempt lifestyle interventions with strict blood glucose monitoring (4x daily) to meet glycemic goals before initiating pharmacotherapy.

Metformin and glyburide can be used in patients who refuse insulin therapy, but they are not recommended by the FDA as first-line treatment options.
Image Description:

Binding of insulin to the insulin receptor (tetrameric receptor tyrosine kinases of two α subunits and two β subunits):

(1) Resting state

(2) Binding of an insulin molecule to the extracellular α subunits → receptor undergoes conformational change → activation of tyrosine kinase domains (β subunit), which self-phosphorylate (autophosphorylation)

(3) Tyrosine kinase domains activate insulin receptor substrate (IRS) → activation of intracellular signal transduction pathways, especially Ras and protein kinase B (PKB)

D) INCORRECT:

Alpha-glucosidase inhibitors such as acarbose cause a decrease in intestinal glucose absorption. The use of acarbose in pregnancy has not been extensively studied and is not an appropriate treatment option for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Thiazolidinediones bind to the gamma subtype of the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR-γ) family, which is present on adipose tissue, muscle, and liver. Activation of these receptors reduces insulin resistance by enhancing peripheral glucose utilization and reducing hepatic glucose production. The use of thiazolidinediones in the treatment of gestational diabetes is considered experimental and is not recommended.

F) INCORRECT:

Sulfonylureas and meglitinides act on the ATP-dependent potassium channels on pancreatic β-cells. However, they act by closing, not opening, these channels. This leads to depolarization of the cell membrane, subsequent calcium influx, and an increase in insulin secretion. Glyburide may be used in women with gestational diabetes who refuse insulin therapy, but it is not the treatment of choice. Meglitinides are not recommended for the treatment of gestational diabetes.
questions.hint: This woman has gestational diabetes that has not responded to diet and lifestyle modifications. If lifestyle changes alone are not sufficient to achieve proper glycemic control, insulin is the preferred antihyperglycemic medication in pregnant women.

questions.text: A previously healthy 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for lethargy, increased thirst, and urinary frequency for 10 days. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her serum glucose concentration is 224 mg/dL. A urine dipstick is positive for ketone bodies. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Expression of human leukocyte antigen subtype A3

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Expression of human leukocyte antigen (HLA) subtype A3 is associated with hemochromatosis, while type 1 diabetes is associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4. Although hemochromatosis can present with diabetes mellitus (due to pancreas damage following iron accumulation), symptoms such as cirrhosis and a characteristic bronze skin tone, arthralgias, and cardiomyopathy would be expected. Furthermore, hemochromatosis commonly affects adults.

B) INCORRECT:

Antimitochondrial antibodies are not associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus. They are, however, commonly seen in primary biliary cholangitis. Type 1 diabetes mellitus is typically associated with anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies.

C) INCORRECT:

Some patients with type 1 diabetes develop insulin receptor antibodies, which attack the insulin receptor. However, complement-mediated destruction of insulin receptors has not been identified as a cause of type 1 diabetes.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, infiltration of autoreactive CD4 and CD8 positive T cells into the pancreatic islets leads to the progressive destruction of insulin-producing β cells, which ultimately results in insulin deficiency. The immune system is thought to be activated by one or more environmental triggers (e.g., a viral infection, dietary factors) in genetically susceptible individuals. The loss of functioning β cells continues over months to years; symptoms usually manifest once 80–90% of β cells have been destroyed.

E) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP) deposition happens in type 2 diabetes, not type 1 diabetes. IAPP is cosecreted with insulin; as peripheral insulin resistance worsens in type 2 diabetes, β cells increase insulin synthesis and secretion, which subsequently leads to increased IAPP secretion as well. In the late stages of the disease, the amyloid aggregates become toxic to β cells.
questions.hint: This slim adolescent presents with classic features of type 1 diabetes mellitus: polydipsia, polyuria, hyperglycemia, and ketonuria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of increased urinary frequency. He wakes up several times a night to urinate and feels fatigued during the day. He also complains of increased thirst; he drinks multiple liters of water and soda daily and still feels thirsty. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows patches of velvety hyperpigmentation in the axillae and on the posterior neck. Laboratory evaluation in this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum thyroxine is a laboratory finding that suggests hyperthyroidism (e.g., Graves disease or thyroid adenoma). A hyperthyroid metabolic state can cause fatigue. However, hyperthyroidism does not typically cause polyuria, polydipsia, or hyperpigmentation. Moreover, this patient shows none of the classical features of hyperthyroidism, e.g., diarrhea, palpitations, heat intolerance, tachycardia, or diaphoresis.

B) CORRECT:

Elevated glycated hemoglobin is detected by measuring serum HbA1c. HbA1c levels can be elevated in patients with diabetes mellitus and correlate with the average blood glucose level from the previous 8–12 weeks. This patient's polyuria and polydipsia are most likely caused by consistently elevated glucose serum levels over 180 mg/dL, which marks the limit of renal glucose reabsorption capacity. The subsequent glucosuria leads to polyuria through osmotic diuresis. The increased renal water loss causes polydipsia and potentially hypovolemia, which explains this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) can be seen in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or malignant prostate cancer. Obstructive BPH is associated with increased urinary frequency and nocturia in middle-aged men. However, patients with BPH usually complain of urinary dribbling, unsuccessful emptying of the bladder, and, occasionally, overflow incontinence. Polydipsia is uncommon.

D) INCORRECT:

Positive urinary leukocyte esterase suggests a urinary tract infection. Common manifestations include fever, pain or burning with urination, urinary frequency, or foul-smelling urine. Although this patient complains of increased urinary frequency, it has been present for several months, and he does not show any other signs or symptoms of infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Low urine osmolality indicates very dilute urine; this is observed in patients with diabetes insipidus, which also causes polyuria and polydipsia. However, low urine osmolality is uncommon in diabetes mellitus. Normal or elevated urine osmolality is expected as a result of glucosuria. Additionally, this patient's acanthosis nigricans would not be explained by diabetes insipidus.
questions.hint: Polyuria, polydipsia, and acanthosis nigricans in an adult suggest insulin resistance, which is the underlying pathology of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. She feels well. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 20.3 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her fasting serum glucose concentration is 132 mg/dL. Serum insulin concentration 30 minutes after oral glucose administration is 20 mIU/L (N = 30–230). Her hemoglobin A1C concentration is 7.1%. After a thorough workup, the physician concludes that the patient has a chronic condition that can likely be managed with diet only and that she is not at a significantly increased risk of micro- or macrovascular complications. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's condition?

choices.text: Defect in expression of glucokinase gene

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A defect in the expression of the glucokinase gene is the underlying pathology in patients with MODY type II. The defect causes an increase in the glucose threshold required to promote insulin secretion. MODY type II is managed with dietary modifications only, as medical treatment fails to lower glucose and HbA1c. In contrast to other subtypes of MODY, patients with MODY type II are not at risk for micro- or macrovascular complications, despite mild fasting hyperglycemia and chronically elevated HbA1c.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased endogenous cortisol production is found in Cushing disease. Cortisol promotes gluconeogenesis, leading to hyperglycemia, and increases peripheral insulin resistance, thereby promoting the development of diabetes mellitus. However, this patient does not have any of the typical signs of hypercortisolism (e.g., central obesity, muscle weakness, striae). Furthermore, patients with Cushing disease who develop diabetes generally benefit from antidiabetic medications, while this patient likely would not.

C) INCORRECT:

Resistance to insulin-mediated glucose uptake occurs in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. Affected individuals are typically overweight, which leads to elevated free fatty acids that interfere with insulin-mediated glucose uptake. Even though patients with type II diabetes mellitus can sometimes be managed with lifestyle modifications, most will eventually require medical therapy to prevent long-term complications, unlike in this case. Furthermore, this patient has a normal BMI.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoantibodies to pancreatic beta cells are the underlying cause of type I diabetes mellitus, which causes absolute insulin deficiency. Patients with type I diabetes require regular monitoring and are at high risk for micro- and macrovascular complications if not properly treated with exogenous insulin injections. This patient, though still of a plausible age for the onset of type I diabetes (i.e., childhood onset), can be treated with dietary modifications and is generally not at risk for vascular complications.

E) INCORRECT:

Mutations in hepatocyte nuclear factor 1 (HNF1) are responsible for the development of MODY type III. Defective HNF1 causes abnormal insulin secretion and lowers the threshold for glucose excretion in the kidneys, leading to glycosuria at a young age. Treatment is with sulfonylureas, which increase insulin release from the pancreas and are particularly effective in preventing long-term micro- and macrovascular complications in these patients.
questions.hint: This young patient has evidence of chronically elevated serum glucose concentrations (HbA1C of 7.1%) and inappropriate release of insulin in response to an oral glucose challenge. Based on her physician's assessment, she likely has a unique type of diabetes mellitus known as maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY), which is sufficiently treated with diet modifications only.

questions.text: A 52-year-old White man with hypertension comes to the physician because of frequent urination and increased thirst. He drinks 4 oz of alcohol daily and has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 106 kg (233 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin A1c of 8.5%. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive alcohol consumption is a risk factor for the development of acute and chronic pancreatitis, alcohol-associated liver disease, and malignancies such as esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. However, alcohol consumption is not associated with an increased risk of T2DM.

B) INCORRECT:

While the prevalence of type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) is highest among non-Hispanic White individuals, this patient has T2DM. The highest rates of T2DM are seen among Hispanic, African American, Native American, Asian American, and Pacific Islander populations. White race is not a risk factor for T2DM.

C) CORRECT:

A high-calorie diet and a sedentary lifestyle are risk factors for obesity (BMI > 30 kg/m2), which increases the risk of T2DM by intensifying peripheral insulin resistance. Insulin resistance inhibits glucose uptake from the bloodstream and impairs anabolic metabolism. Lifestyle modifications such as weight reduction, a balanced diet, and regular exercise reduce the risk of developing T2DM.

D) INCORRECT:

Smoking is the leading risk factor for the development of lung and pancreatic cancer and it increases the risk for various conditions. While there could theoretically be a link between smoking and T2DM (e.g., impairment of insulin sensitivity and an increase in blood glucose concentration in smokers), there is no definitive evidence of a causal association.

E) INCORRECT:

HLA-DR4 is strongly associated with numerous autoimmune diseases, including type I diabetes mellitus (T1DM). However, this patient has T2DM, which is caused by a combination of hereditary and environmental factors and is strongly associated with metabolic syndrome. T2DM is not an autoimmune condition and is not associated with HLA-DR4.
questions.hint: Polyuria (frequent urination), polydipsia (increased thirst), and an elevated hemoglobin A1c in this middle-aged man suggest type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

questions.text: A previously healthy 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 6 hours. Over the past 6 weeks, she has also had increased frequency of urination, and she has been drinking more water than usual. She has lost 6 kg (13 lb) over the same time period despite having a good appetite. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. She appears lethargic. Physical examination shows deep and labored breathing and dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is soft, and there is diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Urine dipstick is positive for ketones and glucose. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

DKA causes a metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap. In response to the acidosis, patients typically exhibit a deep and labored breathing pattern (Kussmaul breathing) to provide respiratory compensation, as seen with this patient. The higher depth and rate of breaths results in an increase in carbon dioxide exhalation and subsequently a decrease in arterial pCO2 (compensatory respiratory alkalosis).

B) INCORRECT:

DKA causes metabolic acidosis, which leads to decreased arterial blood pH (not increased). The insulin deficiency in DKA increases lipolysis, resulting in more free fatty acids. In the liver, free fatty acids are converted to ketones, two of which are acidic (acetoacetic acid and beta-hydroxybutyric acid).

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with DKA typically present with hypovolemia and severe dehydration rather than excess water retention. In DKA, hyperglycemia leads to osmotic diuresis which typically manifests as polyuria and polydipsia, as seen in this patient. The osmotic diuresis eventually leads to hypovolemia, which usually presents with dry mucous membranes, hypotension, and/or tachycardia.

D) INCORRECT:

In DKA, serum glucose concentration is increased due to insulin deficiency. However, serum glucose rarely exceeds 600 mg/dL because ketogenesis (due to insulin deficiency) usually begins at lower glucose concentrations and causes symptoms earlier. A hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS), on the other hand, does not involve ketogenesis (there are residual insulin levels that suppresses lipolysis and ketogenesis) and usually presents with serum glucose levels ≥ 600 mg/dL. The ketonuria and hyperventilation in this patient argue against HHS.

HHS typically occurs in patients with type 2 diabetes, as the condition involves a relative insulin deficiency rather than the absolute insulin deficiency seen in type 1 diabetes. However, DKA can also occur in the advanced stages of type 2 diabetes, when beta cell function has declined so much that insulin levels are negligible.

E) CORRECT:

DKA typically occurs in individuals with undiagnosed, untreated type 1 diabetes mellitus or treatment failure in known diabetics. Absolute insulin deficiency results in hyperglycemia and hyperosmolality. As a result, K+ shifts along with water from inside cells to the extracellular space and is lost in the urine. Moreover, the insulin that normally promotes cellular potassium uptake is absent in DKA, compounding the problem. A total body K+ deficit, therefore, develops in the body, although serum K+ may be normal or even paradoxically elevated.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, lethargy, and a 6-week history of polydipsia and weight loss. Together with Kussmaul breathing (deep and labored breathing), dehydration (dry mucous membranes), glucosuria, and ketonuria, these symptoms indicate diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which causes an anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician for a 2-month history of abdominal discomfort, fatigue, and increased urinary frequency, especially at night. He has also noticed that despite eating more often he has lost 14-lbs (6-kg). He has a congenital solitary kidney and a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis, for which he takes levothyroxine. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 10 years. BMI is 18 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serum studies show an osmolality of 305 mOsm/L and bicarbonate of 17 mEq/L. Urinalysis shows clear-colored urine with no organisms. Which of the following is most likely to be helpful in establishing the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ultrasonography of the thyroid gland can be used to help diagnose thyroid diseases and is routinely used in the evaluation of a palpable thyroid nodule. This patient's history of Hashimoto thyroiditis places him at increased risk for non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which may present with painless enlargement of the thyroid, fatigue, and weight loss. However, polyuria, polyphagia, and abdominal pain would not be expected. There is nothing in this patient' s history to suggest thyroid involvement in his current condition and an ultrasound is unlikely to be helpful.

B) CORRECT:

A single random serum glucose level of ≥ 200 mg/dL is sufficient for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus in a patient with other classic signs of the disease (e.g., polyuria, dehydration, weight loss). Alternatively, a fasting plasma glucose ≥ 126 mg/dL, oral glucose tolerance test ≥ 200 mg/dL, or hemoglobin A1C ≥ 6.5 % are also diagnostic of diabetes mellitus. This patient's young age, history of autoimmune disease, evidence of acidosis, and weight loss are suggestive of type 1 diabetes mellitus, which is caused by autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells.

C) INCORRECT:

A water deprivation test is helpful in the diagnosis of diabetes insipidus (DI). Patients with DI excrete large quantities of dilute urine (polyuria), which causes excessive thirst (polydipsia) in response to fluid loss. While this patient has polyuria, recent onset polyphagia and a metabolic acidosis would not be expected with this condition. Given this patient's age and other symptoms, a different diagnosis is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine levels are helpful in evaluating for impaired renal function, which typically manifests with anuria or oliguria. Polyuria in the setting of kidney injury is classically only seen following an episode of acute tubular necrosis, which this patient has no history of or risk factors for. Serum creatinine would not be helpful in the diagnosis of this patient's condition.

Renal function is not typically impaired in patients with a congenital solitary kidney.

E) INCORRECT:

A digital rectal examination is most commonly performed to screen patients for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or for the evaluation of prostate nodules. Patients with BPH typically present with increased urinary frequency and nocturia, as seen in this patient. However, this patient's polyphagia, polyuria, and hypothyroidism are not characteristic of BPH. Furthermore, neither BPH nor prostate nodules are likely in a patient of this age group.
questions.hint: This patient's history of autoimmune hypothyroidism, urinary frequency, weight loss, hypovolemia (serum osmolality > 295 mOsm/L), and mild acidosis (low serum bicarbonate) suggests a condition that more commonly occurs in childhood.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effect of a high-lipid diet on glucose metabolism in Wistar rats. The experimental rat group is fed a high-lipid diet while the control group is fed a low-lipid diet. Two months after initiation of the experiment, the rats in both groups are injected with insulin and serum glucose measurements are obtained. Compared to the control group, the high-lipid diet group has a significantly higher average serum glucose after receiving insulin. Which of the following intracellular changes is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this finding?

choices.text: Increased exposure of nuclear localization signal
Decreased production of protein kinase A

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is emerging evidence that p53 also plays a role in insulin resistance. However, insulin resistance is associated with an increased, not decreased, expression of p53.

B) CORRECT:

Activation of serine kinases is a key molecular mechanism in the development of insulin resistance. These kinases inactivate insulin receptor substrate (IRS) protein function through phosphorylation, reducing the action of phosphatidylinositide 3-kinases, thereby blocking downstream signaling of insulin receptors. In addition, serine kinases are able to phosphorylate serine residues on the insulin receptor itself, which also impairs insulin signal transduction. The interruption of insulin receptor signaling prevents the expression of GLUT4 receptors on cell surfaces, attenuating insulin's ability to decrease serum glucose levels. Free fatty acids are known to promote phosphorylation of IRS by serine kinases. Further factors known to increase the activity of intracellular serine kinases include catecholamines, glucocorticoids, and TNF-alpha.

In contrast, phosphorylation of tyrosine residues of the insulin receptor is part of the physiologic response to its activation.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased exposure of nuclear localization signals is part of nuclear receptor signaling pathways, such as those of steroid hormones. Insulin resistance can develop after long-term corticosteroid administration, but there is no indication that such steroid administration was performed in this test.

D) INCORRECT:

Caspase 8 is an initiator caspase that activates the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis. Decreased activation leads to an impaired apoptosis process, which can be seen in different malignancies (e.g., lymphoma). However, there is no evidence of malignancy in this experiment. Moreover, some studies on mice actually suggest that blood glucose control improves with decreased caspase 8 activity.

E) INCORRECT:

Protein kinase A is involved in glycogen synthesis and glycogenolysis. Low blood glucose levels increase protein kinase A levels, which increases serum glucose levels through stimulation of glycogenolysis and downregulation of glycogen synthesis. Decreased protein kinase A would result in decreased serum glucose levels, which is the opposite of what is described in this experiment.
questions.hint: The experimental group of rats on a high-lipid diet shows higher insulin resistance (i.e., decreased response of serum glucose after receiving insulin) when compared to the control group.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. Her father has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has gained 18-kg (40-lb) since the birth of her son 6 years ago. Her BMI is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination shows hyperpigmented plaques in the axillae and posterior neck. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin A1c of 6.4% and an elevated serum insulin level. Which of the following factors is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Increased serum levels of glucagon-like peptide-1
Increased levels of serum fatty acids

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased serum levels of glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) would increase insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells with the downstream effect of decreasing serum glucose levels. This is the mechanism of GLP-1 agonists such as exenatide. Insulin resistance, which is seen in this patient, is not associated with increased serum GLP-1.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of serum adiponectin are associated with improved glucose metabolism and are part of the mechanism of action of thiazolidinediones (e.g., pioglitazone). High levels of adiponectin would not be consistent with the signs of insulin resistance seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Positive MHC class I serotype, also known as HLA-B27, is associated with seronegative spondyloarthritis. The HLA-B27 serotype is not associated with the development of insulin resistance, which, given this patient's HbA1c elevation and acanthosis nigricans, is most likely.

D) CORRECT:

Elevated plasma free fatty acids (which is likely in this patient given her obesity) decrease insulin-mediated glucose uptake into tissues, resulting in insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, and increased risk of type 2 diabetes. When insulin resistance first develops, the pancreas is able to compensate by increasing insulin secretion. Over the course of the disease, insulin resistance progresses and the ability of the pancreas to overcome this resistance declines, resulting in decreased endogenous insulin production and subsequent hyperglycemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased levels of serum cortisol, as seen in primary adrenal insufficiency, would result in hypoglycemia rather than the hyperglycemia seen in this patient. Although patients with primary adrenal insufficiency may have hyperpigmentation, it is usually seen on the knuckles and buccal mucosa. The hyperpigmented plaques found on the axillae and posterior neck of this patient suggest acanthosis nigricans, which is associated with insulin resistance.

F) INCORRECT:

Positive HLA-DR4 serotype is associated with the development of type 1 diabetes mellitus, which can also manifest with hyperglycemia but is characterized by low insulin levels. This patient's age and obesity make T1DM unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's obesity, acanthosis nigricans (hyperpigmented plaques in the axillae and neck), elevated serum insulin, and elevated HbA1c are consistent with insulin resistance.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Physical examination shows hyperpigmented plaques on the posterior neck and in the axillae. His hemoglobin A1c concentration is 7.4% and fasting serum glucose concentration is 174 mg/dL. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated systolic blood pressure in hypertensive patients is a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome. Although patients with metabolic syndrome have an increased risk of developing diabetes, elevated systolic blood pressure alone is not a risk factor for type 2 diabetes.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals of Hispanic, African American, and Asian ethnicity have a greater risk for type 2 diabetes mellitus than white individuals. However, ethnicity is not the strongest predisposing factor for developing type 2 diabetes mellitus.

C) INCORRECT:

Childhood obesity increases the risk of type 2 diabetes but it is not the strongest predisposing factor because losing weight before puberty decreases this risk to the same level as those without childhood obesity.

D) INCORRECT:

An increased serum testosterone level is associated with a lower risk of type 2 diabetes in men and an increased risk in women. In this male patient, it would therefore not be a predisposing factor.

E) INCORRECT:

New studies have shown that smoking is an independent risk factor for developing type 2 diabetes but smoking is not the strongest predisposing factor for developing type 2 diabetes mellitus.

F) CORRECT:

A high waist circumference or waist-to-hip ratio is a sign of central obesity, which is a strong predisposing factor for the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Increased abdominal and visceral fat is associated with increased lipolytic activity and increased levels of serum free fatty acids. Increased levels of fatty acids induce insulin resistance by decreasing peripheral insulin-mediated glucose uptake.
questions.hint: This patient's laboratory studies (elevated HbA1c and fasting serum glucose levels) and skin findings (acanthosis nigricans) are consistent with a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 36-year-old Native American man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. The patient is married, has 4 children, and works as a software engineer.
