His father died in a car accident and his mother has coronary artery disease. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He appears healthy. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lbs); his BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/78 mm Hg on the right arm and 122/80 mm Hg on the left. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician regarding health maintenance at this visit?

choices.text: “At this time, there is nothing to worry about. Have a great day.”
“I would like to discuss screening options for high blood sugar with you today.”
“I would like to perform a fecal occult blood test on a stool sample.”
“Please fill out a short questionnaire about addictions before you leave today.”
“I suggest we do a 24-hour blood pressure measurement to evaluate you for hypertension.”

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation is normal as he has no complaints and a normal physical examination. However, Native American ancestry is associated with an increased risk for certain conditions, and patients within this population should receive the corresponding counseling and screening necessary. Furthermore, it is recommended that, prior to the end of the visit, the physician reminds the patient to schedule an appropriate follow-up appointment.

B) CORRECT:

The American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommends screening for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in individuals ≥ 35 years of age regardless of risk factors and in individuals < 35 years of age with either overweight or obesity and ≥ 1 additional risk factor for T2DM (e.g., first-degree family history, certain race or ethnicity, hypertension). The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for T2DM in asymptomatic individuals 35–70 years of age with overweight or obesity. As per both guidelines, screening this patient for T2DM is recommended.

Native American individuals have the highest prevalence of T2DM among racial and ethnic groups in the United States as a result of genetic and socioeconomic factors. While smoking, diet, and alcohol use are risk factors that are generally assessed in routine health maintenance examinations, social and genetic determinants of health are less commonly assessed, often because of poor access to care and provider negligence of minority groups. Poor screening consequently contributes to a higher burden of disease among various racial and ethnic minorities (e.g., African Americans, Hispanics, and Asian Americans).

C) INCORRECT:

While there is a correlation between higher rates of colorectal cancer and Native American ancestry, the causes of this are complex and not fully established. Inequities in access to colorectal screening may be the primary driver for this disparity. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Since this patient is only 36 years of age and does not have significant risk factors for colorectal cancer, screening is not currently indicated. In addition, it is inappropriate to tell this patient he has a high risk of malignancy without providing context, as it will likely increase patient anxiety.

D) INCORRECT:

While recreational drug and alcohol use are a matter of concern in Native American communities, it is inappropriate to assume an addiction from this patient's race alone. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends that all adults should be screened for excessive alcohol use, but since this patient reports not drinking alcohol or taking recreational drugs, additional screening is unwarranted. Moreover, physicians should approach potentially sensitive topics delicately and avoid being confrontational by opening with a term like “addiction” and requesting that the patient fill out a questionnaire before obtaining consent to be screened.

E) INCORRECT:

While there is a correlation between higher rates of hypertension and Native American ancestry, it has not yet been established whether this is a socially determined health risk (e.g., diet), a genetic predisposition, or the result of confounders (e.g., inadequate health care availability). At this time, there is no recommendation for intensified screening for hypertension in Native American persons. Furthermore, there is no reason to suspect hypertension in this patient who has normal blood pressure measurements.
questions.hint: Social determinants of health are an important factor to consider during routine health maintenance examinations.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office as a new patient. He recently emigrated from Tunisia. He had several episodes of diffuse abdominal pain and diarrhea during the move but does not report any symptoms at the moment. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and sickle cell trait. His only medication is metformin. He says he does not take his pills regularly because he feels fine most of the time and is not bothered by having to get up once or twice a night to urinate. He goes hiking every other month but does not do any other sports. His diet mostly consists of calorie-rich products like fried chicken wings and burgers. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks three to four beers per night. He does not use illicit drugs. He is 180 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (224 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 91/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 132/88 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and there is no tenderness. Cardiopulmonary examination discloses no abnormalities. Neurological examination shows symmetrical decreased sensation to pinprick and vibration in the distal lower extremities. Results of fasting laboratory studies are shown:


Hemoglobin
13.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
6500/mm3



Platelet count
250,000/mm3



Hemoglobin A1c
5.9%


Serum



 Na+

140 mEq/L


 K+

4.1 mEq/L


 Cl-

101 mEq/L


 Glucose

165 mg/dL


 ALT
40 U/L


 AST
34 U/L


 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding this patient's glycemic control?

choices.text: The glucose levels are a result of chronic alcohol consumption
The hemoglobin A1c levels are a result of vitamin B12 deficiency
The glucose levels indicate a laboratory mistake
The hemoglobin A1c levels are a result of sickle cell trait
The hemoglobin A1c levels indicate adequate glycemic control

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

According to some studies, moderate alcohol consumption in patients with diabetes mellitus lowers serum triglycerides and insulin and increases adiponectin. Alcohol consumption has also been found to reduce hemoglobin A1c in patients without diabetes. However, alcohol decreases, not increases, serum fasting glucose levels and can even cause severe hypoglycemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency can develop in patients with diarrhea as a result of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth, which can occur in diabetes mellitus. Features of neuropathy, such as decreased sensation to pinprick and vibration, are also common in this deficiency. However, hemoglobin A1c in vitamin B12 deficiency is likely to be increased, not decreased, because of a disproportionally increased number of older RBCs in circulation.

C) INCORRECT:

Although laboratory mistakes can occur in any facility, the rate is < 1%. This patient has early features of neuropathy (i.e., decreased sensation to pinprick and vibration) and a history of nonadherence to metformin, both of which correlate with his fasting serum glucose measurements. Therefore, a laboratory mistake is unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels are falsely normal as a result of his sickle cell trait (SCT). In addition to normal hemoglobin A, individuals with SCT have a genetic mutation that creates pathological hemoglobin S, which decreases the overall quantity of hemoglobin A (including HbA1c). Depending on the laboratory methodology, HbA1c measurements in individuals with SCT may therefore be unreliable. Sickle cells have a decreased lifespan, which also contributes to abnormal HbA1c levels.

Because conditions such as anemia, hemoglobinopathies (e.g., sickle cell disease), and pregnancy (second and third trimesters) can also result in an underestimation of HbA1c, fasting plasma glucose rather than HbA1c should be used for the diagnosis of diabetes in these patient groups.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has an established diagnosis of diabetes mellitus and his current fasting blood glucose readings indicate hyperglycemia. A single measurement of hyperglycemia is not enough evidence that glycemic control is insufficient overall. However, the combination of elevated fasting glucose, nonadherence to metformin, and early features of neuropathy do suggest poor glycemic control.
questions.hint: The lifespan of RBCs in healthy individuals is about 120 days.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?

choices.text: Insulin detemir therapy with prandial insulin lispro injections

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thiazolidinediones such as pioglitazone decrease bone mass and are contraindicated in patients with osteoporosis. Thiazolidinediones can also cause weight gain, peripheral edema, and increased LDL levels, all of which should be avoided in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Sulfonylureas such as glimepiride can cause weight gain and life-threatening hypoglycemia. They are contraindicated in patients taking beta blockers, which can mask warning signs of hypoglycemia and lower serum glucose levels even further. Sulfonylureas are also contraindicated in patients with obesity, severe cardiovascular comorbidities, and sulfonamide allergy.

C) INCORRECT:

Basal-bolus regimens combine a long-acting insulin (e.g., insulin detemir) and a rapid-acting insulin (e.g., insulin lispro). Because these regimens require frequent dosing and monitoring that may increase the risk of medication errors and hypoglycemia, they are reserved for cases in which a simpler treatment approach has failed to achieve the desired HbA1c.

D) CORRECT:

A regimen with a long-acting basal insulin such as insulin glargine is recommended in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) who have persistently elevated HbA1c levels despite combination therapy with multiple noninsulin antidiabetics. Before starting insulin, a GLP-1 agonist (e.g., semaglutide) should be included in the treatment regimen in most patients. Combination therapy of insulin glargine with a GLP-1 agonist reduces the risk of hypoglycemia and promotes weight management. If glycemic targets (in most patients an HbA1c < 7%) are still not met, a mixed insulin regimen may be considered.

Other indications for insulin therapy in T2DM include end-stage renal failure, pregestational and gestational diabetes, surgery, and severe illness. Insulin can also be considered in newly diagnosed patients with initial glucose ≥ 300 mg/dL or HbA1c > 10%, symptoms of hyperglycemia, or signs of a continued catabolic state (e.g., weight loss).
questions.hint: A DPP-4 inhibitor (linagliptin) is discontinued when initiating a GLP-1 agonist (semaglutide) because of overlapping mechanisms of action and no added benefit from combining the two medications. This patient is taking a biguanide (metformin), a GLP-1 agonist, and an SGLT-2 inhibitor (empagliflozin), and still has an HbA1c > 7%.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up. She has a past history of cigarette smoking and no family history of premature coronary heart disease. She has no symptoms of angina, carotid disease, or peripheral vascular disease. Her current medications are hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily, lisinopril 10 mg daily, metformin 500 mg twice daily, and atorvastatin 20 mg daily.
She has a blood pressure of 145/94 mm Hg (similar to several recent readings at home) and a heart rate of 77 beats per minute. Heart and lung auscultation is normal. There is evidence of neuropathy on monofilament testing of the lower extremities.
Fasting lipid testing reveals a total cholesterol level of 200 mg/dL, an LDL-cholesterol level of 84 mg/dL, and an HDL-cholesterol level of 71 mg/dL. The patient’s baseline LDL-cholesterol 3 months ago, before starting atorvastatin, was 130 mg/dL.
What change(s), if any, should be made to this patient’s medication regimen?

choices.text: Increase the dose of lisinopril; switch atorvastatin to rosuvastatin
No change to lisinopril or atorvastatin
No change to lisinopril; increase the dose of atorvastatin
Increase the doses of both lisinopril and atorvastatin
Switch lisinopril to enalapril; no change to the dose of atorvastatin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Switching from atorvastatin to rosuvastatin is not indicated, as the patient is tolerating atorvastatin and has room to increase the dose to higher intensity.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s BP is well above target despite the use of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Therefore, an increase in her lisinopril dose is indicated.

This patient will also require an increase in her statin dose.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient’s BP is well above target despite the use of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Therefore, an increase in her lisinopril dose is indicated.

D) CORRECT:

According to current hypertension guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA), patients with type 2 diabetes who develop hypertension should start treatment at blood pressures (BPs) ≥130/80 and be treated to a target BP of <130/80 mm Hg. The American Diabetes Association recommends individualizing the BP target through a shared decision-making process, but using this same target of <130/80 mm Hg in most patients, assuming it can be safely attained. This patient’s BP is well above target despite the use of lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Therefore, an increase in her lisinopril dose is indicated. She will most likely need a third antihypertensive medication to reach her target BP and should therefore follow up within one month of starting a higher dose of lisinopril, to reassess her BP response.

This patient will also require an increase in her statin dose. According to the current ACC/AHA cholesterol treatment guideline, all adults aged 40 to 75 who have type 2 diabetes should receive, at a minimum, a moderate-intensity statin (e.g., atorvastatin 10–20 mg daily, rosuvastatin 5–10 mg daily, pravastatin 40–80 mg daily, lovastatin 40–80 mg, or simvastatin 20–40 mg daily), regardless of their estimated atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk. If a patient has multiple ASCVD risk factors (as in this case: age >60 years, hypertension, past smoking history, and diabetes-specific risk enhancers such as neuropathy), it is reasonable to attempt to lower the LDL-cholesterol level by ≥50% and to target an LDL-cholesterol level of <70 mg/dL by either intensifying therapy to a high-dose statin (e.g., atorvastatin 40–80 mg daily, rosuvastatin 20–40 mg daily) or adding other agents such as ezetimibe or a proprotein convertase subtilisin-kexin type 9 (PCSK9) serine protease inhibitor. This patient’s LDL-cholesterol level has decreased by only 35% (from 130 mg/dL to 84 mg/dL) since she started a moderate-dose statin, and it remains above 70 mg/dL. The atorvastatin dose should therefore be increased.

Key learning point: In patients with type 2 diabetes, the target blood pressure is <130/80 mm Hg, and the goal for lipid-lowering therapy is to reduce the LDL-cholesterol level by ≥50% from baseline to a target level of <70 mg/dL.

E) INCORRECT:

Switching from lisinopril to enalapril is not indicated, as the patient is tolerating lisinopril and has room to increase the dose.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up. In the 6 months since her last visit, she has lost 4.5 kg of body weight through diet and exercise. She currently takes metformin 1000 mg twice daily, lisinopril 20 mg daily, and a multivitamin.
Her blood pressure is 123/74 mm Hg, and her BMI is 22. The rest of her physical examination is unremarkable.
A fasting lipid panel reveals the following results:



Patient value


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
189


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
95


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
43


Triglycerides (mg/dL)
255


Liver function test results are within normal limits, and the patient’s glycated hemoglobin level is 6.3% (reference range, 4.3–5.6). She has no other identifiable cardiovascular risk factors.
Which one of the following treatments is recommended to minimize this patient’s long-term cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Icosapent ethyl effectively reduces triglyceride concentrations, especially in individuals with severe hypertriglyceridemia (>500 mg/dL). Studies have shown cardiovascular benefit when icosapent ethyl is added to a statin in patients with hypertriglyceridemia who are at high cardiovascular risk (due to established ASCVD or to type 2 diabetes with at least one additional ASCVD risk factor). Current guidelines therefore suggest considering icosapent ethyl as an addition to a statin in this patient population. However, starting a statin should take precedence.

B) INCORRECT:

Pravastatin 10 mg daily is considered a low-intensity statin and so would not be an appropriate choice in this patient with type 2 diabetes.

C) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

E) CORRECT:

Current cholesterol treatment guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) outline four “statin benefit” groups for whom atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk reduction clearly outweighs the risk for adverse events. One of those groups is patients aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of their estimated risk for ASCVD. These patients should receive at least a moderate-intensity statin (atorvastatin 10–20 mg daily, rosuvastatin 5–10 mg daily, simvastatin 20–40 mg daily, pravastatin 40–80 mg daily, or lovastatin 40–80 mg daily). If they have multiple ASCVD risk factors, they should receive a high-intensity statin, such as rosuvastatin 20–40 mg daily or atorvastatin 40–80 mg daily, with the goal of reducing LDL-cholesterol levels by ≥50% to a target LDL-cholesterol level of <70 mg/dL. This patient should receive a moderate-intensity statin.

Key learning point: Regardless of estimated risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, primary prevention in patients aged 40 to 75 years with type 2 diabetes should include at least moderate-intensity statin therapy.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents for follow-up of type 2 diabetes for which he takes metformin 1000 mg twice daily and dulaglutide 4.5 mg once weekly. He also takes atorvastatin 40 mg daily. He has no other medical conditions, takes no other medications, and has no family history of diabetes or any other condition. He drinks approximately 3 beers per week and does not smoke.
On examination, his blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 80 beats per minute. His height is 173 cm, and his weight is 92 kg; his BMI is 30.7. Other than the presence of central adiposity, his examination is unremarkable.
Fasting laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Glycated hemoglobin (%)
12.2
4.3–5.6


Total cholesterol (mg/dL)
206
125–200


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
93
<130



HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
31
≥40



Triglycerides (mg/dL)
409
<150


The ratio of urine albumin to creatinine is <10 mg/g (reference range, <30).
The estimated 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 7.7%.
In addition to dietary and lifestyle changes, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient’s care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In terms of lipid management, this patient should be continued on atorvastatin 40 mg daily, as current guidelines recommend a moderate-intensity statin for all adults with diabetes mellitus aged 40 to 75 who are at average cardiovascular risk. Fenofibrate is not indicated in this case, as this agent has not been shown to reduce the risk for coronary events among patients with diabetes.

B) INCORRECT:

An angiotensin-receptor blocker is not indicated in a patient with normal blood pressure and no evidence of albuminuria.

C) INCORRECT:

Clopidogrel has been shown to reduce cardiovascular events in patients with diabetes mellitus but is recommended only as adjunctive therapy or as an alternative therapy for aspirin-intolerant patients.

Aspirin may be considered as a primary prevention strategy in those with diabetes mellitus who are at increased cardiovascular risk (generally, a 10-year cardiovascular risk >10%). However, aspirin therapy should only be started after a discussion with the patient about the benefits of such therapy versus the increased risk of bleeding, which may, in large part, negate the benefits. This patient does not have an indication for aspirin, as his 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is 7.7%.

D) INCORRECT:

In terms of lipid management, this patient should be continued on atorvastatin 40 mg daily, as current guidelines recommend a moderate-intensity statin for all adults with diabetes mellitus aged 40 to 75 who are at average cardiovascular risk. Niacin is not indicated in this case, as this agent has not been shown to reduce the risk for coronary events among patients with diabetes.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with obesity and those who have type 2 diabetes with poor glycemic control often have a characteristic lipid profile of elevated triglycerides with a low HDL-cholesterol level. Lowering the glucose level in these patients should meaningfully lower the serum triglyceride level and improve the lipid profile. However, in this case, the patient’s glycated hemoglobin level is substantially elevated despite maximal doses of metformin and dulaglutide, making it necessary to add a third antidiabetic agent to his regimen.

In many cases, regimens containing three antidiabetic agents can be designed to not include insulin. Such regimens commonly involve metformin combined with a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor and a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist (or, more recently, tirzepatide, which is a dual agonist of the receptors for both GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide). Alternative agents include sulfonylureas, dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors, or a thiazolidinedione. However, in this case, insulin is a more appropriate choice because it is likely to be more effective at lowering the patient’s glycated hemoglobin to an acceptable level, given the current magnitude of elevation despite maximal doses of metformin and dulaglutide.

Key learning point: The lipid profile known as atherogenic dyslipidemia, seen in patients with obesity or insulin resistance, is characterized by a low HDL-cholesterol level and an elevated triglyceride level.

questions.text:

In addition to recommending lifestyle modification for her obesity, which one of the following medications should this patient initiate?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin has not been shown to reduce cardiovascular events in people with type 2 diabetes.

B) INCORRECT:

Fenofibrate has failed to show a reduction in the risk for coronary events among patients with type 2 diabetes.

If the patient’s triglyceride level exceeded 1000 mg/dL, she would be at risk for pancreatitis, which would warrant more-urgent treatment, most often with a fibrate.

C) INCORRECT:

At least moderate-intensity statin therapy is recommended for all patients with diabetes mellitus who are age 40 to 75 years; high-intensity therapy is a reasonable choice for those who have additional risk enhancers for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD), such as increasing age, increasing duration of diabetes, and family history of premature ASCVD. This patient does not meet criteria for statin therapy.

D) CORRECT:

The first step to managing hypertriglyceridemia is to identify potential secondary causes. If such a cause is identified, it is appropriate to reevaluate the lipid profile after this secondary cause is addressed. Hypertriglyceridemia can be caused by hyperglycemia and would be expected to improve substantially once glycemic control is achieved.

In a patient with type 2 diabetes (e.g., with a glycated hemoglobin level ≥6.5%) and hyperglycemia, metformin is appropriate for initial treatment of hypertriglyceridemia. Statin therapy can be added if the patient’s triglyceride level remains elevated after achievement of glycemic control.

Key learning point: The most effective approach to managing hypertriglyceridemia in a patient with uncontrolled and untreated type 2 diabetes is to control the hyperglycemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism is another cause of secondary hypertriglyceridemia; however, this patient’s thyroid-stimulating hormone level is normal. In general, treatment with levothyroxine is initiated on the basis of symptoms of hypothyroidism or if the thyroid-stimulating hormone level is greater than 10 μU/mL. Inadequately treated hypothyroidism is most typically associated with an elevated LDL-cholesterol level but can also cause mixed hyperlipidemia or hypertriglyceridemia alone.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents for management of diabetes mellitus that was diagnosed 6 months ago, when his fasting glucose level was 129 mg/dL (reference range for diabetes, >125) and his glycated hemoglobin value was 6.8% (reference range, 4.3–5.6). His glucose level was effectively controlled with metformin 1000 mg twice daily until approximately one month ago.
During the past month, the patient’s fasting blood glucose levels have risen again, with preprandial readings typically 140 to 180 mg/dL, postprandial readings typically 200 to 300 mg/dL, and glycated hemoglobin 8.7%. He is otherwise healthy and does not take medications other than the metformin. The patient has no known family history of diabetes. His blood pressure is 118/74 mm Hg, and his BMI is 22.8.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
8.7
4.3–5.6


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
82
<130


HDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
52
≥40

95

What is the best next step in managing this patient’s diabetes?

choices.text: Test for mutations characteristic of maturity-onset diabetes of the young
Test for anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although pancreatic cancer has been associated with rising glucose levels, pancreatic imaging is not indicated in a patient who has no other features to suggest this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Measuring urinary free-cortisol levels would be useful to diagnose Cushing syndrome. This patient does not have clinical features that warrant pursuing this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Maturity-onset diabetes of the young is a monogenic form of diabetes with an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Patients with maturity-onset diabetes of the young are usually diagnosed in adolescence, have conditions that deteriorate slowly, and have a strong family history of diabetes.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient does not have features of glucagonoma, such as necrolytic migratory erythema, cheilitis, weight loss, diarrhea, venous thrombosis, or neuropsychiatric symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes classically manifests with subacute onset of hyperglycemic symptoms, such as polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss, and diabetic ketoacidosis, especially in childhood, adolescence, and young adulthood. However, type 1 diabetes can manifest at any age, and when it does so later in life, it often has a more progressive onset with incidental, asymptomatic hyperglycemia on blood tests. This is sometimes called latent autoimmune diabetes of adulthood (LADA). Type 1 diabetes should be considered in adult patients with diabetes mellitus who are lean, who do not have the common metabolic abnormalities usually observed with type 2 diabetes (such as hypertension and dyslipidemia), who do not have a strong family history of type 2 diabetes, or in whom oral medications for type 2 diabetes quickly fail. Autoantibodies such as anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies, islet-cell autoantibodies, and insulin autoantibodies may be used to differentiate type 1 diabetes from type 2 diabetes.

Key learning point: The rapid failure of oral diabetic medications in a patient with newly diagnosed diabetes and no signs of metabolic syndrome should prompt evaluation for type 1 diabetes.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man presents for management of type 2 diabetes that was diagnosed 6 months ago. His most recent glycated hemoglobin value is 7.8% (reference range, 4.3–5.6). He also has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and obstructive sleep apnea. He has a history of overweight since childhood and has tried several weight-loss diets without success.
He weighs 125 kg, and his BMI is 39.2. He currently takes metformin, canagliflozin, aspirin, simvastatin, and lisinopril.
What is the most effective approach for long-term control of type 2 diabetes in this patient?

choices.text: Therapy with continuous positive airway pressure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is superior to gastric banding for remission of type 2 diabetes and additional metabolic benefits.

B) INCORRECT:

Conservative approaches for diabetes control, including dietary modifications and physical activity, can be beneficial, but long-term adherence is challenging; most studies of these approaches have reported high rates of weight regain.

C) INCORRECT:

Achieving good glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes who also have overweight or obesity is a common clinical challenge, with fewer than 50% of patients achieving and maintaining therapeutic goals. During the past two decades, several new pharmacologic agents have been introduced to help manage type 2 diabetes in this population. The most favored are those acting on the incretin system, primarily liraglutide, semaglutide, and dulaglutide (all glucagon-like peptide-1 [GLP-1] receptor agonists) and tirzepatide, which is a dual agonist of the GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide receptors. Although these medications can induce weight loss that, in some cases, may be close in magnitude to that achieved with bariatric surgery, discontinuation of these agents results in weight gain. Furthermore, the effect of these medications on long-term diabetes remission rates is still unknown. Thus, although choosing pharmacologic therapy with one of these agents would be a reasonable therapeutic choice, it is not the most effective approach for long-term control of type 2 diabetes.

D) CORRECT:

Achieving good glycemic control in patients with type 2 diabetes who also have overweight or obesity is a common clinical challenge, with fewer than 50% of patients achieving and maintaining therapeutic goals. During the past two decades, several new pharmacologic agents have been introduced to help manage type 2 diabetes in this population. The most favored are those acting on the incretin system, primarily liraglutide, semaglutide, and dulaglutide (all glucagon-like peptide-1 [GLP-1] receptor agonists) and tirzepatide, which is a dual agonist of the GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide receptors. Although these medications can induce weight loss that, in some cases, may be close in magnitude to that achieved with bariatric surgery, discontinuation of these agents results in weight gain. Furthermore, the effect of these medications on long-term diabetes remission rates is still unknown. Thus, although choosing pharmacologic therapy with one of these agents would be a reasonable therapeutic choice, it is not the most effective approach for long-term control of type 2 diabetes.

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass has been shown to provide long-lasting remission or control of type 2 diabetes. It is superior to both gastric banding and sleeve gastrectomy for remission of type 2 diabetes and additional metabolic benefits. Bariatric surgery may be indicated in patients without type 2 diabetes who have a BMI >40 (stage 3 obesity) and in patients with type 2 diabetes who have a BMI >35 (stage 2 obesity).

Key learning point: The most effective treatment to induce long-term remission of type 2 diabetes in patients with obesity is bariatric surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

Treatment of sleep apnea has not been found to improve glycemic control in type 2 diabetes.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents for routine follow-up. Her glycated hemoglobin level is found to be 8.4% (reference range, 4.3–5.6).
She reports no foot ulcers and does not have symptoms of numbness or tingling in the extremities. She has never smoked tobacco. Her current medications are insulin glargine, metformin, simvastatin, lisinopril, and aspirin.
On examination, there are no foot ulcers; her second toe overlaps slightly with the big toe on the left foot. She has mild darkening of the skin on the lower legs. Pedal pulses are faint but palpable.
To better evaluate this patient’s peripheral neuropathy, monofilament testing should be performed on which sites?

choices.text: The tip of the distal hallux and the first, second, and fifth metatarsal heads
The skin overlying the calcaneus and the tips of the first, third, and fifth toes
The plantar surface of the distal hallux and the first, third, and fifth metatarsal heads
The plantar surface of the distal hallux and the first, second, and fourth toes
The plantar surface of the heel and the first, third, and fourth toes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A monofilament test is done by placing, with pressure, a 10-g monofilament perpendicular to the skin until the monofilament buckles. The test is performed to screen for sensory loss in the lower extremities. The monofilament should be applied to the plantar surface of the distal hallux and first, third, and fifth metatarsal heads of each foot. A positive test is defined as the loss of sensation in at least one of the four sites. Studies have shown these sites to be the most sensitive and specific for diabetic sensory neuropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

A monofilament test is done by placing, with pressure, a 10-g monofilament perpendicular to the skin until the monofilament buckles. The test is performed to screen for sensory loss in the lower extremities. The monofilament should be applied to the plantar surface of the distal hallux and first, third, and fifth metatarsal heads of each foot. A positive test is defined as the loss of sensation in at least one of the four sites. Studies have shown these sites to be the most sensitive and specific for diabetic sensory neuropathy.

C) CORRECT:

An annual comprehensive foot examination is recommended for patients with diabetes mellitus, because they are at risk for developing peripheral neuropathy, vascular insufficiency, foot ulceration, infection, and lower-extremity amputation.

A monofilament test is done by placing, with pressure, a 10-g monofilament perpendicular to the skin until the monofilament buckles. The test is performed to screen for sensory loss in the lower extremities. The monofilament should be applied to the plantar surface of the distal hallux and first, third, and fifth metatarsal heads of each foot. A positive test is defined as the loss of sensation in at least one of the four sites. Studies have shown these sites to be the most sensitive and specific for diabetic sensory neuropathy.

Although peripheral-nerve conduction studies are the gold standard for detecting neuropathy, such studies are rarely indicated. Many prospective studies have confirmed that loss of the sensation of pressure from a 10-g monofilament is highly predictive of subsequent ulceration.

If a monofilament test is positive, education regarding proper foot care and improved glycemic control should be reinforced.

A comprehensive foot examination comprises an inspection of the foot for change in color, cracking, ulceration, or callus. Musculoskeletal deformities such as claw toes, rocker-bottom feet, or Charcot joint (neuropathic arthropathy) should also be reported. A sensory examination of the feet should be performed, including checking for vibratory and pinprick sensation and ankle reflexes.

Key learning point: The most appropriate locations on the feet for monofilament testing in a patient with type 2 diabetes are the plantar surface of the distal hallux and the first, third, and fifth metatarsal heads.

D) INCORRECT:

A monofilament test is done by placing, with pressure, a 10-g monofilament perpendicular to the skin until the monofilament buckles. The test is performed to screen for sensory loss in the lower extremities. The monofilament should be applied to the plantar surface of the distal hallux and first, third, and fifth metatarsal heads of each foot. A positive test is defined as the loss of sensation in at least one of the four sites. Studies have shown these sites to be the most sensitive and specific for diabetic sensory neuropathy.

E) INCORRECT:

A monofilament test is done by placing, with pressure, a 10-g monofilament perpendicular to the skin until the monofilament buckles. The test is performed to screen for sensory loss in the lower extremities. The monofilament should be applied to the plantar surface of the distal hallux and first, third, and fifth metatarsal heads of each foot. A positive test is defined as the loss of sensation in at least one of the four sites. Studies have shown these sites to be the most sensitive and specific for diabetic sensory neuropathy.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old asymptomatic man is evaluated for hyperkalemia. He has a long-standing history of type 1 diabetes that is managed with an insulin pump; he also has a history of hypertension and mild retinopathy. His medications include daily lisinopril, aspirin, and simvastatin.
Physical examination is unrevealing, other than a blood pressure of 148/94 mm Hg.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.7

6.6
3.5–5.0

104

136–145

22

393
70–100

7.6
4.3–5.6

<0.6

<0.6–4.3

1.5

Microscopic analysis of the urine is unremarkable.
Which one of the following diagnoses is the most likely cause of this patient’s hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral renal-artery stenosis would cause activation rather than suppression of the renin-aldosterone axis and typically causes hypokalemia.

B) INCORRECT:

In the absence of advanced kidney failure, diabetic nephropathy should not result in hyperkalemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Diabetic ketoacidosis can cause hyperkalemia from insulin deficiency but more commonly causes hypokalemia from urinary losses of potassium accompanying the osmotic diuresis that occurs with glycosuria.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has hyperkalemia that appears out of proportion to his mild kidney impairment, suggesting additional contributors to the hyperkalemia. In this setting, one would theoretically expect an elevated aldosterone level due to the direct effect of potassium on aldosterone secretion — and an elevated renin level due to the effect of the angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor in blocking angiotensin II production and thereby reducing the negative feedback on the renal juxtaglomerular apparatus. However, the laboratory data in this patient show a suppressed renin level and a low aldosterone level. This is consistent with hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism. A low or low-normal serum bicarbonate level would help support this diagnosis.

Hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism is a common finding in patients with diabetes mellitus and mild kidney impairment and is characterized by hyperkalemia that is out of proportion to the degree of kidney impairment. The exact mechanism of hyperkalemia in patients with hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism is unclear but appears to involve relatively limited renin production or an inability to activate the renin-aldosterone axis following salt restriction. This abnormality can lead to life-threatening hyperkalemia, especially in patients treated with angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin-receptor blockers, which limit the production and effect of aldosterone, respectively. These agents must be discontinued when severe hyperkalemia is present.

Although patients with hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism have low levels of aldosterone, mineralocorticoid therapy is rarely given because many patients with this disorder also have hypertension and edema. Instead, a potassium-wasting diuretic is the mainstay of therapy.

Key learning point: The most common cause of hyperkalemia in patients with type 1 diabetes is hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism, often exacerbated by renal insufficiency and blockade of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute tubular necrosis is associated with severe kidney failure and granular casts in the urine.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents for ongoing management of type 2 diabetes. His diabetes was poorly controlled for several years, but he recently attained a glycated hemoglobin level of 6.8% after starting basal insulin, and self-monitoring of blood glucose levels has shown >90% of fingerstick glucose values within target. He has nonproliferative retinopathy but is asymptomatic. A complete review of systems is negative. In addition to insulin, he takes aspirin 81 mg daily and atorvastatin 80 mg daily.
His blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg, and his BMI is 32. Neurologic examination identifies diminished Achilles tendon reflexes and diminished sensation in response to light touch and vibration in both feet.
Laboratory evaluation reveals an LDL-cholesterol level of 68 mg/dL (reference range, <130 mg/dL) and 18 mg of albumin per gram of creatinine in a spot urine (<30).
Which one of the following additional evaluations is recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient is considered to be at high risk for cardiovascular disease, given his established type 2 diabetes and several diabetes-specific risk enhancers, including retinopathy and neuropathy. He is already receiving high-dose statin therapy as recommended in the most recent cholesterol treatment guidelines, and his LDL cholesterol is well controlled. Thus, the measurement of C-reactive protein would not alter his cardiovascular risk stratification or cholesterol management.

B) INCORRECT:

Fructosamine is a glycated protein that is occasionally used to assess glycemic control in patients in whom the glycated hemoglobin level is thought to be inaccurate, such as in anemia, hemoglobinopathies, or discrepant fingerstick glucose values. In this patient, both the glycated hemoglobin and the fingerstick glucose values are at goal; the glycated hemoglobin value therefore seems to be an accurate assessment of long-term glycemic control, and measuring a fructosamine level is not required.

C) INCORRECT:

Electromyography is not required to diagnose neuropathy in patients with type 2 diabetes.

D) INCORRECT:

Routine cardiac stress testing is not recommended for asymptomatic patients with type 2 diabetes.

E) CORRECT:

Diabetic nephropathy is typically characterized by a gradual increase in urinary albumin excretion. However, the absence of albuminuria does not exclude diabetic nephropathy. Serum creatinine, estimated glomerular filtration rate, and urinary albumin excretion should be measured annually in patients with type 2 diabetes.

Key learning point: Screening for diabetic nephropathy is done by measuring both urine albumin and serum creatinine.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man with obesity presents with polyuria and polydipsia (which he has had for several weeks), a glucose level of 341 mg/dL (reference range, 70–100), and a positive test for serum ketones. His mother was diagnosed with diabetes at age 32.
He is hospitalized for the management of diabetic ketoacidosis. During hospitalization, he is treated with fluids and insulin, and on the second hospital day, the symptoms improve. His glucose level is between 120 and 150 mg/dL; the ketosis has resolved. The glycated hemoglobin value is 12% (4.3–5.6). Tests for antibodies against glutamic acid decarboxylase, insulin, and islet cells are negative. He is discharged with prescriptions for insulin glargine and insulin aspart.
One month later, he returns for follow-up. He is currently taking insulin glargine 35 U in the morning, as well as insulin aspart 4 U with each meal. Glucose levels on fingerstick testing are all between 90 and 110 mg/dL, except for two measurements: 49 mg/dL before breakfast, and 55 mg/dL one hour after lunch.
In addition to following this patient closely and providing counseling about lifestyle changes and weight loss, which one of the following management steps is most appropriate?

choices.text: Decrease the insulin glargine dose and increase the insulin aspart dose
Increase the insulin glargine dose and decrease the insulin aspart dose
Begin to taper both types of insulin
Replace the insulin glargine with insulin degludec

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypoglycemia in a patient with diabetes suggests that the insulin regimen is not optimal, necessitating adjustment of either the basal or prandial insulin doses. However, neither the insulin glargine dose nor the insulin aspart dose before a meal should be increased in a patient who has hypoglycemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypoglycemia in a patient with diabetes suggests that the insulin regimen is not optimal, necessitating adjustment of either the basal or prandial insulin doses. However, neither the insulin glargine dose nor the insulin aspart dose before a meal should be increased in a patient who has hypoglycemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypoglycemia in a patient with diabetes suggests that the insulin regimen is not optimal, necessitating adjustment of either the basal or prandial insulin doses. However, neither the insulin glargine dose nor the insulin aspart dose before a meal should be increased in a patient who has hypoglycemia.

D) CORRECT:

Ketosis-prone type 2 diabetes is characterized by acute episodes of diabetic ketoacidosis; patients with this presentation do not have the autoantibodies against glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD), islet cells, and insulin that are often seen in patients with type 1 diabetes. Instead, they often have risk factors for type 2 diabetes, including a BMI in the obesity range.

In the first few weeks or months after this condition develops, patients often require a combination of basal and bolus insulin. After this initial period, glucose levels may improve substantially. Insulin can typically be discontinued and, if necessary, replaced with oral hypoglycemic drugs, such as metformin.

Key learning point: Patients with diabetes who present with diabetic ketoacidosis but are able to eventually stop insulin and make the transition to oral hypoglycemic agents have a form of diabetes that is called ketosis-prone diabetes.

E) INCORRECT:

Insulin degludec has a somewhat longer duration of action than insulin glargine. However, replacing insulin glargine with insulin degludec would not be expected to improve this patient's glucose profile.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with a history of obesity, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes presents for further management of persisting hyperglycemia. Her most recent glycated hemoglobin value was 7.9% (reference range, 4.3–5.6), and home glucometer readings reveal consistent postprandial hyperglycemia. She has not had any episodes of hypoglycemia. Her current medications are metformin 1000 mg twice daily and lisinopril 5 mg daily. She has been on this regimen for several years.
Her diabetes has been complicated by retinopathy and neuropathy, but not nephropathy. She reports early satiety, postprandial nausea, and regular vomiting containing undigested food that was ingested several hours earlier. She has been managing her symptoms by eating frequent, small meals. She reports paresthesias affecting both of her lower extremities.
Which one of the following medication changes is most appropriate to help this patient improve her glycemic control?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Several medications that appear to exacerbate gastroparesis are best avoided in patients with this problem. Gastric emptying is dependent, in part, on the neurohormonal inhibition of contractions in the small intestine, which are mediated by glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), cholecystokinin, and peptide YY. Increased endogenous and exogenous GLP-1 levels have been shown to slow gastric emptying. GLP-1 receptor agonists, such as semaglutide, should therefore be avoided in patients with gastroparesis.

B) INCORRECT:

Several medications that appear to exacerbate gastroparesis are best avoided in patients with this problem. Gastric emptying is dependent, in part, on the neurohormonal inhibition of contractions in the small intestine, which are mediated by glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), cholecystokinin, and peptide YY. Increased endogenous and exogenous GLP-1 levels have been shown to slow gastric emptying. The newer agent tirzepatide, a dual agonist of the receptors for both GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide, is contraindicated in this setting.

C) INCORRECT:

Glipizide, a sulfonylurea, would be another reasonable second-line agent if added to metformin therapy in this patient, but it is not recommended as a replacement for metformin; metformin is usually continued when treatment intensification is needed unless there are adverse effects or contraindications.

D) CORRECT:

The diagnosis of gastroparesis is suggested by the presence of early satiety, postprandial nausea, and vomiting of food ingested many hours earlier in a patient with advanced type 2 diabetes.

Dapagliflozin, a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor, reduces blood sugar by increasing glycosuria. It can be used safely in patients with delayed gastric emptying and is an appropriate second-line oral agent to add to metformin in patients with type 2 diabetes and gastroparesis.

Glipizide, a sulfonylurea, would be another reasonable second-line agent if added to metformin therapy in this patient, but it is not recommended as a replacement for metformin; metformin is usually continued when treatment intensification is needed unless there are adverse effects or contraindications.

Several medications that appear to exacerbate gastroparesis are best avoided in patients with this problem. Gastric emptying is dependent, in part, on the neurohormonal inhibition of contractions in the small intestine, which are mediated by glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1), cholecystokinin, and peptide YY. Increased endogenous and exogenous GLP-1 levels have been shown to slow gastric emptying. GLP-1 receptor agonists, such as semaglutide and liraglutide, should therefore be avoided in patients with gastroparesis. The newer agent tirzepatide, a dual agonist of the receptors for both GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide, is also contraindicated in this setting.

Pramlintide is an amylin analogue that works to decrease postprandial glucose by suppressing glucagon secretion, slowing gastric emptying, and promoting satiety. Because of its effect on gastric emptying, it is also contraindicated in gastroparesis.

Key learning point: The three types of antidiabetic medications that should be avoided in a patient with a history of gastroparesis are glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists, dual agonists of the GLP-1 and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide receptors, and amylin analogues.

E) INCORRECT:

Pramlintide is an amylin analogue that works to decrease postprandial glucose by suppressing glucagon secretion, slowing gastric emptying, and promoting satiety. Because of its effect on gastric emptying, it is contraindicated in gastroparesis.

He reports no tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use. His mother has hypothyroidism; he has no other clinically significant family history.
He has a BMI of 28, mildly labored breathing, a blood pressure of 140/80 mm Hg, and a heart rate of 110 beats per minute. Acanthosis nigricans is found in his axillae, bilaterally. He has no acromegalic or cushingoid features.

Urinalysis is positive for ketones but otherwise normal.
While awaiting admission, the patient is given insulin and intravenous saline to treat his high blood glucose level, and his hydrochlorothiazide is temporarily held.
Once this patient's diabetic ketoacidosis has resolved, which one of his home medications should you consider discontinuing in consultation with his outpatient providers?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Liothyronine, the active form of thyroid hormone, is sometimes prescribed by psychiatrists as augmentation therapy for patients with major depression; it is not associated with diabetes.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide (HCT) has not been associated with diabetic ketoacidosis. HCT has been associated with the onset of type 2 diabetes but, given this patient's hypertension, should not be discontinued once the diabetic ketoacidosis has been treated. HCT should be temporarily held in this case, because patients in ketoacidosis are severely volume depleted, and continuing this drug during ketoacidosis would only worsen the depletion. Although HCT can cause hyponatremia, the patient's sodium level should normalize as the hyperglycemia is corrected.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s weight gain, dyslipidemia, and acanthosis nigricans, in combination with the absence of glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies, is suggestive of insulin resistance rather than type 1 diabetes.

Atypical antipsychotic agents, including olanzapine, are associated with clinically significant weight gain and a risk of type 2 diabetes; they may be associated with diabetic ketoacidosis, as in this patient, in which case they should be discontinued. Discontinuation and replacement of a psychotropic should be coordinated with the patient’s psychiatrist.

Key learning point: The metabolic adverse effects of atypical antipsychotic agents such as olanzapine can include weight gain, increased risk for diabetes, and diabetic ketoacidosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Labetalol has not been associated with diabetic ketoacidosis. Labetalol been associated with the onset of type 2 diabetes but, given this patient's hypertension, should not be discontinued once the diabetic ketoacidosis has been treated.

E) INCORRECT:

Venlafaxine, a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor, is not known to increase the risk for diabetes.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man with a 6-year history of treated type 2 diabetes and hypertension presents with pain at the tips of his toes on both feet. He was found to have mild, nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy.
His fasting glucose levels range between 150 and 200 mg/dL (reference range, 70–100). He has not had any hypoglycemic events. His current medications include metformin 1000 mg twice daily, insulin glargine 25 units at night, lisinopril 40 mg daily, a high-intensity statin, and aspirin 81 mg daily.
His blood pressure is 129/78 mm Hg. He has diminished vibratory sense and a lack of ankle reflexes. Pedal pulses are present.
Laboratory testing reveals a glycated hemoglobin value of 9.0% (reference range, 4.3–5.6), a urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio of 48 mg/g (<30), which is confirmed on repeat measurement, and a serum creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dL (0.8–1.3) with an estimated glomerular filtration rate of >59 mL/min/1.73 m2 (≥60).
What is the best next step in this patient’s care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metformin can be used safely when the estimated glomerular filtration rate is above 30 mL/min/1.73 m2. Sulfonylurea drugs, such as glipizide, should generally be avoided in patients receiving insulin, because this combination increases risk for hypoglycemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Sitagliptin use is unlikely to achieve glycemic goals in patients with long-standing type 2 diabetes that is inadequately controlled despite insulin therapy; this medication is most appropriate for patients early in their disease course.

C) INCORRECT:

Although using an angiotensin-receptor blocker together with lisinopril (an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor) might reduce proteinuria compared with using either drug as monotherapy, this combination has been associated with an increased incidence of adverse clinical events and should generally be avoided. If additional agents are needed on top of lisinopril and an SGLT-2 inhibitor, current guidelines would instead recommend adding a nonsteroidal mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist such as finerenone.

D) INCORRECT:

Current guidelines from the American Diabetes Association suggest that patients with type 2 diabetes and hypertension be treated to achieve a target systolic blood pressure of <130 mm Hg and a diastolic blood pressure of <80 mm Hg. Therefore, the addition of hydrochlorothiazide is not indicated in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

In patients with type 2 diabetes, early initiation of tight glycemic control has been shown to effectively prevent or delay the progression of microvascular complications of diabetes (i.e., nephropathy, retinopathy, and neuropathy). However, for patients with long-standing type 2 diabetes, the benefits of tight glycemic control are less clear. There is little evidence that tight control will reduce the incidence of macrovascular events, but there is moderate evidence that it may delay the progression of microvascular complications. There is also evidence that the antidiabetic medication chosen may have direct effects on microvascular complications, separate from the direct glycemic effects. Specifically, sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors, such as empagliflozin, have been shown to substantially reduce the risk of new or worsening nephropathy. SGLT-2 inhibitors are the best choice for this patient with moderately increased albuminuria confirmed on repeat measurement.

Although SGLT-2 inhibitors are the preferred antidiabetic agents for patients with diabetic kidney disease, a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist such as dulaglutide, semaglutide, or liraglutide would also be an acceptable choice in this case. These agents have been shown to have benefits in the prevention of diabetic kidney disease and cardiovascular risk reduction.

Increasing the dose of insulin glargine would also be a reasonable approach to achieving tight glycemic control in this patient, but would not confer benefits other than lowering glucose and would increase the likelihood of weight gain and hypoglycemia.

Key learning point: The best approach to prevent or delay the progression of diabetic retinopathy, neuropathy, and nephropathy is tight glycemic control.

questions.text:
A 92-year-old woman presents for management of type 2 diabetes. She has been controlling her diabetes with dietary measures since diagnosis, and her glycated hemoglobin value has routinely been below 7.0% until last week, when it was 7.4%. The patient has no other symptoms and feels well.
She has hypertension, which is well controlled with hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine. She also has osteoporosis, which is treated with denosumab as well as calcium and vitamin D supplements. She takes fluvastatin for hypercholesterolemia.
Her blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg, her weight is 58 kg, and her BMI is 21.7.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.4
0.6–1.1


Estimated glomerular filtration rate (mL/min/1.73 m2)
25
≥60


Urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
25
10–20


LDL cholesterol (mg/dL)
94
<130


Which one of the following next steps is best in managing this patient’s type 2 diabetes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although metformin is the preferred initial pharmacologic agent for type 2 diabetes, it is contraindicated in individuals who have an estimated glomerular filtration rate <30 mL/min/1.73 m2 (as in this case). Continuing metformin in a patient who is already taking it and develops an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 30 to 45 mL/min/1.73 m2 is reasonable, but starting metformin in an individual with this degree of renal impairment is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Because this patient’s diabetes is reasonably controlled, the potential risk for hypoglycemia associated with sulfonylurea (e.g., glipizide) treatment outweighs the limited benefit of better glycemic control.

C) INCORRECT:

A dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor such as sitagliptin or linagliptin would confer minimal risk of hypoglycemia and would be a reasonable choice if this patient's glycated hemoglobin value were higher, but additional agents are not needed at this time. If a DPP-4 did eventually become necessary for this patient, linagliptin may be preferred over sitagliptin because it is not renally cleared and therefore would not require dose adjustment in a patient with renal impairment.

D) CORRECT:

The risks and benefits of treatment for type 2 diabetes must be weighed carefully in older patients. Compared with younger patients, older individuals may be more susceptible to the adverse effects of treatment, such as hypoglycemia, and may derive less benefit from the control of hyperglycemia. A higher glycated hemoglobin value may be particularly appropriate for patients with long-standing type 2 diabetes who are at high risk for cardiovascular disease. As a result, the American Diabetes Association, the Endocrine Society, and the American Geriatrics Society all allow for less stringent glycemic targets in older adults.

Outpatient diabetes regimens for older patients should be designed specifically to minimize hypoglycemia. Before determining treatment goals and strategies, clinicians should consider the patient’s overall health and personal values. For patients in poor health (end-stage medical conditions, moderate to severe dementia, residence in a long-term nursing facility, or impairments in two or more activities of daily living), it would be reasonable to have a glycated hemoglobin target as high as 8.5% (according to the American Diabetes Association and the Endocrine Society) or 9.0% (according to the American Geriatrics Society). In this particular patient, who is described as independent but with several chronic illnesses (chronic kidney disease, hypertension, dyslipidemia, osteoporosis), a glycated hemoglobin target of <8% may be reasonable.

Continuing dietary control is the best next step in treating this older patient’s diabetes.

Key learning point: Less stringent glycemic control is reasonable in older patients, especially those with multiple comorbid conditions where the risks of tight glycemic control outweigh any expected benefit.

E) INCORRECT:

Because this patient’s diabetes is reasonably controlled, the potential risk for hypoglycemia associated with insulin treatment outweighs the limited benefit of better glycemic control.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with concern about hyperglycemia. A week ago, she measured her own random blood glucose level using a glucometer; it was 186 mg/dL in the mid-afternoon (reference range, <140). She is asymptomatic and reports no excessive urination or thirst. Her medical history is notable for gestational diabetes 5 years ago, which was well controlled with dietary changes alone. Her mother has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes, with onset at age 49.
On physical examination, the patient’s height is 164 cm, her weight is 73.5 kg, and her BMI is 27.3. Her heart rate is 82 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. A velvety hyperpigmentation is noted on the posterior folds of her neck.
The next morning, the patient presents after 8 hours of fasting. Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Plasma glucose (mg/dL)
94
70–100



Glycated hemoglobin (%)
6.1
4.3–5.6



Plasma glucose 2 hours after an oral load of 75 g of glucose (mg/dL)
177
<140


What is the correct interpretation of this patient’s blood test results?

choices.text: At least one of the tests should be repeated on another day before making a diagnosis
The patient can be considered to have a normal glucose profile; no additional testing is needed
The glucose tests should be repeated after 12 hours of fasting
The patient can be diagnosed with impaired glucose tolerance; no additional testing is needed
Autoantibody testing is indicated before making a diagnosis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fasting glucose level of 100 to 125 mg/dL and a plasma glucose level of 140 to 199 mg/dL, two hours after oral glucose loading, are consistent with prediabetes. The range of glycated hemoglobin levels that is diagnostic of prediabetes is subject to debate, but the American Diabetes Association guidance is 5.7% to 6.4%.

B) INCORRECT:

A fasting glucose level of 100 to 125 mg/dL and a plasma glucose level of 140 to 199 mg/dL, two hours after oral glucose loading, are consistent with prediabetes. The range of glycated hemoglobin levels that is diagnostic of prediabetes is subject to debate, but the American Diabetes Association guidance is 5.7% to 6.4%.

C) INCORRECT:

A fasting glucose level of 100 to 125 mg/dL and a plasma glucose level of 140 to 199 mg/dL, two hours after oral glucose loading, are consistent with prediabetes. The range of glycated hemoglobin levels that is diagnostic of prediabetes is subject to debate, but the American Diabetes Association guidance is 5.7% to 6.4%.

D) CORRECT:

A fasting glucose level of 100 to 125 mg/dL and a plasma glucose level of 140 to 199 mg/dL two hours after oral glucose loading are consistent with prediabetes. The range of glycated hemoglobin levels diagnostic of prediabetes is subject to debate, but the American Diabetes Association guidance is 5.7% to 6.4%.

The diagnostic cut-off points for diabetes mellitus, based on American Diabetes Association criteria, are as follows:

• Eight-hour fasting plasma glucose ≥126 mg/dL;
• Glycated hemoglobin ≥6.5%;
• Plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL two hours after an oral glucose-tolerance test (glucose loading dose, 75 g); and
• Random plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL in a patient with classic symptoms of hyperglycemia or hyperglycemic crisis.

The diagnosis requires confirmation by the same test or any of the other tests. The first three measurements appear to identify different groups of patients with diabetes or prediabetes, yet all tests identify patients at risk for adverse sequelae.

Key learning point: Impaired glucose tolerance can be diagnosed if the glucose level 2 hours after a 75-g glucose load is between 140 and 199 mg/dL.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibody testing (for glutamic-acid decarboxylase or anti-islet cell antibodies) can be used to clarify the cause of hyperglycemia when a patient has features that could be consistent with a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman reports urinary frequency that has become increasingly problematic. She has some increase in thirst, but she has not had any nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain.
Her mother and 24-year-old brother have diabetes mellitus, but they are lean, have controlled their diabetes with insulin, and have no diabetes-associated complications.
The patient’s BMI is 23. Her physical examination is unremarkable; there is no acanthosis nigricans, vitiligo, skin tags, or features of Cushing syndrome.
Her fasting laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
138
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.2
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
104
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
24
21–30


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
14
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.7
0.6–1.1


Glucose (mg/dL)
140
70–100


Glycated hemoglobin (%)
8.3
4.3–5.6



C-peptide (ng/mL)
1.0
0.5–2.0


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ketosis-prone diabetes is unlikely given that the patient has no signs of ketosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes is unlikely in this case; although the patient's brother could also have type 1 diabetes, this type of diabetes is less heritable than MODY or type 2 diabetes. It is unlikely to affect three first-degree relatives in an apparent autosomal-dominant pattern. Finally, the C-peptide level is usually low in patients with type 1 diabetes.

C) CORRECT:

Diabetes in an adult with a lean body type and no stigmata of insulin resistance should prompt consideration of diagnoses other than type 2 diabetes, especially if the patient is young. This patient likely has maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY), an umbrella term for monogenic forms of diabetes inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, and she should be referred for genetic testing.

MODY is usually diagnosed in individuals between the ages of 10 and 45 who have a lean body type and a strong family history of diabetes mellitus that started at a young age; these patients do not usually require treatment with insulin, and they have a normal C-peptide level (suggesting intact insulin production).

Key learning point: The most likely cause of hyperglycemia in a young adult with a lean body type and a strong family history of diabetes mellitus is maturity-onset diabetes of the young.

D) INCORRECT:

Latent autoimmune diabetes of adulthood shares genetic features of both type 1 and type 2 diabetes; thus, latent autoimmune diabetes of adulthood would be unlikely in a patient with such a strong family history and an apparent autosomal-dominant pattern. In addition, lean patients with this condition usually have low endogenous insulin production and thus a low C-peptide level.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetes in an adult with a lean body type and no stigmata of insulin resistance should prompt consideration of diagnoses other than type 2 diabetes, especially if the patient is young.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man is hospitalized for treatment of an asthma exacerbation. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 2 years ago and received metformin at the maximal dose. His glycated hemoglobin measurements have never been below 7%; his most recent value was 8.4% (reference range, 4.3–5.6).
His aunt was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at 41 years of age, but there is no other family history of diabetes mellitus. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs.
His vital signs are normal, his BMI is 22, and other than findings consistent with asthma, his physical examination is unremarkable.
During his hospitalization, glucocorticoids are administered, and his blood glucose level is consistently between 250 and 300 mg/dL throughout the day (reference range, 70–100). His glucose levels normalize appropriately in response to initiation of low-dose insulin during his hospitalization.
Recent laboratory testing reveals a glutamic acid decarboxylase 65 antibody level of 2.5 U/mL (≤1.0) and a postprandial C-peptide level of 0.8 ng/mL (1.2–3.4).
What discharge medication(s) are most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (such as liraglutide) have been suggested to have a role in delaying progression of LADA, there is currently inadequate data to support their use.

B) INCORRECT:

There is very little evidence for the use of pioglitazone in patients with LADA, but this would not be expected to be effective.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s features are characteristic of latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA). LADA results in insulin deficiency that gradually increases. Affected patients usually have a low BMI with low serum C-peptide levels and may have one or more antibodies against glutamic acid decarboxylase, islet cells, or insulin. LADA tends to manifest before age 50 in patients who have a family history of autoimmune disease. Although patients with type 1 diabetes also have antibodies against glutamic acid decarboxylase and other antibodies, they tend to have faster disease progression than patients with LADA.

Because of the progressive insulin deficiency associated with LADA, insulin is the treatment of choice for patients with this condition. Although noninsulin medications, and specifically dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (such as sitagliptin) and glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (such as liraglutide), have been suggested to have a role in delaying progression of this disease, there is currently inadequate data to support their use. Sulfonylureas such as glipizide have been shown to be associated with worse beta-cell function than insulin. There is very little evidence for the use of metformin or pioglitazone in patients with LADA, but these would not be expected to be effective.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adult patient with mild hyperglycemia and antibodies against glutamic acid decarboxylase is latent autoimmune diabetes in adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Although noninsulin medications, and specifically dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (such as sitagliptin) and glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (such as liraglutide), have been suggested to have a role in delaying progression of LADA, there is currently inadequate data to support their use. There is very little evidence for the use of metformin in patients with LADA.

E) INCORRECT:

Sulfonylureas such as glipizide have been shown to be associated with worse beta-cell function than insulin. There is very little evidence for the use of metformin in patients with LADA, but this would not be expected to be effective.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman with long-standing type 2 diabetes whose most recent glycated hemoglobin value is 8.1% (reference range, 4.3–5.6) is seen for glycemic management. She reports adherence to her insulin regimen of 180 units of U-100 insulin glargine at night and 50 units of U-100 insulin lispro before every meal. She also takes metformin, aspirin, lisinopril, and simvastatin. In the past, she was unable to tolerate liraglutide and dulaglutide because of development of gastroparesis, and empagliflozin was stopped 6 months ago after she had six episodes of genitourinary candidiasis during the 12 months that she took the drug.
Her mean fasting glucose level is 148 mg/dL (reference range, 70–100), and her mean 2-hour postprandial glucose level is 225 mg/dL. She has had no episodes of hypoglycemia and is otherwise well.
On examination, her height is 162 cm, her weight is 78 kg, her BMI is 29.7, and her blood pressure is 136/80 mm Hg. The skin at the back of her neck and in both axillae is thickened and hyperpigmented.
Which one of the following next steps is best for managing this patient?

choices.text: Replace the current insulin regimen with concentrated regular insulin (U-500)
Replace the U-100 insulin glargine with twice-daily U-100 neutral protamine Hagedorn insulin
Add a sulfonylurea to the regimen
Replace the U-100 insulin lispro with U-100 regular insulin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

People with severe insulin resistance (defined as a daily insulin requirement >200 units) may have difficulty achieving glycemic control with standard concentrations of insulin analogues or regular insulin. An alternative is to use more-concentrated forms of insulin.

Standard Concentrations of Insulin

Most insulins are provided at a concentration of 100 units per 1 mL (U-100); however, when patients need large doses of insulin, this concentration may be insufficient. The amount of insulin needed per dose may exceed the maximal dose that can be administered by the insulin pen or insulin syringe. The patient may therefore have to inject several times to achieve the desired dose, which can reduce both quality of life and adherence to the prescribed regimen. In addition, there may be reduced absorption of the insulin when large volumes are injected, leading to reduced clinical effect.

Concentrated Regular Insulin

Several studies have demonstrated the benefits of concentrated regular insulin (U-500), which is 500 units of insulin in 1 mL. The use of U-500 insulin can result in more stable glucose levels and a lower glycated hemoglobin concentration. In addition to this improved glycemic control and the reduced volume of injected insulin, U-500 insulin has a longer duration of action than U-100 regular insulin and thus typically requires fewer daily injections.

Other Alternatives

Other options for achieving glycemic control in patients with severe insulin resistance include:

• Delivery of U-100 rapid-acting insulin using an insulin pump (a slow infusion of smaller amounts of insulin appears to be more effective than single-bolus injections of large amounts)
• Use of other concentrated insulins, such as U-300 insulin glargine (300 units per mL), U-200 insulin degludec (200 units per mL), and U-200 insulin lispro (200 units per mL)
• Use of noninsulin agents to help reduce the insulin requirements, commonly glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists, dual agonists of the receptors for both GLP-1 and the glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide, and sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors (all of which are contraindicated in this case).

Key learning point: When patients with type 2 diabetes require >200 units of insulin daily, they should be switched to a concentrated form of insulin, such as U-500 regular insulin.

B) INCORRECT:

Replacing the insulin glargine with neutral protamine Hagedorn insulin would not improve glucose control and may be harmful because the use of neutral protamine Hagedorn insulin is associated with a higher incidence of hypoglycemia.

C) INCORRECT:

When high doses of insulin are required, oral insulin secretagogues, such as sulfonylureas, are ineffective.

D) INCORRECT:

Replacing this patient’s insulin lispro with regular insulin, without increasing the concentration of insulin, would not improve glucose control and may be deleterious, given that the half-life of regular insulin does not correspond to a typical postprandial glucose peak.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring glucagon levels is inappropriate in the absence of clinical features of glucagonoma, such as refractory hyperglycemia with rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), weight loss, diarrhea, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man with well-controlled asthma presents with a fasting blood glucose level of 132 mg/dL (reference range, 70–100) and a glycated hemoglobin value of 7.5% (4.3–5.6). His BMI is 26.7. He receives a diagnosis of new-onset type 2 diabetes and is instructed in diet and exercise.
He returns 6 months later and reports adherence to dietary and exercise recommendations. His weight and BMI are unchanged, and his glycated hemoglobin level is 8.0%.
