Monotherapy with sitagliptin is not recommended as initial treatment for children or adolescents with type 2 diabetes. Sitagliptin, a dipeptidyl-peptidase-4 inhibitor, is indicated as an adjunct to diet and exercise to improve glycemic control in adults with type 2 diabetes

B) INCORRECT:

Adding insulin therapy to metformin and lifestyle changes is also recommended for patients who have ketosis or ketoacidosis, have overlapping characteristics of type 1 and type 2 diabetes, or have evidence of significant hyperglycemia (random glucose level ≥250 mg/dL or glycated hemoglobin level ≥8.5%).

C) INCORRECT:

Monotherapy with glipizide is not recommended as initial treatment for children or adolescents with type 2 diabetes. Glipizide, a sulfonylurea whose safety has not been established in children, is not FDA approved for treating children with diabetes. Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists have recently been approved as adjunct therapy for treatment of type 2 diabetes in people aged ≥10 years and are recommended by the ADA in this age group if glycated hemoglobin goals are not met with metformin and lifestyle changes.

D) CORRECT:

Determining the type of diabetes mellitus is important in all patients with new-onset diabetes because management differs drastically between type 1 and type 2 diabetes. Patients with type 2 diabetes, as in this case, generally have a strong family history of type 2 diabetes, show evidence of insulin resistance (acanthosis nigricans) on examination, and have either overweight or obesity. Lifestyle changes are necessary for all patients with diabetes, but medication is also indicated in this patient. According to the American Diabetes Association (ADA) guidelines, metformin is the most appropriate initial therapy (in addition to lifestyle modification) for patients who have a glycated hemoglobin level <8.5% and do not have ketosis or significant hyperglycemia (random glucose level ≥250 mg/dL). Lifestyle changes include dietary counseling, physical activity, adequate sleep, and restriction of screen time. Comorbidities such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia should be identified and aggressively treated. Glycated hemoglobin levels should be monitored every 3 months, and treatment should be tailored to meet a target glycated hemoglobin level <7.0%. If the glycated hemoglobin level does not indicate a response to metformin in the first 4 months, then a second agent is typically indicated.

Key learning point: The appropriate initial approach to managing children or adolescents who have type 2 diabetes and a glycated hemoglobin level <8.5% is metformin treatment and lifestyle changes.

E) INCORRECT:

Basal and bolus insulin therapy would be appropriate initial therapy for a patient with type 1 diabetes or appropriate second-line therapy for a patient with type 2 diabetes who cannot obtain adequate control with oral agents or with basal insulin used with oral agents.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman presents for her first prenatal visit at 8 weeks’ gestation. The pregnancy was unintended but welcomed. She has a history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes with a prepregnancy glycated hemoglobin level of 10.1% (goal, <7.0%). She has continued to take metformin 850 mg three times daily; she takes no other medications.
Her BMI is 35, and her blood pressure is 105/72 mm Hg. Handheld ultrasonography confirms visual fetal cardiac activity at about 150 beats per minute. Her bimanual examination is consistent with an 8-week pregnancy.
Urinalysis is positive for glucose, but no protein is detected.
Which one of the following conditions is most likely to be the cause of perinatal mortality in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fetal macrosomia, defined as fetal size >90th percentile for gestational age or >4 kg in the full-term infant, occurs in 15% to 45% of pregnancies among women with diabetes. Although macrosomia is more common than major congenital abnormalities, it is not a leading cause of perinatal mortality.

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal intrauterine growth restriction is most often associated with maternal renovascular disease and maternal hypertension, but it is not a major cause of perinatal mortality.

C) INCORRECT:

Diabetes is not considered a risk factor for prematurity.

D) CORRECT:

Major congenital anomalies occur in 6% to 12% of pregnancies among women with preexisting diabetes, making it the leading cause of perinatal mortality in this population. Studies have linked this increased mortality to poor prepregnancy glycemic control, at least in part because levels of glycated hemoglobin correlate with the frequency of anomalies. Cardiac, central nervous system, and skeletal anomalies are the most common congenital anomalies to complicate the pregnancies of women with preexisting diabetes.

Fetal macrosomia, defined as fetal size >90th percentile for gestational age or >4 kg in the full-term infant, occurs in 15% to 45% of pregnancies among women with diabetes. During the second half of pregnancy, hypertrophic islet cells respond to hyperglycemia with an increase in fetal insulin production. Insulin is a major anabolic hormone; in the setting of hyperglycemia, there is a substantial increase in fat stores, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and cardiomegaly. Although macrosomia is more common than major congenital abnormalities, it is not a leading cause of perinatal mortality.

Other pregnancy-related conditions that are especially common in women with preexisting type 2 diabetes include preterm labor, polyhydramnios (which may contribute to preterm labor), and primary cesarean delivery.

Key learning point: The leading cause of perinatal mortality in pregnant women with uncontrolled diabetes that existed before the pregnancy is a major congenital anomaly.

E) INCORRECT:

Preeclampsia is more common in women with type 1 diabetes, especially with coexisting nephropathy. It is also more common in women with hypertension and poor glucose control. However, it is not as common a complication as macrosomia in patients with uncontrolled hyperglycemia and is a less common cause of perinatal mortality than congenital malformations.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy presents for a sports physical. He has gained 4.5 kg since his well-child visit 4 months ago. He says that he wants to play football but currently prefers to play video games in his free time. He eats fast food for lunch every day, drinks two to three sodas per day, and enjoys snacking late into the night.
His BMI is 120% of the 95th percentile for his age. His height is at the 90th percentile for his age, and he has appropriate growth velocity. His blood pressure is 135/78 mm Hg. The skin around his neck, axillae, and elbows is significantly darkened and has a velvety texture. He also has light-colored striae over his abdomen.
His mother, who has accompanied him on the visit, is concerned about his weight gain. She reports that she and her mother both have type 2 diabetes and that her mother also has hypothyroidism.
Which one of the following measurements should be obtained as part of this patient's initial evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A thyroid-stimulating hormone level is not indicated in a patient with no known symptoms of hypothyroidism, even if they have a significant family history.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine levels should be evaluated in cases of persistent hypertension but would not be the test of choice after one elevated blood-pressure reading.

C) INCORRECT:

Insulin levels are not part of the diagnostic criteria for diabetes. Fasting insulin and C-peptide levels can provide information regarding the health of the pancreatic beta cell. Elevated insulin and C-peptide levels are more consistent with type 2 diabetes and insulin resistance, whereas lower insulin or C-peptide levels may suggest diminished beta-cell function.

D) CORRECT:

According to the American Diabetes Association, asymptomatic children aged 10 and older should be evaluated for type 2 diabetes if they have overweight or obesity and meet at least one of the following criteria:

• Family history of type 2 diabetes in first- or second-degree relatives
• Racial or ethnic background statistically or historically associated with higher risk (Native American, African American, Latino, Asian American, or Pacific Islander)
• Signs of insulin resistance or conditions associated with insulin resistance (e.g., acanthosis nigricans and hypertension)
• Maternal history of diabetes or gestational diabetes during the child’s gestation

This patient, who is 13 years old with obesity (BMI >95th percentile for age, height, and sex), has at least two of the criteria above and should therefore be evaluated further.

Children and adolescents (as well as adults) are considered to have type 2 diabetes if their laboratory evaluation reveals at least one of the following results:

• Fasting plasma glucose level ≥126 mg/dL
• Glycated hemoglobin level ≥6.5%
• Random plasma glucose level ≥200 mg/dL with classic symptoms of hyperglycemia (polyuria, polydipsia, unexplained weight loss)
• Plasma glucose level ≥200 mg/dL two hours after challenge in oral glucose-tolerance testing

Glycated hemoglobin measurements, fasting plasma glucose measurements, and oral glucose tolerance tests may all be used as screening tests for type 2 diabetes, but each has limitations. The American Diabetes Association acknowledges that there are limited data supporting the use of glycated hemoglobin to diagnose diabetes in children but continues to offer it as an option, except in children with hemoglobinopathies, cystic fibrosis, or symptoms suggestive of acute-onset type 1 diabetes. Fasting plasma glucose measurements are cost-effective but may lead to overdiagnosis of diabetes in children. Oral glucose tolerance tests can be difficult to administer, especially in children.

Key learning point: Initial evaluation for type 2 diabetes can be done using glycated hemoglobin, fasting serum glucose, or oral glucose tolerance testing.

E) INCORRECT:

Islet-cell antibody level is not a primary diagnostic indicator of type 2 diabetes but may be valuable as an ancillary study. Islet-cell antibodies are more common in patients with type 1 diabetes.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of increased fussiness and vomiting for the past day and heavy, wet diapers for the past week but no diarrhea or fevers.
She is tachycardic, but with normal blood pressure for her age and height, and is well perfused. She has deep, labored breathing. Her mucous membranes are dry. Abdominal examination reveals a soft, nondistended abdomen without tenderness.
Point-of-care testing identifies a serum glucose level of 680 mg/dL (reference range, 60–100); the venous pH is 7.05 (7.35–7.45). Urinalysis reveals 2+ glucose and ketones.
Serum electrolyte levels are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
130
135–147


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.2
3.4–4.7


Chloride (mEq/liter)
96
97–107


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
5
16–24


Anion gap (mEq/liter)
29
8–12


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
4.7
4.5–6.5


Magnesium (mEq/liter)
1.8
1.26–2.1


Glucose (mg/dL)
720
60–100


Which of the following total-body stores of electrolytes and volume status is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with DKA typically have osmotic diuresis leading to hypovolemia and a total-body deficit of potassium and phosphorus.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with DKA typically have osmotic diuresis leading to hypovolemia and a total-body deficit of potassium and phosphorus.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with DKA typically have osmotic diuresis leading to hypovolemia and a total-body deficit of potassium and phosphorus.

D) CORRECT:

This patient is presenting with new-onset type 1 diabetes complicated by severe diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). She meets diagnostic criteria for DKA by exhibiting hyperglycemia (glucose level >200 mg/dL), acidemia (venous pH <7.3), and large ketonuria. Appropriate treatment of DKA consists of resuscitation fluids followed by deficit-replacement fluids, insulin therapy, and electrolyte repletion; in addition, patients should be monitored closely for complications of DKA and its therapy, including cerebral edema, electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypophosphatemia), hyperchloremic acidemia, and hypoglycemia.

Children with DKA have glucosuria, which leads to an osmotic diuresis with loss of sodium and water, resulting in volume depletion. There are also urinary losses of a range of electrolytes, but the initial serum electrolyte values may not represent total-body stores of these electrolytes.

In DKA, serum sodium is affected by water movement in two ways: (1) the osmotic dilution effect of hyperglycemia (hyperosmolality due to hyperglycemia draws free water out of the cells, diluting the serum and reducing the measured serum sodium level), and (2) osmotic diuresis that leads to excess water loss and therefore relative deficiency in water, with a resulting increase in the measured sodium concentration. Younger children may not be able to independently replete their excessive water losses as efficiently as older children and adults can. To account for the dilutional effect of hyperglycemia, a corrected sodium level can be calculated. This corrected level is an estimate of what the measured serum sodium level would have been if there was no hyperglycemia and can therefore indicate whether there is free-water deficiency (if the corrected sodium level is in the hypernatremia range) or free-water excess (if the corrected sodium level is in the hyponatremia range). This can then influence the choice of intravenous fluid to correct the patient’s water and volume derangements. The corrected sodium level is calculated by adding 1.6 mEq/liter to the measured sodium level for every 100-mg/dL increase in the glucose level above a level of 100 mg/dL. In this patient, who has a measured serum sodium level of 130 mEq/liter and glucose level of 720 mg/dL, the corrected sodium level is 130 + (1.6 x 6.2), or approximately 140 mEq/liter.

Patients with DKA also have a total-body potassium deficit (typically on the order of 3 to 6 mmol/kg, related to transcellular shifts, osmotic diuresis, urinary excretion from secondary hyperaldosteronism, and losses from vomiting), although their initial serum potassium level may be low, normal, or high. This deficit requires potassium repletion through intravenous fluids; typically, 40 mEq/liter is added to the fluids as a combination of potassium chloride, acetate, or phosphate, and then the content is adjusted on the basis of subsequent serum potassium measurements. If the patient is initially hyperkalemic, potassium is added after demonstration of urine output; if the patient is initially hypokalemic, the potassium infusion may be required before initiation of insulin therapy to prevent worsening of hypokalemia due to insulin-mediated shift of potassium into cells.

Osmotic diuresis also results in a total-body deficit of phosphorus (typically on the order of 0.5–2.5 mmol/kg), although the serum phosphorus level is often elevated at presentation because of insulin deficiency and metabolic acidemia. Insulin treatment and correction of acidemia causes serum phosphorus levels to drop, unmasking the total-body phosphorus deficit.

Key learning point: Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis have deficits in total-body potassium and phosphorus.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with DKA typically have osmotic diuresis leading to hypovolemia and a total-body deficit of potassium and phosphorus.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old young woman with long-standing type 1 diabetes and Hashimoto thyroiditis presents for routine follow-up. Her glycated hemoglobin level has ranged from 7.2% to 8.4% during the past 3 years. She is currently prescribed multiple daily injections of insulin for diabetes management, including insulin glargine once daily for basal insulin and insulin lispro for prandial insulin before meals. An insulin pump was attempted when she was 14 years of age, but she developed a rash to the adhesive and did not like the feeling of being attached to the device, so she opted to go back to multiple daily injections of insulin. She also takes levothyroxine to treat her hypothyroidism.
She started college 3 months ago in a new city and is currently home on break. She reports that she has lost 3.6 kg of body weight at college despite an increase in appetite. She has also had dry mouth, which has prompted her to drink throughout the day and night. The increased thirst is accompanied by increased urination and fatigue.
She forgot to bring her glucometer to the appointment today but reports that her blood glucose level was 90 mg/dL this morning before breakfast.
Which one of the following laboratory results is most likely to explain this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Elevated tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypothyroidism related to Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common autoimmune disease that occurs concurrently with type 1 diabetes. Classic symptoms of hypothyroidism include fatigue, constipation, cold intolerance, and dry skin (but not dry mouth). Although this patient may also have poor adherence to her levothyroxine regimen, her symptoms are more consistent with hyperglycemia than a hypothyroid state. An elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone level is therefore unlikely in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

As patients with type 1 diabetes get older, they often have increasing independence with their diabetes management — a transition that many find challenging given the intense insulin regimens required to maintain optimal glycemic control. The recommended treatment for type 1 diabetes includes injections of long-acting insulin once daily for basal insulin and rapid-acting insulin with every meal for prandial and correctional insulin. These regimens require patients to administer 4 to 6 insulin injections each day, monitor blood glucose levels before each injection, and calculate carbohydrate intake and correction-factor doses. Use of an insulin pump (continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion) can simplify some aspects of diabetes management but may also present other challenges, including pump malfunction and alarm fatigue. “Diabetes burnout” is therefore very common, especially during periods of transition, when patients might find it even more challenging to maintain the recommended frequency of blood glucose monitoring and insulin injections.

In this case, the patient has recently started college in a new city and is experiencing classic symptoms of hyperglycemia despite attributing her increased thirst to dry mouth. Hyperglycemia causes glucosuria and subsequent polyuria, which then leads to polydipsia related to excess fluid losses. Without adequate insulin, patients are not able to use glucose as a source of energy and subsequently experience weight loss and fatigue. This patient’s laboratory testing is therefore likely to show an elevated glycated hemoglobin level.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of worsening glycemic control in a patient with type 1 diabetes who recently became more independent with diabetes care is poor adherence to diabetes treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of albuminuria (urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio >30 mg/g) is an early sign of diabetic nephropathy; screening is recommended after a patient has had type 1 diabetes for 3 to 5 years. Patients with poorly controlled diabetes have a higher risk of developing diabetic nephropathy, whereas intensive diabetes control and lower glycated hemoglobin levels during childhood have long-term benefits and are associated with lower rates of microvascular complications. This patient should undergo measurement of the urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio as part of routine screening, but gross proteinuria is not expected at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency and celiac disease are autoimmune diseases that are more prevalent in patients with type 1 diabetes than in the general population. Although either condition, when undiagnosed, can lead to weight loss, this patient’s other symptoms are not consistent with these diagnoses: She reports increased appetite, whereas adrenal insufficiency is more commonly associated with nausea and decreased appetite, and celiac disease typically manifests with abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Low morning cortisol and elevated tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody levels are therefore unlikely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency and celiac disease are autoimmune diseases that are more prevalent in patients with type 1 diabetes than in the general population. Although either condition, when undiagnosed, can lead to weight loss, this patient’s other symptoms are not consistent with these diagnoses: She reports increased appetite, whereas adrenal insufficiency is more commonly associated with nausea and decreased appetite, and celiac disease typically manifests with abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Low morning cortisol and elevated tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody levels are therefore unlikely in this patient.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman presents for a health maintenance examination at her university health center. She takes no medications and has never been sexually active. She reports no problems with appetite, sleep, bowel movements, urination, or mood. She reached menarche at 13 years of age, but her periods have never been regular, occurring every 40 to 90 days. She smokes a couple of cigarettes each day but does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her mother has type 2 diabetes and had a heart attack recently, at 55 years of age. Her father has well-controlled hypertension. Her blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg, and her BMI is 24.
On examination, comedones are noted on her forehead, nose, and cheeks (figure). She also has a moderate amount of dark hair above her upper lip, on her chin, and on her lower abdomen. An external genitourinary examination is unremarkable.
A urine sample is negative for human chorionic gonadotropin. Laboratory testing reveals a random glucose level of 160 mg/dL (reference range, <140) and an elevated free testosterone level. Serum levels of thyroid-stimulating hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, prolactin, 17-hydroxyprogesterone, and lipids are normal. Cortisol levels in a late-night saliva sample are within the reference range.
You discuss smoking cessation with the patient and assess her readiness for change, as well as options for treating her menstrual irregularity, acne, and hirsutism. A follow-up appointment is scheduled in one month.
Which one of the following tests should be ordered next?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient meets the Rotterdam criteria for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) given the presence of features of ovulatory dysfunction (chronically irregular menses) and hyperandrogenism (acne, hirsutism, and elevated free testosterone level). When considering PCOS, clinicians should conduct testing to rule out pregnancy and differential diagnoses of PCOS, such as thyroid disease, hyperprolactinemia, and nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

Patients with PCOS are at increased risk for metabolic syndrome, a group of conditions including hypertension, abdominal obesity, dyslipidemia, and glucose intolerance. All patients with PCOS should be screened for metabolic syndrome with regular measurements of blood pressure, waist circumference, fasting lipid profiles, and tests for prediabetes or type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Abnormal results suggesting metabolic syndrome in women include blood pressure ≥130/85 mm Hg, waist circumference ≥35 inches, HDL-cholesterol level ≤50 mg/dL, triglyceride level ≥150 mg/dL, fasting glucose level ≥110 mg/dL, and a 2-hour postprandial glucose level ≥140 mg/dL.

This patient's mildly elevated random (nonfasting) glucose level of 160 mg/dL is concerning but not diagnostic of prediabetes or T2DM. Although this patient’s BMI is currently in the healthy range (18.5–24.9), she has risk factors for glucose intolerance, including PCOS and a family history of T2DM. Because PCOS is associated with a 5- to 10-fold increased risk for prediabetes and T2DM, screening for these conditions is recommended upon diagnosis of PCOS and should be conducted regularly (typically every 1 to 3 years). The preferred screening approach in patients with PCOS is a 2-hour oral glucose tolerance testing (OGTT) with a 75-gram glucose load. A glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) test and fasting plasma glucose levels are more convenient than a formal 2-hour OGTT, but they are less sensitive. This is because in the early stages of glucose intolerance, the physiologic mechanisms that maintain euglycemia may be able to keep both the fasting blood glucose level and the average blood glucose level (which is assessed using HbA1c) normal. If a patient with PCOS is unable or unwilling to complete an OGTT, an HbA1c test or fasting plasma glucose level may be considered.

Key learning point: Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome should be screened for metabolic syndrome at diagnosis and regularly thereafter, using waist circumference, blood pressure, fasting lipid levels, and a 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with PCOS are at increased risk for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, but current guidelines do not recommend screening for this disorder in individuals without overweight.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient, with features of ovulatory dysfunction and hyperandrogenism, already meets the Rotterdam criteria for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). While ultrasonography can confirm polycystic ovarian morphology, it is not routinely required for the diagnosis or initial workup of PCOS. Due to the increased risk of endometrial cancer associated with PCOS, transvaginal ultrasonography may be considered if an older woman with PCOS experiences symptoms such as intermenstrual or heavy menstrual bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia may manifest in adolescence or young adulthood with symptoms of hyperandrogenism. Although evaluation for nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia includes an adrenocorticotropic hormone stimulation test, it is not indicated in this patient who has a normal 17-hydroxyprogesterone level.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with PCOS are at an increased risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and should be evaluated for OSA symptoms regardless of BMI. Polysomnography, however, is not routinely needed in the workup of PCOS. It is performed only to confirm an OSA diagnosis if the patient has OSA symptoms or tests positive on a standardized OSA screening questionnaire.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female college student presents with a 2-week history of vaginal itching and burning. She also noticed white vaginal discharge despite cleaning her genital area daily using a "soap-free, natural" vaginal douche. She is worried that she might have contracted a sexually transmitted disease. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus. The patient swims for the college swimming team. She had an intrauterine device implanted 3 months ago. Speculum examination shows an erythematous vagina covered in copious white discharge. Her vaginal pH is 4.4 and the microscopic image of a potassium hydroxide preparation shows multiple pseudohyphae. Hemoglobin A1c is 7.2%. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While swimming pools do not predispose to Candida infection in general, there is a debate about whether wearing damp, tight-fitting bathing suits for an extended period of time might create an optimal environment for yeast and promote overgrowth. However, another predisposing factor is much more significant in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Frequent vaginal douching to cleanse the inside of the vagina and the use of soaps with perfumes and irritating chemicals are risk factors for bacterial vaginosis because they disturb the normal vaginal microflora. Vaginal douching decreases the amount of lactic acid-producing lactobacilli, which leads to an increase in the pH balance. A pH higher than 4.5 is no longer acidic enough to prevent the proliferation of certain organisms, and contributes, e.g., to an increase in Gardnerella vaginalis.

C) INCORRECT:

Unprotected sexual intercourse is a risk factor for several sexually transmitted infections, such as trichomoniasis and Chlamydia. However, Candida overgrowth is commonly precipitated by other factors.

D) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices may be associated with gynecologic infections and pelvic inflammatory disease. However, the risk is very low, making another cause much more likely in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus (DM) predisposes to vaginal yeast infections since high levels of glucose provide the carbon needed for Candida overgrowth and infection. Moreover, DM results in immunodeficiency, which is also associated with an increased risk of persistent or recurrent yeast infection. Other risk factors that precipitate overgrowth of C. albicans are systemic antibiotic therapy and pregnancy, in which case high levels of estrogen favor overgrowth by Candida. Treatment of acute infection consists of topical azoles (e.g., miconazole, clotrimazole) or a single dose of oral fluconazole. Maintaining normal blood sugar levels may help reduce the risk of recurrent or persistent infections in patients with DM.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast
questions.hint: Multiple pseudohyphae on wet mount preparation are characteristic of Candida infection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office for a 2-month history of abdominal discomfort, fatigue, and increased urinary frequency, especially at night. He has also noticed that despite eating more often he has lost 14-lbs (6-kg). He has a congenital solitary kidney and a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis, for which he takes levothyroxine. Body mass index is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. Serum studies show an osmolality of 305 mOsm/L and bicarbonate of 17 mEq/L. Urinalysis shows clear-colored urine with no organisms. Which of the following is most likely to be helpful in establishing the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An ultrasonography of the thyroid gland can be used to help diagnose thyroid diseases and is routinely used in the evaluation of a palpable thyroid nodule. This patient's history of Hashimoto thyroiditis places him at increased risk for non-Hodgkin lymphoma, which may present with painless enlargement of the thyroid, fatigue, and weight loss. However, polyuria, polyphagia, and abdominal pain would not be expected. There is nothing in this patient' s history to suggest thyroid involvement in his current condition and an ultrasound is unlikely to be helpful.

B) CORRECT:

A single random serum glucose level of ≥ 200 mg/dL is sufficient for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus in a patient with other classic signs of the disease (e.g., polyuria, dehydration, weight loss). Alternatively, a fasting plasma glucose ≥ 126 mg/dL, oral glucose tolerance test ≥ 200 mg/dL, or hemoglobin A1C ≥ 6.5 % are also diagnostic of diabetes mellitus. This patient's young age, history of autoimmune disease, evidence of acidosis, and weight loss are suggestive of type 1 diabetes mellitus, which is caused by autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells.

Key learning point: A random serum glucose ≥200 mg/dL in the presence of classic symptoms is diagnostic for diabetes mellitus, especially in young patients with polyuria, weight loss, and a history of autoimmune disease.

C) INCORRECT:

A water deprivation test is helpful in the diagnosis of diabetes insipidus (DI). Patients with DI excrete large quantities of dilute urine (polyuria), which causes excessive thirst (polydipsia) in response to fluid loss. While this patient has polyuria, recent onset polyphagia and a metabolic acidosis would not be expected with this condition. Given this patient's age and other symptoms, a different diagnosis is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine levels are helpful in evaluating for impaired renal function, which typically manifests with anuria or oliguria. Polyuria in the setting of kidney injury is classically only seen following an episode of acute tubular necrosis, which this patient has no history of or risk factors for. Serum creatinine would not be helpful in the diagnosis of this patient's condition.

Renal function is not typically impaired in patients with a congenital solitary kidney.

E) INCORRECT:

A digital rectal examination is most commonly performed to screen patients for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or for the evaluation of prostate nodules. Patients with BPH typically present with increased urinary frequency and nocturia, as seen in this patient. However, this patient's polyphagia, polyuria, and hypothyroidism are not characteristic of BPH. Furthermore, neither BPH nor prostate nodules are likely in a patient of this age group.
questions.hint: This patient's history of autoimmune hypothyroidism, urinary frequency, weight loss, hypovolemia (serum osmolality > 295 mOsm/L), and mild acidosis (low serum bicarbonate) suggests a condition that more commonly occurs in childhood.

questions.text: A previously healthy 15-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents for lethargy, increased thirst, and urinary frequency for 10 days. She is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (120 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her serum glucose concentration is 224 mg/dL. A urine dipstick is positive for ketone bodies. A diagnosis of type 1 diabetes mellitus is made. Which of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Expression of human leukocyte antigen subtype A3

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Expression of human leukocyte antigen (HLA) subtype A3 is associated with hemochromatosis, while type 1 diabetes is associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4. Although hemochromatosis can present with diabetes mellitus (due to pancreas damage following iron accumulation), symptoms such as cirrhosis and a characteristic bronze skin tone, arthralgias, and cardiomyopathy would be expected. Furthermore, hemochromatosis commonly affects adults.

B) INCORRECT:

Antimitochondrial antibodies are not associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus. They are, however, commonly seen in primary biliary cholangitis. Type 1 diabetes mellitus is typically associated with anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies.

C) INCORRECT:

Some patients with type 1 diabetes develop insulin receptor antibodies, which attack the insulin receptor. However, complement-mediated destruction of insulin receptors has not been identified as a cause of type 1 diabetes.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, infiltration of autoreactive CD4 and CD8 positive T cells into the pancreatic islets leads to the progressive destruction of insulin-producing β cells, which ultimately results in insulin deficiency. The immune system is thought to be activated by one or more environmental triggers (e.g., a viral infection, dietary factors) in genetically susceptible individuals. The loss of functioning β cells continues over months to years; symptoms usually manifest once 80–90% of β cells have been destroyed.

E) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP) deposition happens in type 2 diabetes, not type 1 diabetes. IAPP is cosecreted with insulin; as peripheral insulin resistance worsens in type 2 diabetes, β cells increase insulin synthesis and secretion, which subsequently leads to increased IAPP secretion as well. In the late stages of the disease, the amyloid aggregates become toxic to β cells.
questions.hint: This slim adolescent presents with classic features of type 1 diabetes mellitus: polydipsia, polyuria, hyperglycemia, and ketonuria.

questions.text: An 18-year-old young woman with long-standing type 1 diabetes and Hashimoto thyroiditis presents for routine follow-up. Her glycated hemoglobin level has ranged from 7.2% to 8.4% during the past 3 years. She is currently prescribed multiple daily injections of insulin for diabetes management. She also takes levothyroxine to treat her hypothyroidism. She started college 3 months ago in a new city. She reports that she has lost 3.6 kg of body weight at college. She has also had dry mouth, which has prompted her to drink throughout the day and night. The increased thirst is accompanied by increased urination and fatigue. She forgot to bring her glucometer to the appointment today but reports that her blood glucose level was 90 mg/dL this morning before breakfast. A) INCORRECT:

An elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone level is therefore unlikely in this patient.

These regimens require patients to administer 4 to 6 insulin injections each day, monitor blood glucose levels before each injection, and calculate carbohydrate intake and correction-factor doses. “Diabetes burnout” is therefore very common, especially during periods of transition, when patients might find it even more challenging to maintain the recommended frequency of blood glucose monitoring and insulin injections. In this case, the patient has recently started college in a new city and is experiencing classic symptoms of hyperglycemia despite attributing her increased thirst to dry mouth. Hyperglycemia causes glucosuria and subsequent polyuria, which then leads to polydipsia related to excess fluid losses. Without adequate insulin, patients are not able to use glucose as a source of energy and subsequently experience weight loss and fatigue. This patient’s laboratory testing is therefore likely to show an elevated glycated hemoglobin level.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of worsening glycemic control in a patient with type 1 diabetes who recently became more independent with diabetes care is poor adherence to diabetes treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of albuminuria (urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio >30 mg/g) is an early sign of diabetic nephropathy; screening is recommended after a patient has had type 1 diabetes for 3 to 5 years. Patients with poorly controlled diabetes have a higher risk of developing diabetic nephropathy, whereas intensive diabetes control and lower glycated hemoglobin levels during childhood have long-term benefits and are associated with lower rates of microvascular complications. This patient should undergo measurement of the urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio as part of routine screening, but gross proteinuria is not expected at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency and celiac disease are autoimmune diseases that are more prevalent in patients with type 1 diabetes than in the general population. Although either condition, when undiagnosed, can lead to weight loss, this patient’s other symptoms are not consistent with these diagnoses: She reports increased appetite, whereas adrenal insufficiency is more commonly associated with nausea and decreased appetite, and celiac disease typically manifests with abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Low morning cortisol and elevated tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody levels are therefore unlikely in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency and celiac disease are autoimmune diseases that are more prevalent in patients with type 1 diabetes than in the general population. Although either condition, when undiagnosed, can lead to weight loss, this patient’s other symptoms are not consistent with these diagnoses: She reports increased appetite, whereas adrenal insufficiency is more commonly associated with nausea and decreased appetite, and celiac disease typically manifests with abdominal pain, bloating, and nausea. Low morning cortisol and elevated tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibody levels are therefore unlikely in this patient.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is hospitalized for treatment of an asthma exacerbation. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 2 years ago and received metformin at the maximal dose. His glycated hemoglobin measurements have never been below 7%; his most recent value was 8.4% (reference range, 4.3–5.6). His aunt was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at 41 years of age. His BMI is 22. During his hospitalization, glucocorticoids are administered, and his blood glucose level is consistently between 250 and 300 mg/dL throughout the day (reference range, 70–100). His glucose levels normalize appropriately in response to initiation of low-dose insulin during his hospitalization. Recent laboratory testing reveals a glutamic acid decarboxylase 65 antibody level of 2.5 U/mL (≤1.0) and a postprandial C-peptide level of 0.8 ng/mL (1.2–3.4). What discharge medication(s) are most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (such as liraglutide) have been suggested to have a role in delaying progression of LADA, there is currently inadequate data to support their use.

B) INCORRECT:

There is very little evidence for the use of pioglitazone in patients with LADA, but this would not be expected to be effective.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s features are characteristic of latent autoimmune diabetes in adults (LADA). LADA results in insulin deficiency that gradually increases. Affected patients usually have a low BMI with low serum C-peptide levels and may have one or more antibodies against glutamic acid decarboxylase, islet cells, or insulin. LADA tends to manifest before age 50 in patients who have a family history of autoimmune disease. Because of the progressive insulin deficiency associated with LADA, insulin is the treatment of choice for patients with this condition.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an adult patient with mild hyperglycemia and antibodies against glutamic acid decarboxylase is latent autoimmune diabetes in adults.

D) INCORRECT:

Although noninsulin medications, and specifically dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors (such as sitagliptin) and glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonists (such as liraglutide), have been suggested to have a role in delaying progression of LADA, there is currently inadequate data to support their use. There is very little evidence for the use of metformin in patients with LADA.

E) INCORRECT:

Sulfonylureas such as glipizide have been shown to be associated with worse beta-cell function than insulin. There is very little evidence for the use of metformin in patients with LADA, but this would not be expected to be effective.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the office because of a 4-month history of increased urinary frequency. He wakes up several times a night to urinate and feels fatigued during the day. He also complains of increased thirst; he drinks multiple liters of water and soda daily and still feels thirsty. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows patches of velvety hyperpigmentation in the axillae and on the posterior neck. Laboratory evaluation in this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum thyroxine is a laboratory finding that suggests hyperthyroidism (e.g., Graves disease or thyroid adenoma). A hyperthyroid metabolic state can cause fatigue. However, hyperthyroidism does not typically cause polyuria, polydipsia, or hyperpigmentation. Moreover, this patient shows none of the classical features of hyperthyroidism, e.g., diarrhea, palpitations, heat intolerance, tachycardia, or diaphoresis.

B) CORRECT:

Elevated glycated hemoglobin is detected by measuring serum HbA1c. HbA1c levels can be elevated in patients with diabetes mellitus and correlate with the average blood glucose level from the previous 8–12 weeks. This patient's polyuria and polydipsia are most likely caused by consistently elevated glucose serum levels over 180 mg/dL, which marks the limit of renal glucose reabsorption capacity. The subsequent glucosuria leads to polyuria through osmotic diuresis. The increased renal water loss causes polydipsia and potentially hypovolemia, which explains this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) can be seen in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or malignant prostate cancer. Obstructive BPH is associated with increased urinary frequency and nocturia in middle-aged men. However, patients with BPH usually complain of urinary dribbling, unsuccessful emptying of the bladder, and, occasionally, overflow incontinence. Polydipsia is uncommon.

D) INCORRECT:

Positive urinary leukocyte esterase suggests a urinary tract infection. Common manifestations include fever, pain or burning with urination, urinary frequency, or foul-smelling urine. Although this patient complains of increased urinary frequency, it has been present for several months, and he does not show any other signs or symptoms of infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Low urine osmolality indicates very dilute urine; this is observed in patients with diabetes insipidus, which also causes polyuria and polydipsia. However, low urine osmolality is uncommon in diabetes mellitus. Normal or elevated urine osmolality is expected as a result of glucosuria. Additionally, this patient's acanthosis nigricans would not be explained by diabetes insipidus.
questions.hint: Polyuria, polydipsia, and acanthosis nigricans in an adult suggest insulin resistance, which is the underlying pathology of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with hypertension comes to the office because of frequent urination and increased thirst. He drinks 4 oz of alcohol daily and has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 106 kg (233 lb); body mass index is 33 kg/m2. His blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin A1c of 8.5%. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive alcohol consumption is a risk factor for the development of acute and chronic pancreatitis, alcohol-associated liver disease, and malignancies such as esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. However, alcohol consumption is not associated with an increased risk of T2DM.

B) INCORRECT:

While the prevalence of type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) is highest among non-Hispanic White individuals, this patient has T2DM. The highest rates of T2DM are seen among Hispanic, African American, Native American, Asian American, and Pacific Islander populations. White race is not a risk factor for T2DM.

C) CORRECT:

A high-calorie diet and a sedentary lifestyle are risk factors for obesity (BMI > 30 kg/m2), which increases the risk of T2DM by intensifying peripheral insulin resistance. Insulin resistance inhibits glucose uptake from the bloodstream and impairs anabolic metabolism. Lifestyle modifications such as weight reduction, a balanced diet, and regular exercise reduce the risk of developing T2DM.

D) INCORRECT:

Smoking is the leading risk factor for the development of lung and pancreatic cancer and it increases the risk for various conditions. While there could theoretically be a link between smoking and T2DM (e.g., impairment of insulin sensitivity and an increase in blood glucose concentration in smokers), there is no definitive evidence of a causal association.

E) INCORRECT:

HLA-DR4 is strongly associated with numerous autoimmune diseases, including type I diabetes mellitus (T1DM). However, this patient has T2DM, which is caused by a combination of hereditary and environmental factors and is strongly associated with metabolic syndrome. T2DM is not an autoimmune condition and is not associated with HLA-DR4.
questions.hint: Polyuria (frequent urination), polydipsia (increased thirst), and an elevated hemoglobin A1c in this middle-aged man suggest type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up examination. Physical examination shows hyperpigmented plaques on the posterior neck and in the axillae. His hemoglobin A1c concentration is 7.4% and fasting serum glucose concentration is 174 mg/dL. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated systolic blood pressure in hypertensive patients is a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome. Although patients with metabolic syndrome have an increased risk of developing diabetes, elevated systolic blood pressure alone is not a risk factor for type 2 diabetes.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals of Hispanic, African American, and Asian ethnicity have a greater risk for type 2 diabetes mellitus than white individuals. However, ethnicity is not the strongest predisposing factor for developing type 2 diabetes mellitus.

C) INCORRECT:

Childhood obesity increases the risk of type 2 diabetes but it is not the strongest predisposing factor because losing weight before puberty decreases this risk to the same level as those without childhood obesity.

D) INCORRECT:

New studies have shown that smoking is an independent risk factor for developing type 2 diabetes but smoking is not the strongest predisposing factor for developing type 2 diabetes mellitus.

E) CORRECT:

A high waist circumference or waist-to-hip ratio is a sign of central obesity, which is a strong predisposing factor for the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Increased abdominal and visceral fat is associated with increased lipolytic activity and increased levels of serum free fatty acids. Increased levels of fatty acids induce insulin resistance by decreasing peripheral insulin-mediated glucose uptake.
questions.hint: This patient's laboratory studies (elevated HbA1c and fasting serum glucose levels) and skin findings (acanthosis nigricans) are consistent with a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text:
A 92-year-old woman presents for management of type 2 diabetes. She has been controlling her diabetes with dietary measures since diagnosis, and her glycated hemoglobin value has routinely been below 7.0% until last week, when it was 7.4%. The patient has no other symptoms and feels well. She has hypertension, which is well controlled with hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine. She also has osteoporosis, which is treated with denosumab as well as calcium and vitamin D supplements. She takes fluvastatin for hypercholesterolemia. Her blood pressure is 134/82 mm Hg, her weight is 58 kg (128 lb), and her BMI is 21.7 kg/m2. Laboratory studies show:


Creatinine
1.4 mg/dL


Estimated glomerular filtration rate
25 mL/min/1.73 m2 (N ≥ 60)


Urea nitrogen
25 mg/dL


LDL cholesterol
94 mg/dL


Which of the following next steps is best in managing this patient’s type 2 diabetes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although metformin is the preferred initial pharmacologic agent for type 2 diabetes, it is contraindicated in individuals who have an estimated glomerular filtration rate < 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 (as in this case). Continuing metformin in a patient who is already taking it and develops an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 30 to 45 mL/min/1.73 m2 is reasonable, but starting metformin in an individual with this degree of renal impairment is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Because this patient’s diabetes is reasonably controlled, the potential risk for hypoglycemia associated with sulfonylurea (e.g., glipizide) treatment outweighs the limited benefit of better glycemic control.

C) INCORRECT:

A dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor such as sitagliptin or linagliptin would confer minimal risk of hypoglycemia and would be a reasonable choice if this patient's glycated hemoglobin value were higher, but additional agents are not needed at this time. If a DPP-4 did eventually become necessary for this patient, linagliptin may be preferred over sitagliptin because it is not renally cleared and therefore would not require dose adjustment in a patient with renal impairment.

D) CORRECT:

Older individuals may be more susceptible to the adverse effects of treatment, such as hypoglycemia, and may derive less benefit from the control of hyperglycemia compared to younger patients . A higher glycated hemoglobin value may be particularly appropriate for patients with long-standing type 2 diabetes who are at high risk for cardiovascular disease. Outpatient diabetes regimens for older patients should be designed specifically to minimize hypoglycemia. Before determining treatment goals and strategies, clinicians should consider the patient’s overall health and personal values. For patients in poor health (end-stage medical conditions, moderate to severe dementia, residence in a long-term nursing facility, or impairments in two or more activities of daily living), it would be reasonable to have a glycated hemoglobin target as high as 8.5%. In this particular patient, who is described as independent but with several chronic illnesses (chronic kidney disease, hypertension, dyslipidemia, osteoporosis), a glycated hemoglobin target of <8% may be reasonable. Continuing dietary control is the best next step in treating this older patient’s diabetes.

Key learning point: Less stringent glycemic control is reasonable in older patients, especially those with multiple comorbid conditions where the risks of tight glycemic control outweigh any expected benefit.

E) INCORRECT:

Because this patient’s diabetes is reasonably controlled, the potential risk for hypoglycemia associated with insulin treatment outweighs the limited benefit of better glycemic control.
questions.hint: The risks and benefits of treatment for type 2 diabetes must be weighed carefully in older patients.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman presents with concern about hyperglycemia. A week ago, she measured her own random blood glucose level using a glucometer; it was 186 mg/dL in the mid-afternoon (N < 140). On physical examination, the patient’s height is 164 cm, her weight is 73.5 kg (162 lb), and her BMI is 27.3 kg/m2. Her pulse is 82/min, and her blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. A velvety hyperpigmentation is noted on the posterior folds of her neck. The next morning, the patient presents after 8 hours of fasting. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


Plasma glucose
94 mg/dL


Glycated hemoglobin
6.1%


Plasma glucose 2 hours after an oral load of 75 g of glucose

177 mg/dL (N < 140)


What is the correct interpretation of this patient’s blood test results?

choices.text: Autoantibody testing is indicated before making a diagnosis
At least one of the tests should be repeated on another day before making a diagnosis
The patient can be considered to have a normal glucose profile; no additional testing is needed
The patient can be diagnosed with impaired glucose tolerance; no additional testing is needed
The glucose tests should be repeated after 12 hours of fasting

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antibody testing (for glutamic-acid decarboxylase or anti-islet cell antibodies) can be used to clarify the cause of hyperglycemia when a patient has features that could be consistent with a diagnosis of type 1 diabetes.

B) INCORRECT:

A fasting glucose level of 100 to 125 mg/dL and a plasma glucose level of 140 to 199 mg/dL, two hours after oral glucose loading, are consistent with prediabetes. The range of glycated hemoglobin levels that is diagnostic of prediabetes is subject to debate, but the American Diabetes Association guidance is 5.7% to 6.4%.

C) INCORRECT:

A fasting glucose level of 100 to 125 mg/dL and a plasma glucose level of 140 to 199 mg/dL, two hours after oral glucose loading, are consistent with prediabetes. The range of glycated hemoglobin levels that is diagnostic of prediabetes is subject to debate, but the American Diabetes Association guidance is 5.7% to 6.4%.

D) CORRECT:

A fasting glucose level of 100 to 125 mg/dL and a plasma glucose level of 140 to 199 mg/dL two hours after oral glucose loading are consistent with prediabetes. The range of glycated hemoglobin levels diagnostic of prediabetes is subject to debate, but the American Diabetes Association guidance is 5.7% to 6.4%. The diagnostic cut-off point for diabetes mellitus is an eight-hour fasting plasma glucose ≥126 mg/dL. The diagnosis requires confirmation by the same test or any of the other tests. The first three measurements appear to identify different groups of patients with diabetes or prediabetes, yet all tests identify patients at risk for adverse sequelae.

Key learning point: Impaired glucose tolerance can be diagnosed if the glucose level 2 hours after a 75-g glucose load is between 140 and 199 mg/dL.

E) INCORRECT:

A fasting glucose level of 100 to 125 mg/dL and a plasma glucose level of 140 to 199 mg/dL, two hours after oral glucose loading, are consistent with prediabetes. The range of glycated hemoglobin levels that is diagnostic of prediabetes is subject to debate, but the American Diabetes Association guidance is 5.7% to 6.4%.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with well-controlled asthma presents with a fasting blood glucose level of 132 mg/dL and a glycated hemoglobin value of 7.5%. Body mass index (BMI) is 27 kg/m2. He receives a diagnosis of new-onset type 2 diabetes and is instructed in diet and exercise. He returns 6 months later and reports adherence to dietary and exercise recommendations. His weight and BMI are unchanged, and his glycated hemoglobin level is 8.0%. He is taking inhaled fluticasone daily, plus a short-acting beta-agonist inhaler as needed. He has no allergies, and his physical examination is normal. His serum creatinine level is normal, and there is no albuminuria. What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists (e.g., liraglutide) have been shown to have a variety of benefits beyond glucose lowering, including a reduced risk of cardiovascular events, delayed progression of diabetic kidney disease, and weight loss. However, because of their high cost, these agents are generally not considered first-line therapy unless metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated. Given accumulating evidence on the nonglycemic benefits of these agents, guidelines currently suggest incorporating GLP-1 receptor agonists into the glucose-lowering regimens of patients for whom the nonglycemic benefits are particularly desirable (e.g., those with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease or at high cardiovascular risk). This patient does not fit into that category.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhaled glucocorticoids at standard doses for asthma do not generally result in steroid-induced diabetes; if this patient’s asthma is well controlled on inhaled fluticasone, that medication should be continued.

C) INCORRECT:

Lifestyle modifications (eating a balanced diet, engaging in physical activity, and aiming to lose weight, when indicated) are integral to managing type 2 diabetes. However, if the patient’s blood glucose and glycated hemoglobin levels do not respond sufficiently to a reasonable trial of lifestyle modification, pharmacotherapy should be initiated.

D) INCORRECT:

Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) cause weight gain, may result in hypoglycemia, and lack evidence for nonglycemic benefits. Therefore, despite their low cost, they are generally not considered first-line treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Metformin is generally the preferred initial agent for treating new-onset type 2 diabetes (in the absence of drug intolerance or contraindications to its use, such as renal impairment or uncompensated heart failure). Metformin is safe and effective, is not associated with weight gain or hypoglycemia, and may reduce the risk of cardiovascular events and cancers.

Key learning point: In the absence of contraindications, the recommended first-line treatments for patients with new-onset type 2 diabetes are lifestyle modification and metformin.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and obesity (BMI, 36) presents to discuss weight-loss options. His glycated hemoglobin level is 7.3% on metformin 1000 mg twice daily and sitagliptin 100 mg daily. He has never been in a formal weight-loss program but expresses interest. You suggest that he enroll in a local behavioral weight-loss program that provides weekly group and individual counseling and that emphasizes caloric restriction to 1500–1800 calories daily and an average of at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise daily. Which one of the following outcomes can this patient reasonably expect if he loses 7% to 10% of his body weight within one year after starting the recommended program?

choices.text: Reduced use of prescription diabetes medications
Decrease in physical quality of life

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bone mineral density (BMD) tends to decline in patients who lose weight, an effect that is most marked after bariatric surgery. There are many reasons for this decline, including lower mechanical loading of the bone, malabsorption of vitamin D and calcium, and possibly hormonal changes; in addition, the presence of less soft tissue may artificially lower the BMD obtained by a standard dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry scan. With diet-induced weight loss, there is a loss of BMD, particularly at the hip, but this is quite small in magnitude. In the Look AHEAD trial, the adjudicated fracture rates were no different between the two groups.

B) INCORRECT:

Obesity is a strong risk factor for urinary incontinence. Weight loss may help reduce this risk and, in some studies, has been associated with improvement and resolution of incontinence.

C) CORRECT:

Weight loss in individuals with overweight or obesity is associated with a multitude of health benefits, including glycemic control in those with type 2 diabetes. In the Look AHEAD trial, more than 5000 patients with type 2 diabetes and a BMI ≥25 were randomized to receive either an intensive lifestyle intervention that focused on increased physical activity and caloric restriction or routine diabetes support and education. At one year, the intervention group lost significantly more body weight than the control group (mean loss, 8.6% vs. 0.7%) and had substantial improvements in glycemic control despite a significant decrease in the proportion of individuals using diabetes medications. They also had improvements in systolic blood pressure, physical quality of life, sleep apnea, sexual function, and depressive symptoms. In addition, fewer individuals in the intervention group than the control group had to start medications for hypertension and dyslipidemia.

Key learning point: In adults with type 2 diabetes and a BMI ≥25, intensive lifestyle interventions that result in a loss of 7% to 10% of body weight have been shown to lead to a host of health benefits, including long-term improvements in glycemic control and reduced use of diabetes medications.

D) INCORRECT:

In the Look AHEAD trial, more than 5000 patients with type 2 diabetes and a BMI ≥25 were randomized to receive either an intensive lifestyle intervention that focused on increased physical activity and caloric restriction or routine diabetes support and education. At one year, the intervention group lost significantly more body weight than the control group (mean loss, 8.6% vs. 0.7%) and had substantial improvements in glycemic control despite a significant decrease in the proportion of individuals using diabetes medications. They also had improvements in systolic blood pressure, physical quality of life, sleep apnea, sexual function, and depressive symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

There is no increased risk of nephrolithiasis with weight loss. However, cholelithiasis is common after the rapid weight loss induced by bariatric surgery, and there is also an increased risk with very-low-calorie diets (<800 calories daily). The data on cholelithiasis after moderate weight loss (defined as 7%–10% of body weight within a year) are less clear, with some studies suggesting an increased risk of gallstone disease even in this setting.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents for follow-up. In the 6 months since her last visit, she has lost 4.5 kg of body weight through diet and exercise. Medications are metformin, lisinopril, and multivitamin. Her blood pressure is 123/74 mm Hg, and her BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. A fasting lipid panel reveals the following results:


Total cholesterol
189 mg/dL


LDL cholesterol
95 mg/dL


HDL cholesterol
43 mg/dL


Triglycerides
255 mg/dL


Which one of the following treatments is recommended to minimize this patient’s long-term cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Icosapent ethyl effectively reduces triglyceride concentrations, especially in individuals with severe hypertriglyceridemia (>500 mg/dL). Studies have shown cardiovascular benefit when icosapent ethyl is added to a statin in patients with hypertriglyceridemia who are at high cardiovascular risk (due to established ASCVD or to type 2 diabetes with at least one additional ASCVD risk factor). Current guidelines therefore suggest considering icosapent ethyl as an addition to a statin in this patient population. However, starting a statin should take precedence.

B) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe is a second-line lipid-lowering agent that can be used for additional atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk reduction in patients who do not achieve target LDL reduction with the maximally tolerated dose of first-line therapy. This patient's LDL cholesterol is within the reference range.

C) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

E) CORRECT:

Current cholesterol treatment guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) outline four “statin benefit” groups for whom atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk reduction clearly outweighs the risk for adverse events. One of those groups is patients aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of their estimated risk for ASCVD. These patients should receive at least moderate-intensity statin therapy. If they have multiple ASCVD risk factors, they should receive a high-intensity statin, with the goal of reducing LDL-cholesterol levels by ≥50% to a target LDL-cholesterol level of <70 mg/dL. This patient should receive a moderate-intensity statin.

Key learning point: Regardless of estimated risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, primary prevention in patients aged 40 to 75 years with type 2 diabetes should include at least moderate-intensity statin therapy.

questions.text: A previously healthy 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for 6 hours. Over the past 6 weeks, she has also had increased frequency of urination, and she has been drinking more water than usual. She has lost 6 kg (13 lb) over the same time period despite having a good appetite. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. She appears lethargic. Physical examination shows deep and labored breathing and dry mucous membranes. The abdomen is soft, and there is diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Urine dipstick is positive for ketones and glucose. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

DKA causes a metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap. In response to the acidosis, patients typically exhibit a deep and labored breathing pattern (Kussmaul breathing) to provide respiratory compensation, as seen with this patient. The higher depth and rate of breaths results in an increase in carbon dioxide exhalation and subsequently a decrease in arterial pCO2 (compensatory respiratory alkalosis).

B) INCORRECT:

DKA causes metabolic acidosis, which leads to decreased arterial blood pH (not increased). The insulin deficiency in DKA increases lipolysis, resulting in more free fatty acids. In the liver, free fatty acids are converted to ketones, two of which are acidic (acetoacetic acid and beta-hydroxybutyric acid).

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with DKA typically present with hypovolemia and severe dehydration rather than excess water retention. In DKA, hyperglycemia leads to osmotic diuresis which typically manifests as polyuria and polydipsia, as seen in this patient. The osmotic diuresis eventually leads to hypovolemia, which usually presents with dry mucous membranes, hypotension, and/or tachycardia.

D) INCORRECT:

In DKA, serum glucose concentration is increased due to insulin deficiency. However, serum glucose rarely exceeds 600 mg/dL because ketogenesis (due to insulin deficiency) usually begins at lower glucose concentrations and causes symptoms earlier. A hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS), on the other hand, does not involve ketogenesis (there are residual insulin levels that suppresses lipolysis and ketogenesis) and usually presents with serum glucose levels ≥ 600 mg/dL. The ketonuria and hyperventilation in this patient argue against HHS.

HHS typically occurs in patients with type 2 diabetes, as the condition involves a relative insulin deficiency rather than the absolute insulin deficiency seen in type 1 diabetes. However, DKA can also occur in the advanced stages of type 2 diabetes, when beta cell function has declined so much that insulin levels are negligible.

E) CORRECT:

DKA typically occurs in individuals with undiagnosed, untreated type 1 diabetes mellitus or treatment failure in known diabetics. Absolute insulin deficiency results in hyperglycemia and hyperosmolality. As a result, K+ shifts along with water from inside cells to the extracellular space and is lost in the urine. Moreover, the insulin that normally promotes cellular potassium uptake is absent in DKA, compounding the problem. A total body K+ deficit, therefore, develops in the body, although serum K+ may be normal or even paradoxically elevated.
questions.hint: This patient presents with acute abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, lethargy, and a 6-week history of polydipsia and weight loss. Together with Kussmaul breathing (deep and labored breathing), dehydration (dry mucous membranes), glucosuria, and ketonuria, these symptoms indicate diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which causes an anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the office because of increased frequency of micturition over the past month. He has also been waking up frequently during the night to urinate. Over the past 2 months, he has had a 3.2-kg (7-lb) weight loss. He is in the 40th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, creatinine, and osmolality are within the reference range. Urinalysis discloses 1+ glucose. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Insulin resistance is a pathophysiological feature of type 2 diabetes mellitus, which typically develops in individuals with obesity, a genetic disposition (first-degree relative with diabetes), and features of metabolic syndrome. Affected individuals are usually > 40 years old, though onset can also rarely occur in teenagers with obesity. Since this patient is young, has no family history of serious illness, and is of normal weight, type 2 diabetes mellitus is unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Renal resistance to ADH is seen in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) and is caused by defects in ADH receptors. These defects can be due to drugs, hypokalemia, or renal disease. Lack of response to ADH impairs the kidney's ability to concentrate urine, resulting in polyuria (> 3 L/day) with diluted urine, nocturia, and polydipsia. Urine osmolality is typically < 300 mOsmol/kg, and is often < 100 mOsmol/kg. Since urine osmolality in this patient is normal, nephrogenic DI can be ruled out.
Image Description:

The binding of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) to V2 receptors (R) promotes the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels into the apical cell membranes of principal cells in the renal collecting duct, thereby facilitating free water reabsorption and concentration of urine.

In diabetes insipidus (DI), this mechanism is impaired either due to reduced pituitary ADH secretion (central DI) or defective renal ADH receptors (nephrogenic DI), in both cases reducing the insertion of aquaporin-2 channels. This impairs the ability of the kidneys to concentrate urine and results in the production of large amounts of dilute urine (up to 15 L/day).

C) CORRECT:

Absolute insulin deficiency is the underlying pathology of type 1 diabetes mellitus, caused by autoimmune-mediated destruction of pancreatic β cells. The resulting elevation of blood glucose levels leads to a range of symptoms, typically including polyuria, nocturia, polydipsia, and increased appetite. Nonspecific symptoms of fatigue, weight loss, and an increased tendency to infections (e.g., skin infections, UTIs) are also common. The symptoms usually develop within days to a few weeks or manifest suddenly with diabetic ketoacidosis. While glucosuria detected via urine dipstick is suggestive of diabetes mellitus, the diagnosis is confirmed through an oral glucose tolerance test or a random blood glucose level ≥ 200 mg/dL.

D) INCORRECT:

Compulsive water intake is a feature of primary polydipsia, which is a condition seen in individuals with psychiatric diseases (e.g., schizophrenia, obsessive-compulsive disorder). It is characterized by a compulsion to drink large amounts of fluid despite the absence of thirst, resulting in polyuria with low urine osmolality and hyponatremia. Since the patient's parents report no unusual behavior, and urine osmolality and serum electrolyte levels are normal, primary polydipsia can be ruled out.

E) INCORRECT:

An inadequate ADH secretion is seen in individuals with central diabetes insipidus and is caused by an absent or insufficient hypothalamic synthesis of ADH. The lack of ADH impairs the kidney's ability to concentrate urine, resulting in polyuria (> 3 L/day) with diluted urine, nocturia, and polydipsia. Urine osmolality is typically < 300 mOsmol/kg, and is often < 100 mOsmol/kg. Since urine osmolality in this patient is normal, inadequate ADH secretion can be ruled out.
questions.hint: Polyuria, nocturia, and weight loss in an adolescent with 1+ glucose on urine dipstick are suggestive of type 1 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-month history of fatigue and increased urination. The patient reports that he has been drinking more than usual because he is constantly thirsty. He has intermittent episodes of blurred vision. He had elevated blood pressure at his previous visit but is otherwise healthy. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 93 kg (205 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. His pulse is 75/min and his blood pressure is 144/94 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin A1c
7.1%


Serum



 Glucose
220 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


 Total cholesterol
270 mg/dL


Urine



 Glucose
2+


 Albumin:creatinine ratio


280 mg/g (N < 30)


In addition to metformin therapy and counseling for lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: No additional management is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

All patients with T2DM aged 40–75 years should receive lipid-lowering treatment regardless of baseline lipid levels to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. However, statins are the first-line therapy, not fibrates. Fibrates are used in the treatment of severe hypertriglyceridemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Insulin therapy should be considered in patients with newly diagnosed T2DM who present with symptoms of hyperglycemia (as seen here), signs of a continued catabolic state (e.g., weight loss), initial glucose ≥ 300 mg/dL, or HbA1c > 10%. However, a basal insulin regimen with long-acting insulins (e.g., glargine insulin, NPH insulin) should be started initially. Rapid-acting insulins (e.g., lispro) are added to basal insulin regimens when glycemic control is not achieved with basal insulin alone.

C) CORRECT:

An increased urine albumin:creatinine ratio (UACR) indicates albuminuria (UACR of 30–300 mg/g indicates microalbuminuria). While all first-line antihypertensive agents are appropriate for adults with diabetes and hypertension, an ACE inhibitor (ACEI) or an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is the antihypertensive of choice if the patient has albuminuria as these drugs have been shown to have a renoprotective effect in this patient group. The blood pressure target should be individualized; for patients with a high 10-year ASCVD risk, < 130/80 mm Hg is an appropriate treatment goal if safely attained. The American Diabetes Association also recommends prescribing SGLT-2 inhibitors for renoprotection in patients with albuminuria.

In addition to lifestyle modifications, metformin, an ACEI (or ARB), and an SGLT-2 inhibitor, this patient should also be initiated on statin therapy, which is indicated in all patients aged 40–75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of lipid levels.

Additionally, a short course of basal insulin therapy should be considered for patients with symptomatic hyperglycemia (as seen here), signs of a continued catabolic state (e.g., weight loss), initial glucose ≥ 300 mg/dL, or HbA1c > 10%.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspirin therapy should be considered for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) in patients 40–59 years of age with a high 10-year ASCVD risk (≥ 10%) and a low risk of bleeding. In patients > 60 years of age, aspirin is not recommended for the primary prevention of ASCVD.

E) INCORRECT:

Given this patient's comorbidities, additional management besides lifestyle modifications and monotherapy with metformin is required.
questions.hint: Random plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL in a patient with symptoms of hyperglycemia (i.e., fatigue, polyuria, polydipsia, blurred vision) is consistent with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Comorbidities are common in patients with T2DM and should be addressed.

questions.text: A 36-year-old Native American man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. The patient is married, has 4 children, and works as a software engineer. His father died in a car accident and his mother has coronary artery disease. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs.
