He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lbs); his BMI is 28 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 121/78 mm Hg on the right arm and 122/80 mm Hg on the left. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the clinician regarding health maintenance at this visit?

choices.text: “I would like to perform a fecal occult blood test on a stool sample.”
“I suggest we do a 24-hour blood pressure measurement to evaluate you for hypertension.”
“I would like to discuss screening options for high blood sugar with you today.”
“At this time, there is nothing to worry about. Have a great day.”
“Please fill out a short questionnaire about addictions before you leave today.”

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While there is a correlation between higher rates of colorectal cancer and Native American ancestry, the causes of this are complex and not fully established. Inequities in access to colorectal screening may be the primary driver for this disparity. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Since this patient is only 36 years of age and does not have significant risk factors for colorectal cancer, screening is not currently indicated. In addition, it is inappropriate to tell this patient he has a high risk of malignancy without providing context, as it will likely increase patient anxiety.

B) INCORRECT:

While there is a correlation between higher rates of hypertension and Native American ancestry, it has not yet been established whether this is a socially determined health risk (e.g., diet), a genetic predisposition, or the result of confounders (e.g., inadequate health care availability). At this time, there is no recommendation for intensified screening for hypertension in Native American persons. Furthermore, there is no reason to suspect hypertension in this patient who has normal blood pressure measurements.

C) CORRECT:

The American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommends screening for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) in individuals ≥ 35 years of age regardless of risk factors and in individuals < 35 years of age with either overweight or obesity and ≥ 1 additional risk factor for T2DM (e.g., first-degree family history, certain race or ethnicity, hypertension). The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for T2DM in asymptomatic individuals 35–70 years of age with overweight obesity. As per both guidelines, screening this patient for T2DM is recommended.

Native American individuals have the highest prevalence of T2DM among racial and ethnic groups in the United States as a result of genetic and socioeconomic factors. While smoking, diet, and alcohol use are risk factors that are generally assessed in routine health maintenance examinations, social and genetic determinants of health are less commonly assessed, often because of poor access to care and provider negligence of minority groups. Poor screening consequently contributes to a higher burden of disease among various racial and ethnic minorities (e.g., African Americans, Hispanics, and Asian Americans).

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation is normal as he has no complaints and a normal physical examination. However, Native American ancestry is associated with an increased risk for certain conditions, and patients within this population should receive the corresponding counseling and screening necessary. Furthermore, it is recommended that, prior to the end of the visit, the clinician reminds the patient to schedule an appropriate follow-up appointment.

E) INCORRECT:

While recreational drug and alcohol use are a matter of concern in Native American communities, it is inappropriate to assume an addiction from this patient's race alone. The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends that all adults should be screened for excessive alcohol use, but since this patient reports not drinking alcohol or taking recreational drugs, additional screening is unwarranted. Moreover, clinicians should approach potentially sensitive topics delicately and avoid being confrontational by opening with a term like “addiction” and requesting that the patient fill out a questionnaire before obtaining consent to be screened.
questions.hint: Social determinants of health are an important factor to consider during routine health maintenance examinations.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old overweight man presents for his annual check-up. For the past three months, he has had pronounced thirst, some episodes of blurred vision, and occasional numbness in his feet. He denies polyuria or significant weight changes. He does not engage in regular physical activity, and his diet is high in processed foods and sugar-sweetened beverages. He has no known family history of autoimmune disorders. His BMI is 31. Physical examination reveals acanthosis nigricans around the posterior neck (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Glucose, fasting
7.2 mmol/L
3.5 - 6.5 mmol/L


Hemoglobin A1c
6.7 %
4.7 - 5.6 %



Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) is a monogenic diabetes form usually presenting in younger individuals with a family history. The patient's age, obesity, and acanthosis nigricans suggest insulin resistance, not MODY. His lifestyle factors and laboratory findings further support a metabolic syndrome etiology rather than a genetic defect.

B) INCORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is an autoimmune condition typically presenting in younger, lean individuals with symptoms like polyuria and weight loss. The patient is 59 years old and overweight, which is inconsistent with type 1 diabetes. Acanthosis nigricans and the absence of a family history of autoimmune disorders further reduce the likelihood of this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Gestational diabetes mellitus occurs during pregnancy, making it impossible for a 59-year-old man. Although the patient shows signs of insulin resistance, his demographic details and lack of pregnancy history exclude this diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

The patient's age, obesity, and sedentary lifestyle are key risk factors for type 2 diabetes mellitus. Acanthosis nigricans, observed on examination, indicates insulin resistance, a hallmark of this condition. Laboratory findings support the diagnosis: a fasting glucose level of 7.2 mmol/L and a hemoglobin A1c of 6.7% both exceed diagnostic thresholds. These findings reflect progressive insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency, leading to hyperglycemia characteristic of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Key learning point: A fasting plasma glucose level of 7.0 mmol/L or higher, or an A1c of 6.5% or higher, is diagnostic of diabetes, and in adults, this is most commonly type 2 diabetes.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man returns for routine follow-up. He has a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and mild hyperlipidemia controlled with a statin. He checks his capillary glucose once daily and reports a few mild episodes of sweating and tremor relieved by juice over the last six months. His most recent laboratory evaluation reveals a hemoglobin A1c of 7.9% (reference: <5.7% for non-diabetic). Physical examination is normal, with no signs of peripheral neuropathy or nephropathy. He is concerned about reducing his risk of long-term complications without experiencing low blood sugar.
Which of the following best reflects the recommended glycemic target for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An A1c target of less than 6.0% may increase hypoglycemia risk, especially in patients with existing mild hypoglycemic episodes. This aggressive target is more suitable for younger or newly diagnosed patients with minimal hypoglycemia risk, not for a 60-year-old with type 2 diabetes and hypoglycemic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

A target of less than 8.0% is suitable for patients with advanced complications, severe comorbidities, or frequent severe hypoglycemia. This patient, with mild hypoglycemic episodes and no significant complications, benefits from a stricter target to reduce long-term risks.

C) INCORRECT:

A target of less than 6.5% is appropriate for younger patients with a short diabetes duration and minimal hypoglycemia risk. However, this patient is 60 years old with mild hypoglycemic episodes, making a less stringent target more suitable to avoid increasing hypoglycemia risk.

D) CORRECT:

The American Diabetes Association recommends a hemoglobin A1c target of less than 7.0% for most nonpregnant adults with type 2 diabetes. This target reduces the risk of microvascular complications, such as retinopathy, nephropathy, and neuropathy, while minimizing hypoglycemia risk. It balances optimizing long-term outcomes with avoiding overtreatment, especially in patients prone to hypoglycemia. Individualized management considers patient age, comorbidities, and diabetes duration.

Key learning point: The general target for Hemoglobin A1c in patients with type 2 diabetes is <7.0% to reduce the risk of complications while minimizing the risk of hypoglycemia.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman presents for evaluation 8 weeks postpartum after delivering her second child. During her pregnancy, she required insulin for gestational diabetes. Her mother and sister have type 2 diabetes. She has resumed moderate physical activity and dietary modifications but is concerned about her risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Her BMI is 28 kg/m2 (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Glucose, fasting
6.2 mmol/L
3.5 - 6.5 mmol/L


Glucose tolerance test




 2 hour
8.5 mmol/L
< 8.6 mmol/L



She asks if there is anything more she can do to prevent diabetes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management to reduce her risk of progression to type 2 diabetes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione, improves peripheral insulin sensitivity but is primarily used in established type 2 diabetes. Its role in primary prevention is limited, especially in postpartum patients with borderline glycemic abnormalities. Adverse effects, such as weight gain and fluid retention, are concerns, particularly given the patient's BMI of 28 kg/m2. Current guidelines favor lifestyle modifications and, in some cases, metformin over thiazolidinediones for diabetes prevention.

B) CORRECT:

Metformin effectively reduces the progression from prediabetes to type 2 diabetes, especially in individuals with a history of gestational diabetes and a family history of diabetes. It works by decreasing hepatic gluconeogenesis and enhancing peripheral insulin sensitivity, improving glycemic control. The Diabetes Prevention Program demonstrated that metformin, combined with lifestyle modifications, significantly lowers the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. In patients with impaired fasting glucose and borderline glucose tolerance, metformin can mitigate metabolic risks associated with insulin resistance.

Key learning point: Metformin is recommended for individuals at high risk of developing type 2 diabetes, particularly those with a history of gestational diabetes and a strong family history of diabetes.

C) INCORRECT:

Sitagliptin, a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitor, enhances incretin hormones to improve glycemic control in type 2 diabetes. However, it lacks evidence for preventing diabetes in individuals without overt hyperglycemia. Lifestyle modifications remain the primary prevention strategy, with metformin considered in high-risk cases. DPP-4 inhibitors like sitagliptin are not appropriate for proactive management in individuals without established diabetes.

D) INCORRECT:

Acarbose, an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor, delays carbohydrate digestion, reducing postprandial glucose levels. It is mainly used in established type 2 diabetes, not as an initial prevention strategy. Although it can reduce diabetes progression in impaired glucose tolerance, its routine use in postpartum women with gestational diabetes history is unsupported. Gastrointestinal side effects may limit adherence, especially with mild glycemic abnormalities.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old overweight man presents with several months of increased thirst and frequent urination. His BMI is 33 kg/m2. He reports no significant comorbidities and is open to dietary modifications and daily exercise. Repeat tests confirm type 2 diabetes mellitus. Laboratory studies show normal renal function (see lab result).


Test
Result
Normal Values


Glucose, fasting
8.8 mmol/L
3.5 - 6.5 mmol/L


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to achieve glycemic control?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The sulfonylurea glipizide stimulates insulin release but does not address insulin resistance, a key issue in type 2 diabetes. It can cause hypoglycemia and weight gain, which is undesirable in overweight patients. Metformin, which improves insulin sensitivity and has a favorable weight profile, is more appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Pioglitazone enhances insulin sensitivity but is associated with weight gain, fluid retention, and increased heart failure risk. These side effects are disadvantageous for overweight patients. Metformin, combined with lifestyle changes, is preferred for initial management due to its weight-neutral effects and efficacy in improving insulin sensitivity.

C) CORRECT:

Metformin is the first-line pharmacologic treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus. It reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis and improves insulin sensitivity, effectively lowering fasting blood glucose levels with a low risk of hypoglycemia. Combining metformin with lifestyle modifications, such as dietary changes and regular physical activity, addresses insulin resistance and aids in glycemic control. This approach also benefits cardiovascular and metabolic health, particularly in overweight patients.

Key learning point: For newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes, the first-line treatment includes lifestyle modifications (diet and exercise) and metformin to achieve glycemic control.

D) INCORRECT:

Insulin therapy is reserved for severe hyperglycemia or metabolic decompensation. This patient has modestly elevated glucose levels and is open to lifestyle changes. Initial management typically involves lifestyle modifications and oral agents like metformin, rather than insulin.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man presents with dizziness, trembling, and confusion after intense workouts. He has a 5-year history of type 1 diabetes and is training for a half marathon. He takes multiple daily injections of insulin, including a once-daily long-acting formulation and a rapid-acting form with meals, and monitors his blood glucose frequently. His pre-exercise blood glucose is typically near 5.6 mmol/L (reference range 3.9–5.8 mmol/L). He has tried small carbohydrate snacks before workouts but still experiences occasional hypoglycemia. Physical examination between episodes is normal, and he has no microvascular or macrovascular disease. He wants to continue his exercise routine without frequent hypoglycemia.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy?

choices.text: Maintain current insulin doses and add extra carbohydrates immediately before exercise
Stop long-acting insulin on days when exercise is planned
Increase the long-acting insulin dose to compensate for workout-induced stress
Reduce the rapid-acting insulin dose before exercise while continuing usual long-acting insulin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adding carbohydrates before exercise can buffer against hypoglycemia, but this patient has tried this without success. Exercise increases insulin sensitivity, causing a relative hyperinsulinemic state. Maintaining current insulin doses does not address this, and carbohydrates may not be absorbed quickly enough to counteract increased glucose utilization during intense exercise.

B) INCORRECT:

Long-acting insulin provides essential basal coverage, suppressing hepatic gluconeogenesis and maintaining metabolic stability. Omitting it risks hyperglycemia and diabetic ketoacidosis. Adjustments to rapid-acting insulin or carbohydrate intake are preferred for managing exercise-induced hypoglycemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Exercise enhances insulin sensitivity, increasing hypoglycemia risk. Increasing long-acting insulin would raise basal insulin levels, worsening hypoglycemia. Management should focus on adjusting insulin around exercise, not increasing basal insulin, as exercise-induced stress does not typically cause hyperglycemia in well-trained individuals.

D) CORRECT:

In type 1 diabetes, exercise increases insulin sensitivity, enhancing glucose uptake by muscles and risking hypoglycemia. Rapid-acting insulin peaks during exercise, so reducing its dose before exercise mitigates hypoglycemia risk while maintaining basal insulin coverage with long-acting insulin. This approach balances insulin availability with exercise-induced glucose disposal, reducing reliance on carbohydrate supplementation.

Key learning point: To prevent exercise-induced hypoglycemia in type 1 diabetes, consider reducing the meal-time insulin dose prior to exercise while maintaining basal insulin coverage.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with type 2 diabetes for seven years has stable glycemic control without symptoms. Which measure best prevents diabetic complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 monitoring is relevant for diabetic patients on long-term metformin therapy due to potential absorption interference. However, it does not directly prevent primary diabetic complications like retinopathy, nephropathy, or cardiovascular issues, which are the main concerns in diabetes management.

B) INCORRECT:

A screening treadmill test evaluates inducible myocardial ischemia in symptomatic patients, not as a preventive measure for diabetic complications. In asymptomatic patients with stable glycemic control, routine stress testing does not reduce the risk of microvascular complications such as retinopathy, nephropathy, or neuropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Daily low-dose aspirin therapy is considered for reducing cardiovascular events in high-risk patients. However, this patient is asymptomatic with stable glycemic control and no clear evidence of high cardiovascular risk. Aspirin does not prevent microvascular complications like retinopathy, neuropathy, or nephropathy, which are major concerns in diabetes.

D) CORRECT:

Annual dilated fundus examinations are crucial for secondary prevention in patients with type 2 diabetes. They allow early detection of diabetic retinopathy, a common microvascular complication that can lead to vision loss. Dilation of the pupil enables a thorough evaluation of the retinal vasculature, identifying microaneurysms, hemorrhages, exudates, and neovascularization before visual symptoms occur. Early detection allows for timely interventions to prevent or slow retinal damage, as recommended by the American Diabetes Association. This measure significantly reduces the risk of permanent visual impairment and helps maintain quality of life in diabetic patients.

Key learning point: Secondary prevention for diabetes includes screening for early detection and chronic disease management to prevent complications.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy presents with progressive thirst, frequent hunger, and frequent urination over the last month. He has lost 4 kg despite an increased appetite. He denies abdominal pain or blurred vision and has no significant past medical history. On examination, he appears thin with a BMI at the 20th percentile. There is no evidence of acanthosis nigricans (see lab results).

Blood pressure
110/65 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Glucose, random
15 mmol/L
3.9 - 5.5 mmol/L


Hemoglobin A1C
11.2 %
4.7 - 5.6 %


C-peptide
Low for the degree of hyperglycemia
Low for the degree of hyperglycemia



Which of the following best explains the underlying mechanism of his hyperglycemia?

choices.text: Genetic defect in glucose sensing by pancreatic beta cells
Autoimmune beta-cell destruction leading to absolute insulin deficiency
Excess insulin secretion from an insulinoma
Obesity-related insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Genetic defects in glucose sensing, seen in monogenic diabetes, result in mild hyperglycemia due to impaired insulin secretion response. This patient has significant hyperglycemia, weight loss, and low C-peptide levels, indicating a loss of beta cell function rather than impaired glucose sensing. The findings are inconsistent with monogenic diabetes.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss, along with elevated glucose and hemoglobin A1C levels, suggest type 1 diabetes mellitus. The low C-peptide level indicates an absolute insulin deficiency due to autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells. This destruction impairs glucose uptake in peripheral tissues and allows continued hepatic gluconeogenesis, resulting in hyperglycemia. Recognizing this mechanism is essential for understanding hyperglycemia in pediatric patients.

Key learning point: In children presenting with hyperglycemia and symptoms of polydipsia, polyphagia, and polyuria, decreased insulin production due to type 1 diabetes mellitus is the most likely cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Insulinomas cause recurrent hypoglycemia due to excess insulin secretion, leading to elevated insulin and C-peptide levels. This patient has hyperglycemia and a low C-peptide level, indicating an insulin deficiency rather than excess. The clinical presentation aligns with autoimmune beta-cell destruction, not an insulinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Obesity-related insulin resistance is typical in type 2 diabetes, characterized by decreased insulin sensitivity and relative insulin deficiency. However, this patient has a low BMI and recent weight loss, inconsistent with obesity-related insulin resistance. The low C-peptide level further indicates an absolute insulin deficiency, not the hyperinsulinemia seen in early type 2 diabetes.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old boy presents with multiple episodes of hypoglycemia, especially in the late afternoon and early evening, over the past several days. He was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes and started on insulin therapy two weeks ago. His recent glucose logs show values around 60 mg/dL before dinner. His parents report he appears less thirsty and urinates less frequently. Physical examination is normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Switch to a premixed 70/30 insulin regimen
Reduce the total daily insulin dose

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In type 1 diabetes, insulin is essential to prevent metabolic decompensation. Even brief insulin interruption can lead to diabetic ketoacidosis. The patient's mild hypoglycemia suggests the need for dose adjustment rather than cessation. Reduced thirst and urination indicate a biochemical state not severe enough to warrant a 24-hour insulin suspension.

B) INCORRECT:

Sulfonylureas stimulate pancreatic β cells to release insulin and are used in type 2 diabetes. In type 1 diabetes, autoimmune destruction of β cells leads to absolute insulin deficiency, making sulfonylureas ineffective. The patient's hypoglycemia suggests an overly aggressive insulin regimen, and adding a sulfonylurea would increase hypoglycemic risk without addressing the underlying pathophysiology.

C) INCORRECT:

A premixed 70/30 insulin regimen combines intermediate-acting and short-acting insulins in a fixed ratio, which may simplify insulin delivery in some cases. However, it offers limited flexibility in dose adjustment, crucial for pediatric type 1 diabetes where insulin sensitivity and carbohydrate intake vary. The fixed proportions prevent fine-tuning of basal and prandial insulin needs, and the peak action times may not align with the child's meal schedule, potentially worsening hypoglycemia.

D) CORRECT:

In newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes, patients may experience a honeymoon period where residual pancreatic β-cell function improves, leading to endogenous insulin secretion. This results in lower insulin requirements, and maintaining the initial insulin dose can increase hypoglycemia risk. The patient's low pre-dinner glucose levels and decreased polyuria and polydipsia suggest this phase. Reducing the total daily insulin dose aligns with the need to adjust therapy based on endogenous insulin production, ensuring better glycemic control and minimizing hypoglycemic events.

Key learning point: In newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes patients, the honeymoon period can cause unexpected hypoglycemia due to temporary endogenous insulin production, necessitating adjustments in insulin therapy.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl is brought to the clinic due to an 8 kg weight gain over the past year. She rarely participates in sports and spends most of her free time playing video games. She has no significant past medical history and no concerning symptoms. Her BMI is at the 96th percentile for her age. Physical examination reveals excess adipose tissue but is otherwise normal. Her mother is concerned about potential health risks.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Structured diet and daily exercise regimen
Orlistat to reduce intestinal fat absorption

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In managing pediatric obesity, the primary approach involves lifestyle modifications to address the imbalance between caloric intake and expenditure. A structured diet emphasizes nutritional education and meal planning, focusing on reducing high-calorie, nutrient-poor foods while promoting fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean proteins. Coupled with a daily exercise regimen, this strategy enhances energy expenditure, cardiovascular health, and insulin sensitivity. Involving both the patient and family in behavior-based interventions supports adherence and long-term success. This non-pharmacologic approach is prioritized in children to mitigate immediate and future health risks associated with obesity.

Key learning point: Lifestyle modification, including dietary changes and increased physical activity, is the first-line management for pediatric obesity.

B) INCORRECT:

Endocrine disorders causing weight gain often present with additional symptoms like growth deceleration or unusual fat distribution. In this patient, isolated obesity with a sedentary lifestyle history does not suggest an endocrine cause, making extensive hormonal testing unnecessary as an initial step.

C) INCORRECT:

Bariatric surgery is reserved for adolescents with severe obesity and comorbidities, not for a 12-year-old with a BMI at the 96th percentile and no complications. Initial management should focus on lifestyle modifications, including diet, exercise, and behavioral interventions, before considering invasive options.

D) INCORRECT:

Orlistat, a lipase inhibitor, reduces dietary fat absorption but is not a first-line treatment for pediatric obesity. Lifestyle modifications, including improved nutrition and physical activity, are prioritized before pharmacotherapy. Orlistat can cause gastrointestinal side effects and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, which are concerning in a growing child.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old G2P1 woman is 28 weeks pregnant and presents to the Outpatient Clinic. She has no prior history of type 1 or type 2 diabetes. Her BMI is 25 kg/m². Physical examination is normal. A 1-hour glucose challenge test (50 g load) shows 9.5 mmol/L (reference <7.8). A subsequent 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test confirms gestational diabetes mellitus. A recent ultrasound shows appropriate fetal growth for gestational age. She is concerned about the impact on her pregnancy, including the possibility of macrosomia and complicated delivery.

Blood pressure
118/72 mm Hg

Which of the following is the most appropriate management step for controlling her blood glucose levels at this stage of her pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metformin is not the standard initial pharmacological treatment for gestational diabetes. Insulin is preferred due to its precise titration and lack of placental transfer. Metformin is considered when insulin is declined, but this patient should first try dietary and exercise interventions.

B) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous insulin therapy is used when lifestyle measures fail to control gestational diabetes. It is reserved for cases where blood glucose levels remain elevated despite dietary and exercise interventions. This patient, with normal fetal growth and no high-risk features, does not require early insulin initiation.

C) CORRECT:

Gestational diabetes mellitus is initially managed with lifestyle modifications, with individualized dietary counseling as the cornerstone. This approach involves regulating carbohydrate intake and planning balanced meals to maintain optimal glycemic control. The goal is to minimize postprandial glucose peaks, preventing fetal hyperinsulinemia and complications like macrosomia. Regular self-monitoring of blood glucose is integrated with dietary adjustments to assess the intervention's effectiveness. Pharmacologic therapy is considered only if these measures fail to achieve target glucose levels.

Key learning point: In the management of gestational diabetes mellitus, dietary modifications are the first-line treatment to help control blood glucose levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Induction at 34 weeks is considered for significant maternal or fetal compromise, such as uncontrolled gestational diabetes with fetal macrosomia. This patient, at 28 weeks with appropriate fetal growth, does not require early delivery. The focus is on glycemic control through diet and exercise.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents for a routine diabetic follow-up. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes, mild retinopathy, and well-controlled hypertension with an ACE inhibitor. He has no major complaints and denies changes in urine color or frequency. He has never had any kidney function tests beyond routine serum labs. There is no pedal edema (see lab results).

Blood pressure
130/78 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Glucose, fasting
5.5 mmol/L
3.5 - 6.5 mmol/L


Creatinine
80 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate screening test to detect early diabetic kidney damage in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio is the preferred test for early detection of diabetic nephropathy, as it identifies microalbuminuria, a marker of early glomerular damage. Microalbuminuria indicates changes in glomerular permeability due to chronic hyperglycemia and hypertension, even when serum creatinine and estimated glomerular filtration rate are normal. Annual screening with this test allows for timely treatment modifications, such as maintaining ACE inhibitor therapy to slow progression. This method is a practical alternative to the 24-hour urine collection, providing accurate and convenient assessment of renal status in diabetic patients.

Key learning point: In patients with type 2 diabetes, the urine albumin/creatinine ratio is recommended annually to screen for early kidney damage, as it is more sensitive than serum creatinine or eGFR for detecting microalbuminuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Quantifying total protein in a 24-hour urine collection is not optimal for early diabetic nephropathy detection. Early kidney damage primarily involves microalbuminuria, which is not detected by total protein assays. The 24-hour method faces challenges like incomplete collection, making it less sensitive to subtle albuminuria increases.

C) INCORRECT:

Estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is a key indicator of renal function but is less effective for early diabetic kidney damage detection. Microalbuminuria, indicating early glomerular changes, often occurs before any decline in eGFR. Normal serum creatinine can lead to a normal eGFR, missing early kidney injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine is used to estimate glomerular filtration rate but is limited in detecting early diabetic kidney damage. In early diabetic nephropathy, hyperfiltration can keep serum creatinine normal despite glomerular injury. Factors like muscle mass and age also affect serum creatinine, reducing its sensitivity as an early marker of renal impairment.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman who is a college student comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of vaginal itching and burning. She reports noticing white vaginal discharge despite daily cleaning of her genital area with a "soap-free, natural" vaginal douche. She is concerned about the possibility of a sexually transmitted infection. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus and is a member of the college swimming team. An intrauterine device was placed 3 months ago. On speculum examination, the vagina is erythematous and covered in copious white discharge. Her vaginal pH is 4.4, and a potassium hydroxide preparation shows multiple pseudohyphae. Hemoglobin A1c is 7.2% (4.8%–6.0%). Which one of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While swimming pools do not predispose to Candida infection in general, there is a debate about whether wearing damp, tight-fitting bathing suits for an extended period of time might create an optimal environment for yeast and promote overgrowth. However, another predisposing factor is much more significant in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Frequent vaginal douching to cleanse the inside of the vagina and the use of soaps with perfumes and irritating chemicals are risk factors for bacterial vaginosis because they disturb the normal vaginal microflora. Vaginal douching decreases the amount of lactic acid-producing lactobacilli, which leads to an increase in the pH balance. A pH higher than 4.5 is no longer acidic enough to prevent the proliferation of certain organisms, and contributes, e.g., to an increase in Gardnerella vaginalis.

C) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine devices may be associated with gynecologic infections and pelvic inflammatory disease. However, the risk is very low, making another cause much more likely in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus (DM) predisposes to vaginal yeast infections since high levels of glucose provide the carbon needed for Candida overgrowth and infection. Moreover, DM results in immunodeficiency, which is also associated with an increased risk of persistent or recurrent yeast infection. Other risk factors that precipitate overgrowth of C. albicans are systemic antibiotic therapy and pregnancy, in which case high levels of estrogen favor overgrowth by Candida. Treatment of acute infection consists of topical azoles (e.g., miconazole, clotrimazole) or a single dose of oral fluconazole. Maintaining normal blood sugar levels may help reduce the risk of recurrent or persistent infections in patients with DM.

Key learning point: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus is a major risk factor for vulvovaginal candidiasis due to increased glucose availability and impaired immune defenses.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

E) INCORRECT:

Unprotected sexual intercourse is a risk factor for several sexually transmitted infections, such as trichomoniasis and Chlamydia. However, Candida overgrowth is commonly precipitated by other factors.
questions.hint: Multiple pseudohyphae on wet mount preparation are characteristic of Candida infection.

questions.text: You are seeing a previously healthy 15-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic by her parents because of 10 days of lethargy, increased thirst, and urinary frequency. She is 173 cm tall and weighs 54 kg; BMI is 18. Physical examination is normal. Her serum glucose concentration is 12.4 mmol/L (4.0–6.0). A urine dipstick is positive for ketone bodies. You diagnose type 1 diabetes mellitus. Which one of the following is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of her condition?

choices.text: Expression of human leukocyte antigen subtype A3.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pancreatic islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP) deposition happens in type 2 diabetes, not type 1 diabetes. IAPP is cosecreted with insulin; as peripheral insulin resistance worsens in type 2 diabetes, β cells increase insulin synthesis and secretion, which subsequently leads to increased IAPP secretion as well. In the late stages of the disease, the amyloid aggregates become toxic to β cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Expression of human leukocyte antigen (HLA) subtype A3 is associated with hemochromatosis, while type 1 diabetes is associated with HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4. Although hemochromatosis can present with diabetes mellitus (due to pancreas damage following iron accumulation), symptoms such as cirrhosis and a characteristic bronze skin tone, arthralgias, and cardiomyopathy would be expected. Furthermore, hemochromatosis commonly affects adults.

C) INCORRECT:

Some patients with type 1 diabetes develop insulin receptor antibodies, which attack the insulin receptor. However, complement-mediated destruction of insulin receptors has not been identified as a cause of type 1 diabetes.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus, infiltration of autoreactive CD4 and CD8 positive T cells into the pancreatic islets leads to the progressive destruction of insulin-producing β cells, which ultimately results in insulin deficiency. The immune system is thought to be activated by one or more environmental triggers (e.g., a viral infection, dietary factors) in genetically susceptible individuals. The loss of functioning β cells continues over months to years; symptoms usually manifest once 80–90% of β cells have been destroyed.

Key learning point: Type 1 diabetes mellitus is caused by autoimmune T-cell–mediated destruction of pancreatic beta cells, leading to absolute insulin deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Antimitochondrial antibodies are not associated with type 1 diabetes mellitus. They are, however, commonly seen in primary biliary cholangitis. Type 1 diabetes mellitus is typically associated with anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies.
questions.hint: This slim adolescent presents with classic features of type 1 diabetes mellitus: polydipsia, polyuria, hyperglycemia, and ketonuria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 4-month history of increased urinary frequency. He reports waking up several times each night to urinate and feels fatigued during the day. He also describes increased thirst, drinking multiple liters of water and soda daily but still feeling thirsty. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are patches of velvety hyperpigmentation in the axillae and on the posterior neck. Laboratory evaluation in this patient is most likely to show which one of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Elevated glycated hemoglobin is detected by measuring serum HbA1c. HbA1c levels can be elevated in patients with diabetes mellitus and correlate with the average blood glucose level from the previous 8–12 weeks. This patient's polyuria and polydipsia are most likely caused by consistently elevated glucose serum levels over 10 mmol/L, which marks the limit of renal glucose reabsorption capacity. The subsequent glucosuria leads to polyuria through osmotic diuresis. The increased renal water loss causes polydipsia and potentially hypovolemia, which explains this patient's symptoms.

Key learning point: Type 2 diabetes mellitus is diagnosed by elevated glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c), reflecting chronic hyperglycemia and correlating with symptoms like polyuria, polydipsia, and acanthosis nigricans.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) can be seen in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or malignant prostate cancer. Obstructive BPH is associated with increased urinary frequency and nocturia in middle-aged men. However, patients with BPH usually complain of urinary dribbling, unsuccessful emptying of the bladder, and, occasionally, overflow incontinence. Polydipsia is uncommon.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum thyroxine is a laboratory finding that suggests hyperthyroidism (e.g., Graves disease or thyroid adenoma). A hyperthyroid metabolic state can cause fatigue. However, hyperthyroidism does not typically cause polyuria, polydipsia, or hyperpigmentation. Moreover, this patient shows none of the classical features of hyperthyroidism, e.g., diarrhea, palpitations, heat intolerance, tachycardia, or diaphoresis.

D) INCORRECT:

Low urine osmolality indicates very dilute urine; this is observed in patients with diabetes insipidus, which also causes polyuria and polydipsia. However, low urine osmolality is uncommon in diabetes mellitus. Normal or elevated urine osmolality is expected as a result of glucosuria. Additionally, this patient's acanthosis nigricans would not be explained by diabetes insipidus.

E) INCORRECT:

Positive urinary leukocyte esterase suggests a urinary tract infection. Common manifestations include fever, pain or burning with urination, urinary frequency, or foul-smelling urine. Although this patient complains of increased urinary frequency, it has been present for several months, and he does not show any other signs or symptoms of infection.
questions.hint: Polyuria, polydipsia, and acanthosis nigricans in an adult suggest insulin resistance, which is the underlying pathology of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with hypertension comes to your clinic because of frequent urination and increased thirst. He drinks 4 oz of alcohol daily and has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He is 180 cm tall and weighs 106 kg; body mass index is 33. His blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin A1c of 8.5% (4.8%–6.0%). Which one of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excessive alcohol consumption is a risk factor for the development of acute and chronic pancreatitis, alcohol-associated liver disease, and malignancies such as esophageal squamous cell carcinoma. However, alcohol consumption is not associated with an increased risk of T2DM.

B) INCORRECT:

HLA-DR4 is strongly associated with numerous autoimmune diseases, including type I diabetes mellitus (T1DM). However, this patient has T2DM, which is caused by a combination of hereditary and environmental factors and is strongly associated with metabolic syndrome. T2DM is not an autoimmune condition and is not associated with HLA-DR4.

C) INCORRECT:

While the prevalence of type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) is highest among non-Hispanic White individuals, this patient has T2DM. The highest rates of T2DM are seen among Hispanic, African American, Native American, Asian American, and Pacific Islander populations. White race is not a risk factor for T2DM.

D) INCORRECT:

Smoking is the leading risk factor for the development of lung and pancreatic cancer and it increases the risk for various conditions. While there could theoretically be a link between smoking and T2DM (e.g., impairment of insulin sensitivity and an increase in blood glucose concentration in smokers), there is no definitive evidence of a causal association.

E) CORRECT:

A high-calorie diet and a sedentary lifestyle are risk factors for obesity (BMI > 30 kg/m2), which increases the risk of T2DM by intensifying peripheral insulin resistance. Insulin resistance inhibits glucose uptake from the bloodstream and impairs anabolic metabolism. Lifestyle modifications such as weight reduction, a balanced diet, and regular exercise reduce the risk of developing T2DM.

Key learning point: A high-calorie diet and sedentary lifestyle are major modifiable risk factors for type 2 diabetes mellitus due to their role in promoting obesity and insulin resistance.
questions.hint: Polyuria (frequent urination), polydipsia (increased thirst), and an elevated hemoglobin A1c in this middle-aged man suggest type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up. On examination, you note hyperpigmented plaques on the posterior neck and in the axillae. His hemoglobin A1c is 7.4% (4.8%–6.0%) and his fasting serum glucose is 9.7 mmol/L (4.0–6.0). Which one of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for these laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Individuals of Hispanic, African American, and Asian ethnicity have a greater risk for type 2 diabetes mellitus than white individuals. However, ethnicity is not the strongest predisposing factor for developing type 2 diabetes mellitus.

B) INCORRECT:

New studies have shown that smoking is an independent risk factor for developing type 2 diabetes but smoking is not the strongest predisposing factor for developing type 2 diabetes mellitus.

C) CORRECT:

A high waist circumference or waist-to-hip ratio is a sign of central obesity, which is a strong predisposing factor for the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Increased abdominal and visceral fat is associated with increased lipolytic activity and increased levels of serum free fatty acids. Increased levels of fatty acids induce insulin resistance by decreasing peripheral insulin-mediated glucose uptake.

Key learning point: Central obesity, indicated by a high waist circumference, is the strongest modifiable risk factor for developing type 2 diabetes mellitus and associated conditions like acanthosis nigricans.

D) INCORRECT:

Elevated systolic blood pressure in hypertensive patients is a diagnostic criterion for metabolic syndrome. Although patients with metabolic syndrome have an increased risk of developing diabetes, elevated systolic blood pressure alone is not a risk factor for type 2 diabetes.

E) INCORRECT:

Childhood obesity increases the risk of type 2 diabetes but it is not the strongest predisposing factor because losing weight before puberty decreases this risk to the same level as those without childhood obesity.
questions.hint: This patient's laboratory studies (elevated HbA1c and fasting serum glucose levels) and skin findings (acanthosis nigricans) are consistent with a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: You are seeing a 41-year-old man with well-controlled asthma who was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes after a fasting blood glucose of 7.3 mmol/L (4.0–6.0) and a glycated hemoglobin of 7.5% (4.8%–6.0%). His BMI is 27. He was advised to follow diet and exercise recommendations. At a 6-month follow-up, he reports adherence to these recommendations, but his weight and BMI are unchanged, and his glycated hemoglobin is now 8.0% (4.8%–6.0%). He uses inhaled fluticasone daily and a short-acting beta-agonist inhaler as needed. He has no allergies. Physical examination is normal. Serum creatinine is normal, and there is no albuminuria. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in his care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inhaled glucocorticoids at standard doses for asthma do not generally result in steroid-induced diabetes; if this patient’s asthma is well controlled on inhaled fluticasone, that medication should be continued.

B) INCORRECT:

Lifestyle modifications (eating a balanced diet, engaging in physical activity, and aiming to lose weight, when indicated) are integral to managing type 2 diabetes. However, if the patient’s blood glucose and glycated hemoglobin levels do not respond sufficiently to a reasonable trial of lifestyle modification, pharmacotherapy should be initiated.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists (e.g., liraglutide) have been shown to have a variety of benefits beyond glucose lowering, including a reduced risk of cardiovascular events, delayed progression of diabetic kidney disease, and weight loss. However, because of their high cost, these agents are generally not considered first-line therapy unless metformin is contraindicated or not tolerated. Given accumulating evidence on the nonglycemic benefits of these agents, guidelines currently suggest incorporating GLP-1 receptor agonists into the glucose-lowering regimens of patients for whom the nonglycemic benefits are particularly desirable (e.g., those with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease or at high cardiovascular risk). This patient does not fit into that category.

D) INCORRECT:

Sulfonylureas (e.g., glyburide) cause weight gain, may result in hypoglycemia, and lack evidence for nonglycemic benefits. Therefore, despite their low cost, they are generally not considered first-line treatment.

E) CORRECT:

Metformin is generally the preferred initial agent for treating new-onset type 2 diabetes (in the absence of drug intolerance or contraindications to its use, such as renal impairment or uncompensated heart failure). Metformin is safe and effective, is not associated with weight gain or hypoglycemia, and may reduce the risk of cardiovascular events and cancers.

Key learning point: In the absence of contraindications, the recommended first-line treatments for patients with new-onset type 2 diabetes are lifestyle modification and metformin.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and obesity (BMI 36) comes to your clinic to discuss weight-loss options. His glycated hemoglobin is 7.3% (4.8%–6.0%) while taking metformin 1000 mg twice daily and sitagliptin 100 mg daily. He has not previously participated in a formal weight-loss program but is now interested. You recommend that he enroll in a local behavioral weight-loss program that offers weekly group and individual counseling, focuses on caloric restriction to 1500–1800 calories per day, and encourages at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise daily. Which one of the following outcomes can this patient reasonably expect if he loses 7% to 10% of his body weight within one year after starting the recommended program?

choices.text: Decrease in physical quality of life.
Reduced use of prescription diabetes medications.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Obesity is a strong risk factor for urinary incontinence. Weight loss may help reduce this risk and, in some studies, has been associated with improvement and resolution of incontinence.

B) INCORRECT:

In the Look AHEAD trial, more than 5000 patients with type 2 diabetes and a BMI ≥ 25 were randomized to receive either an intensive lifestyle intervention that focused on increased physical activity and caloric restriction or routine diabetes support and education. At one year, the intervention group lost significantly more body weight than the control group (mean loss, 8.6% vs. 0.7%) and had substantial improvements in glycemic control despite a significant decrease in the proportion of individuals using diabetes medications. They also had improvements in systolic blood pressure, physical quality of life, sleep apnea, sexual function, and depressive symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone mineral density (BMD) tends to decline in patients who lose weight, an effect that is most marked after bariatric surgery. There are many reasons for this decline, including lower mechanical loading of the bone, malabsorption of vitamin D and calcium, and possibly hormonal changes; in addition, the presence of less soft tissue may artificially lower the BMD obtained by a standard dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry scan. With diet-induced weight loss, there is a loss of BMD, particularly at the hip, but this is quite small in magnitude. In the Look AHEAD trial, the adjudicated fracture rates were no different between the two groups.

D) INCORRECT:

There is no increased risk of nephrolithiasis with weight loss. However, cholelithiasis is common after the rapid weight loss induced by bariatric surgery, and there is also an increased risk with very-low-calorie diets (< 800 calories daily). The data on cholelithiasis after moderate weight loss (defined as 7%–10% of body weight within a year) are less clear, with some studies suggesting an increased risk of gallstone disease even in this setting.

E) CORRECT:

Weight loss in individuals with overweight or obesity is associated with a multitude of health benefits, including glycemic control in those with type 2 diabetes. In the Look AHEAD trial, more than 5000 patients with type 2 diabetes and a BMI ≥ 25 were randomized to receive either an intensive lifestyle intervention that focused on increased physical activity and caloric restriction or routine diabetes support and education. At one year, the intervention group lost significantly more body weight than the control group (mean loss, 8.6% vs. 0.7%) and had substantial improvements in glycemic control despite a significant decrease in the proportion of individuals using diabetes medications. They also had improvements in systolic blood pressure, physical quality of life, sleep apnea, sexual function, and depressive symptoms. In addition, fewer individuals in the intervention group than the control group had to start medications for hypertension and dyslipidemia.

Key learning point: In adults with type 2 diabetes and a BMI ≥ 25, intensive lifestyle interventions that result in a loss of 7% to 10% of body weight have been shown to lead to a host of health benefits, including long-term improvements in glycemic control and reduced use of diabetes medications.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes comes to your clinic for follow-up. Since her last visit 6 months ago, she has lost 4.5 kg through diet and exercise. Her medications include metformin, lisinopril, and a multivitamin. Her blood pressure is 123/74 mm Hg, and her BMI is 22. Physical examination is unremarkable. A fasting lipid panel shows the following results:


Cholesterol, total, blood
4.9 mmol/L (3.5–5.2)


Cholesterol, LDL, blood
2.5 mmol/L (see the LDL Analysis table below)


Cholesterol, HDL, blood
1.1 mmol/L (>1.3)


Triglycerides, blood
2.9 mmol/L (≤1.7)


LDL Analysis


Cardiovascular Disease Risk
When to Consider Initiating Treatment
Treatment Target



High and intermediate
LDL level of ≥ 3.5 mmol/L
LDL level of < 2.0 mmol/L or ≥50% reduction in pretherapy LDL level


Low
LDL level of > 5.0 mmol/L
≥50% reduction in pretherapy LDL level



Which one of the following treatments is recommended to minimize her long-term cardiovascular risk?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ezetimibe is a second-line lipid-lowering agent that can be used for additional atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease risk reduction in patients who do not achieve target LDL reduction with the maximally tolerated dose of first-line therapy. This patient's LDL cholesterol is within the reference range.

B) INCORRECT:

Icosapent ethyl effectively reduces triglyceride concentrations, especially in individuals with severe hypertriglyceridemia (> 5.65 mmol/L). Studies have shown cardiovascular benefit when icosapent ethyl is added to a statin in patients with hypertriglyceridemia who are at high cardiovascular risk (due to established ASCVD or to type 2 diabetes with at least one additional ASCVD risk factor). Current guidelines therefore suggest considering icosapent ethyl as an addition to a statin in this patient population. However, starting a statin should take precedence.

C) CORRECT:

Current cholesterol treatment guidelines from the American College of Cardiology (ACC) and the American Heart Association (AHA) outline four “statin benefit” groups for whom atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk reduction clearly outweighs the risk for adverse events. One of those groups is patients aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of their estimated risk for ASCVD. These patients should receive at least moderate-intensity statin therapy. If they have multiple ASCVD risk factors, they should receive a high-intensity statin, with the goal of reducing LDL-cholesterol levels by ≥ 50% to a target LDL-cholesterol level of < 1.81 mmol/L. This patient should receive a moderate-intensity statin.

Key learning point: Regardless of estimated risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, primary prevention in patients aged 40 to 75 years with type 2 diabetes should include at least moderate-intensity statin therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

E) INCORRECT:

Nicotinic acid and fibrates have not been consistently shown to lower cardiovascular risk and are generally reserved for patients with a severely elevated triglyceride level or a very low HDL-cholesterol level.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to your clinic because of increased frequency of urination over the past month. He has also been waking up frequently at night to urinate. Over the past 2 months, he has lost 3.2 kg. He is in the 40th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination is normal. Serum electrolytes, creatinine, and osmolality are within the reference range. Urinalysis shows 1+ glucose. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Compulsive water intake is a feature of primary polydipsia, which is a condition seen in individuals with psychiatric diseases (e.g., schizophrenia, obsessive-compulsive disorder). It is characterized by a compulsion to drink large amounts of fluid despite the absence of thirst, resulting in polyuria with low urine osmolality and hyponatremia. Since the patient's parents report no unusual behavior, and urine osmolality and serum electrolyte levels are normal, primary polydipsia can be ruled out.

B) INCORRECT:

An inadequate ADH secretion is seen in individuals with central diabetes insipidus and is caused by an absent or insufficient hypothalamic synthesis of ADH. The lack of ADH impairs the kidney's ability to concentrate urine, resulting in polyuria (> 3 L/day) with diluted urine, nocturia, and polydipsia. Urine osmolality is typically < 300 mmol/kg, and is often < 100 mmol/kg. Since urine osmolality in this patient is normal, inadequate ADH secretion can be ruled out.

C) INCORRECT:

Insulin resistance is a pathophysiological feature of type 2 diabetes mellitus, which typically develops in individuals with obesity, a genetic disposition (first-degree relative with diabetes), and features of metabolic syndrome. Affected individuals are usually > 40 years old, though onset can also rarely occur in teenagers with obesity. Since this patient is young, has no family history of serious illness, and is of normal weight, type 2 diabetes mellitus is unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Absolute insulin deficiency is the underlying pathology of type 1 diabetes mellitus, caused by autoimmune-mediated destruction of pancreatic β cells. The resulting elevation of blood glucose levels leads to a range of symptoms, typically including polyuria, nocturia, polydipsia, and increased appetite. Nonspecific symptoms of fatigue, weight loss, and an increased tendency to infections (e.g., skin infections, UTIs) are also common. The symptoms usually develop within days to a few weeks or manifest suddenly with diabetic ketoacidosis. While glucosuria detected via urine dipstick is suggestive of diabetes mellitus, the diagnosis is confirmed through an oral glucose tolerance test or a random blood glucose level ≥ 11 mmol/L.

Key learning point: Insulin deficiency leads to hyperglycemia, resulting in polyuria and glucosuria due to the inability of the kidneys to reabsorb excess filtered glucose.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal resistance to ADH is seen in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) and is caused by defects in ADH receptors. These defects can be due to drugs, hypokalemia, or renal disease. Lack of response to ADH impairs the kidney's ability to concentrate urine, resulting in polyuria (> 3 L/day) with diluted urine, nocturia, and polydipsia. Urine osmolality is typically < 300 mmol/kg, and is often < 100 mmol/kg. Since urine osmolality in this patient is normal, nephrogenic DI can be ruled out.
questions.hint: Polyuria, nocturia, and weight loss in an adolescent with 1+ glucose on urine dipstick are suggestive of type 1 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman comes to your clinic for a general preventive visit. She has no known medical conditions and takes only a multivitamin. Her last visit to a physician was 6 years ago. On examination, her blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, height is 168 cm, and weight is 88 kg (BMI 31). Lung, heart, and abdominal examinations are normal. Which one of the following screening tests or interventions should you recommend for this patient?

choices.text: No additional screening is required at this time.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The CTFPHC does not recommend advising women to routinely practice breast self-examination to screen for breast cancer because there is no evidence that this practice reduces mortality, and it may lead to unnecessary biopsies. For average-risk women, the CTFPHC recommends screening mammography every 2–3 years for those aged 50–74; routine screening is not advised for women aged 40–49, although those who wish to be screened after an informed discussion may be offered mammography on an individual basis.

B) INCORRECT:

A specific screening test is recommended for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine screening for vitamin D deficiency is not recommended because there is insufficient evidence of benefit. This patient is already taking a multivitamin and, therefore, is likely getting the recommended daily amount of vitamin D.

D) INCORRECT:

The CTFPHC recommends colorectal cancer screening among patients aged 50–74 years with fecal occult blood testing every 2 years or flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years, but advises against routine screening before age 50 or after age 74.

E) CORRECT:

According to Canadian guidelines, adults should have their 10-year risk of type 2 diabetes (T2DM) estimated with a validated risk calculator such as the Finnish Diabetes Risk Score (FINDRISC) or Canadian Diabetes Risk Questionnaire (CANRISK). The CTFPHC advises that asymptomatic adults ≥ 18 years of age with one or more risk factors (e.g., obesity, hypertension) undergo this risk assessment every 3–5 years. Diabetes Canada recommends the risk assessment for all adults aged 40–74 years and for younger adults with additional risk factors. These risk calculators can categorize patients as low risk, moderate risk, high risk, and very high risk based on their 10-year probability of T2DM.

The CTFPHC recommends a blood test for T2DM every 3–5 years in high-risk individuals and annually in those at very high risk. Diabetes Canada advises blood test screening every 3 years for individuals at high risk and those ≥ 40 years of age. Earlier or more frequent testing is recommended for individuals at very high risk or strong risk factors such as overweight, family history, hypertension, or dyslipidemia (including HDL < 1.0 mmol/L). The preferred screening test is glycated hemoglobin (A1C), but fasting plasma glucose or the 2-hour oral glucose-tolerance test are acceptable alternatives.

Key learning point: Individuals aged 40–74 years and those with risk factors for type 2 diabetes mellitus should have their 10-year risk assessed using a validated tool (e.g., FINDRISC, CANRISK).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of sickle cell trait presents to the emergency department after a low-speed RTC. He reports striking a street sign he did not see while driving at night. He reports that over the past month, his vision has become progressively blurred, especially at distance, and he has been increasingly thirsty and urinating frequently. He reports a 15-pound (6.8 kg) weight loss despite eating more than normal as he felt increasingly hungry. He denies loss of consciousness or injury. Vital signs are BP, 145/85 mm Hg; P, 88; T, 37.0°C (98.6°F). Physical examination shows no injuries but mild dehydration and the finding shown in the photograph in both axilla. He last ate 2 hours ago. Which test would be most appropriate to establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Random blood glucose ≥200 mg/dL in a patient with classic symptoms of hyperglycemia is diagnostic for diabetes mellitus. This patient presents with the classic triad of polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss, making random glucose the most appropriate immediate test regardless of recent food intake.

B) INCORRECT:

Urinalysis for glucosuria is nonspecific and unreliable for diagnosing diabetes mellitus. Glucosuria can occur with normal blood glucose levels or may be absent despite hyperglycemia, making direct blood glucose measurement the preferred approach.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral glucose tolerance test is the most sensitive test for diabetes but is time-consuming, expensive, and impractical in the emergency department. It would be unnecessary when a simpler test can establish the diagnosis in a symptomatic patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Fasting plasma glucose would require the patient to fast for more than 8 hours, which is impractical in the emergency department setting when a patient presents with classic symptoms. Additionally, the patient ate 2 hours ago, making this test unsuitable at present.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemoglobin A1c may be falsely low in patients with sickle cell trait due to decreased red blood cell lifespan, making it unreliable for diagnosis in this patient. While HbA1c ≥6.5% can diagnose diabetes, it would not be the most appropriate choice given this patient's underlying hemoglobinopathy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of increasing fatigue, thirst, and frequent urination. He has a history of hypertension and obesity. His BMI is 34 kg/m². Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin A1c of 8.5%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathophysiologic mechanism for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Increased glucagon secretion from pancreatic alpha cells
Decreased glucose uptake by skeletal muscle and adipose tissue
Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reduced hepatic glucose production describes the opposite of what occurs in type 2 diabetes mellitus. Insulin normally suppresses glucose production (gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis) by the liver. Due to hepatic insulin resistance, this suppression is lost, leading to increased or unopposed hepatic glucose output, which is a major contributor to fasting hyperglycemia.

B) INCORRECT:

While inappropriately elevated glucagon levels contribute to hyperglycemia in type 2 diabetes mellitus by promoting hepatic glucose production, this is considered a secondary phenomenon. The primary defect is peripheral insulin resistance. The lack of insulin's normal suppressive effect on alpha cells leads to dysregulation, but it is not the initial or central cause.

C) CORRECT:

The primary pathophysiologic mechanism behind type 2 diabetes is insulin resistance, in which peripheral tissues, particularly skeletal muscle and adipose tissue, fail to respond effectively to insulin. Insulin normally facilitates glucose entry into these cells via GLUT4 transporters. In an insulin-resistant state, this process is impaired, leading to decreased glucose uptake from the bloodstream and subsequent hyperglycemia. Obesity is a major contributor to insulin resistance, as excess adipose tissue releases inflammatory cytokines and free fatty acids that interfere with insulin signaling. Initially, the pancreas compensates by producing more insulin (hyperinsulinemia), but eventually, beta-cell function declines, leading to relative insulin deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

This mechanism describes the pathophysiology of type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). T1DM is an autoimmune condition that typically presents in younger, non-obese individuals and results in an absolute deficiency of insulin. This patient's age, obesity, and gradual onset of symptoms are not characteristic of T1DM.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation, including his age and obesity, as well as increased hemoglobin A1c, is consistent with type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the clinic for an annual wellness examination. She has no current complaints. Her last pregnancy 3 years ago was complicated by gestational diabetes, which resolved postpartum. Her father has type 2 diabetes mellitus. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 132/84 mm Hg. Her BMI is 28 kg/m². The remainder of her examination is unremarkable. According to current guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding screening for diabetes mellitus in this patient?

choices.text: Screen now with a 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test
No screening is indicated due to her age
Screen now with a hemoglobin A1c

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Screening is indicated now for this patient. A 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test is an acceptable method for screening. However, it is more cumbersome for the patient than a hemoglobin A1c or fasting plasma glucose because it requires fasting and a 2-hour wait. It is not considered uniquely superior for routine screening in a non-pregnant adult.

B) INCORRECT:

Although this patient is 32 years old, which is below the universal screening age of 35, her multiple risk factors make screening appropriate. A history of gestational diabetes, a family history of diabetes, and overweight are all strong indications for screening regardless of age.

C) CORRECT:

This patient requires screening for type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) now, despite being younger than the universal screening age of 35. Guidelines recommend earlier screening for adults with a BMI ≥25 kg/m² and at least one additional risk factor. This patient has multiple risk factors: a history of gestational diabetes (GDM), a first-degree relative with diabetes, and a BMI in the overweight range. Women with a history of GDM have a very high risk of developing T2DM and should be screened every 1–3 years for life. A hemoglobin A1c is one of three appropriate initial screening tests, along with fasting plasma glucose and a 2-hour oral glucose tolerance test. It is often preferred for its convenience because it does not require fasting.

D) INCORRECT:

While current guidelines recommend screening all adults for type 2 diabetes mellitus beginning at age 35, this recommendation applies to individuals without risk factors. This patient has several significant risk factors, including a history of gestational diabetes, a first-degree relative with diabetes, and a BMI of 28 kg/m², which necessitate earlier screening.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes for a routine follow-up. His medical history is significant for a myocardial infarction 2 years ago, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. His current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. He is adherent to his medication but has struggled with diet and exercise. He is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 88 kg (193 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m². Laboratory results show a hemoglobin A1c of 8.2% and an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 75 mL/min/1.73 m². In addition to reinforcing lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate medication to add to this patient's regimen for glycemic control?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pioglitazone, a thiazolidinedione, improves insulin sensitivity and can lower HbA1c. However, its use is limited by side effects, including weight gain, fluid retention, and an increased risk of precipitating or worsening heart failure. Given this patient's history of myocardial infarction, initiating a medication with a known risk of causing fluid retention and heart failure is not appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Sitagliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor that can improve glycemic control. Although it is weight-neutral and has a low risk of hypoglycemia, large clinical trials have shown that DPP-4 inhibitors are cardiovascularly neutral. They do not provide the secondary prevention benefit needed for this patient with a history of myocardial infarction, making other agents a better choice.

C) INCORRECT:

Glipizide is a sulfonylurea that effectively lowers blood glucose by stimulating insulin secretion. However, this class of medication does not offer any cardiovascular protection and is associated with significant side effects, including weight gain and a high risk of hypoglycemia. For a patient with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease and obesity, agents with proven cardiovascular benefits and favorable weight profiles are preferred.

D) CORRECT:

Liraglutide, a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist, has demonstrated a significant reduction in major adverse cardiovascular events in high-risk patients. Additionally, GLP-1 receptor agonists promote weight loss, which is a desirable effect in this patient with a BMI of 31 kg/m². Current guidelines strongly recommend adding an agent with proven cardiovascular benefit in a patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus with established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Given its dual benefit of improving glycemic control and providing secondary cardiovascular prevention, liraglutide is the most appropriate choice.
questions.hint: For patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, the choice of a second-line agent should prioritize medications with proven cardiovascular benefit.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of numbness and burning sensation in his feet that is worse at rest. He has not been seen by a physician in several years. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 118 kg (260 lb); BMI is 37 kg/m2. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick, light touch, and vibration over the soles of both feet. Ankle jerk is 1+ bilaterally. His hemoglobin A1C concentration is 10.2%. Which of the following pathophysiological processes is most likely to be involved in this patient's condition?

choices.text: Deposition of antiglutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies
Increased production of adiponectin by adipocytes
Expression of human leukocyte antigen subtype DR4

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Accumulation of islet amyloid polypeptide (proamylin) is the most likely process involved in this patient's type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). In this disease, peripheral insulin resistance creates a huge demand for glucose lowering hormones, resulting in increased production of proinsulin and proamylin. The pancreatic proteolytic enzymes that convert proinsulin and proamylin into insulin and amylin are not able to keep up with the high levels of production, which leads to the accumulation of proamylin. Although the exact role of amylin in the pathogenesis of T2DM is unknown, proamylin accumulation is thought to be responsible for the eventual decrease in insulin production in T2DM.

B) INCORRECT:

Antiglutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies (anti-GAD) target pancreatic islet cells, leading to the destruction of insulin-producing beta cells and impaired insulin secretion. Deposition of anti-GAD antibodies is characteristic of type 1 diabetes, not type 2 diabetes.

C) INCORRECT:

Binding of autoantibodies to islet cell antigens and complement activation is involved in the pathogenesis of type 1 diabetes mellitus. However, destruction of insulin receptors is not involved in the pathogenesis of either type 1 or type 2 diabetes mellitus.

D) INCORRECT:

Adiponectin is an adipocyte-derived cytokine that would help prevent, not cause, type 2 diabetes. Adiponectin is associated with improved blood glucose control and lipid profiles in patients with type 2 DM. Adiponectin is downregulated in obesity, which may contribute to the development of insulin resistance in type 2 diabetes.

E) INCORRECT:

Expression of human leukocyte antigen (HLA) subtypes HLA-DR3 and HLA-DR4 are associated with type 1 DM and other autoimmune diseases. Type 2 diabetes, which occurs primarily because of peripheral insulin resistance, is not an autoimmune process and is not associated with HLA-DR4.

F) INCORRECT:

Insulitis or lymphocyte infiltration of the islets of Langerhans can result in the destruction of the insulin-producing beta cells and impaired insulin secretion. Lymphocytic infiltration of islet cells is seen in type 1 diabetes, not type 2 diabetes.
questions.hint: This patient's elevated HbA1C indicates chronically elevated serum glucose. Given this patient's high BMI and age, the most likely cause is type 2 diabetes mellitus. His neurological findings are a result of diabetic microvascular disease and osmotic damage of the peripheral nervous system (diabetic neuropathy).
